questions.text: A 22-day-old baby presenting with seizures, increased head size over the past week, and a sunset sign in the eyes, what is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Aqueductal stenosis

  • Aqueductal Stenosis is one of the defined causes of hydrocephalus and the most common cause of congenital (present at birth) hydrocephalus.
    • Leads to internal hydrocephalus.
    • Lateral and  third ventricle dilates.
    • The forebrain will die due to the flattening effect.
    • Treatment can be through endoscopic third ventriculostomy, shunt placement, endoscopic aqueductoplasty,­ and stent placement.

  • Congenital hydrocephalus is a collection of excess cerebrospinal fluid in the brain at birth. The extra fluid may increase pressure in the brain and can result in brain damage. It can also cause mental and physical problems. Long-term effects mostly depend on what causes the fluid collection and how the baby responds to treatment.
  • Congenital hydrocephalus can be caused by.
    • Bleeding in the fetus before birth.
    • Certain maternal infections (toxoplasmosis or syphilis)
    • Other birth defects, like spina bifida.
    • Genetic defects or structural defects.

Option A: Cranium bifidum with meningoencephalocele

  • Doesn't cause congenital hydrocephalus.

Option B: Cranium bifidum with meningohydroencephalocele

  • Doesn't cause congenital hydrocephalus.

Option D: Arnold Chiari syndrome

  • It can cause hydrocephalus but is not a common cause of congenital hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presenting with generalized weakness and decreased sensations on the left side of her body, the Neurology OPD examination involves rubbing a wisp of cotton on her fingertip with closed eyes. What sensory function does this test assess, and what is the underlying mediation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Anterior spinothalamic tract

  • The Spinothalamic tract has two adjacent pathways: The anterior pathway and the lateral pathway.
  • The anterior spinothalamic tract carries information about simple touch. The lateral spinothalamic tract conveys pain and temperature.
  • The anterior spinothalamic tract is concerned with a light touch-sensation produced by stroking the skin with a wisp of cotton. The slow conducting fibres carry in this sensation.
  • The anterior spinothalamic tract carries sensory information regarding light and poorly localised touch. This information is carried in slow-conducting fibres (Aδ and C fibres) in contrast to the rapidly conducting fibres carrying information about pain and temperature.
  • After joining the spinal cord, the fibres cross after ascending 1–2 segments and synapse in Lissauer's tract. From there, the fibres ascend to the lateral or anterior spinothalamic tract and terminate in the ventral posterior nucleus of the thalamus.
  • The fibres are also given off reticular formation and periaqueductal grey matter. The cerebral sensory cortex receives the final projections.

Option A: Anterior corticospinal tract

  • The anterior corticospinal tract controls the movement of the trunk muscles, for example, the neck-shoulder.
  • The lateral corticospinal tract functions for controlling the movement of the limb muscles.

Option B: Anterior spinocerebellar tract

  • The spinocerebellar tract is involved in the unconscious proprioception from the peripheral receptors to the cerebellum through the spinal cord. The anterior spinocerebellar tract carries the proprioception from the lower limb to the cerebellum through the spinal cord.

Option D: Cuneocerebellar tract

  • The Cuneo-cerebellar tract involves the unconscious proprioception from the upper limb to the cerebellum through the spinal cord.
  • The spinocerebellar tract carries the proprioception from the lower limb to the cerebellum through the spinal cord.

questions.text: A 9-month-old girl is admitted to the hospital with tachypnea and shortness of breath. On physical examination, there is tachycardia and a bounding peripheral pulse, and her angiograms show a patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following embryonic arterial structures is responsible for developing the ductus arteriosus?
questions.solution:
Option D: Left sixth arch

  • The ductus arteriosus and the pulmonary arteries develop from the left sixth aortic arch.
  • The ductus arteriosus closes functionally in an infant soon after birth, with anatomic closure requiring several weeks, but persistent 6th arch artery leads to PDA.

Patent Ductus arteriosus:

  • PDA is the connection of the left pulmonary artery to the beginning of the descending aorta.
  • During fetal life, blood passes through it from the pulmonary artery to the aorta, thus passing to the lungs.
  • It normally constricts after birth and later becomes ligamentum arteriosum.
  • Failure of the ductus arteriosus to close may occur as an isolated congenital abnormality or may be associated with congenital heart disease.
  • Indomethacin helps close PDA.
  • Prostaglandins E1 & E2 keep PDA open

Option A: Right fourth arch

  • It forms the proximal right subclavian artery

Option B: Left fifth arch

  • The whole fifth arch regresses and does not contribute to any structure.

Option C: Right fifth arch

  • The fifth arch does not contribute to any structure.
  • It usually regresses.

questions.text: In a 43-year-old female with lower extremity edema, abdominal pain, early satiety, and weight loss, due to a retroperitoneal mass compressing and obstructing the IVC, which structure is not involved in collateral blood supply?

choices.text: Superior epigastric and inferior epigastric vein

questions.solution:
Option B: Superficial epigastric and iliolumbar vein

  • The superficial epigastric vein is a vein that travels with the superficial epigastric artery.
  • It joins the accessory saphenous vein near the fossa ovalis.
  • Superficial Epigastric vein forms collaterals with Lateral Thoracic vein via a thoraco-epigastric vein in case of either IVC or SVC obstruction.
  • The iliolumbar vein is the vena comitans of the iliolumbar artery. The obturator nerve crosses superficial to it. It drains vertebral segments four and five and is closely related to the ascending lumbar vein.
  • Since superficial epigastric and iliolumbar veins drain into IVC, they are not helping the cause.

Option A: Superior epigastric and inferior epigastric vein

  • Superior epigastric and inferior epigastric form collateral in the rectus sheath.
  • Superior epigastric drain into internal thoracic then into SVC which opens into the right atrium, hence blood can be drained from IVC into SVC.

Option C: Azygos and ascending lumbar vein

  • The ascending lumbar vein is a vein that runs up through the lumbar region on the side of the vertebral column.
  • The azygos vein is a vein running up the right side of the thoracic vertebral column draining itself towards the superior vena cava. It connects the systems of superior vena cava and inferior vena cava. It can provide an alternative path for blood to the right atrium when either of the venae cavae is blocked.

Option D: Lateral thoracic and prevertebral vein

  • The lateral thoracic vein (sometimes debatably referred to as the long thoracic vein) is a tributary of the axillary vein. It runs with the lateral thoracic artery and drains the Serratus anterior muscle and the Pectoralis major muscle.
  • The function of the prevertebral vein is to drain the venous blood from the cervical spine and prevertebral and suboccipital muscles. It terminates low in the neck by emptying into the brachiocephalic vein when the IVC is obstructed by the lateral thoracic and prevertebral vein from the collateral supply.

questions.text: A 47-year-old tennis player comes to the office to evaluate shoulder pain during training. The doctor tells her that she has a rotator cuff injury that needs surgery. The doctor explains that over the years of play, a shoulder ligament gradually damaged the muscle underneath badly. Which of the following ligaments is the doctor most likely referring to?
questions.solution:
Option D: Coracoacromian ligament

  • Age-dependent changes due to chronic stress and cellular degradation cause thickening and stiffening of the coracoacromial ligament, leading to capsular tightness, rotator cuff tear arthropathy, and impingement syndrome.
  • The coracoacromial ligament is an integral component of the coracoacromial arch.
  • The coracoacromial arch is formed by the coracoid process, acromion, and the coracoacromial ligament.
  • Structures located in this arch are
    • Subacromian-subdeltoid bursa
    • Supraspinatus tendon
    • The long head of the biceps tendon
  • The stiffening of the ligament leads to the erosion and inflammation of the supraspinatus tendon due to the repetitive movement of the arm during training, resulting in pain and a limited range of motion of the shoulder joint.

Option A: Acromioclavicular ligament.

  • The acromioclavicular ligament, which connects the acromion with the lateral end of the clavicle, has no contact with the supraspinatus tendon.

Option B: Coracohumeral ligament.

  • The coracohumeral ligament is located too anterior to contact the supraspinatus tendon.

Option C: Glenohumeral ligament.

  • The glenohumeral ligament lies deep within the rotator cuff muscles and would not contribute to injury to the supraspinatus.

questions.text: Which muscle is most likely affected in a 45-year-old male who sustained multiple lacerations to the upper limb after walking through a plate glass door while intoxicated, resulting in an inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joints of the second and fifth digits?
questions.solution:
Option A: Flexor digitorum profundus

  • Flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) flexes the distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) of the 2nd to 5th digits.

  • FDP originates from the proximal three-quarters of the anterior and medial surface of the shaft of the ulna and interosseous membrane.
  • FDP has two parts:
    • Medial part: Inserts into the bases of distal phalanges of 4th and 5th digits. It is supplied by the ulnar nerve.
    • Lateral part: Inserts into the bases of distal phalanges of 2nd and 3rd digits. It is supplied by the median nerve.
  • FDP flexes the distal interphalangeal joints and helps in curling the fingers to make a fist.

Option B: Flexor digitorum superficialis

  • Flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS) flexes the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIP) of the medial four fingers.
  • FDS arises via two heads, humero-ulnar and radial. Near the wrist, it gives four tendons enclosed in a common flexor sheath and passes through the carpal tunnel.
  • These tendons insert on the shaft of the middle phalanges of the medial four fingers.
  • FDS is innervated by the median nerve.

  • The figure shows the origin and insertion of flexor digitorum superficialis.

Option C: Lumbricals

  • Lumbricals cause flexion at metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints.
  • Lumbricals originate from the FDP tendons and insert into the lateral sides of the 2nd to 5th digit.

Option D: Dorsal interossei muscles

  • Dorsal interossei originate from the adjacent sides of the two metacarpal bones and insert into the bases of proximal phalanges.
  • These muscles abduct the 2nd to 4th fingers. They also help the lumbricals flex the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the liver center with jaundice and generalized edema. After a thorough assessment, a diagnosis of cryptogenic cirrhosis is made. A liver transplant is planned. During the operation, the transplant doctor asks his junior residents about the anatomy of the liver. Which of the following statements is true about the anatomy and functions of the liver?

choices.text: Receives blood only from the hepatic arteries
Manufactures red blood cells in an adult
Drains bile from the quadrate lobe into the right hepatic duct
Drains venous blood into the hepatic veins

questions.solution:
Option D: Drains venous blood into the hepatic veins

  • The liver receives blood from the portal vein and hepatic artery and drains its venous blood into the hepatic veins
  • From hepatic veins, blood drains into the inferior vena cava.
  • Blood drains from this large vein into the heart's right atrium.

Option A: Receives blood only from the hepatic arteries

  • The liver receives blood from the portal vein and hepatic artery and drains its venous blood into the hepatic veins.

Option B: Manufactures red blood cells in an adult

  • The liver produces red blood cells in the fetus.
  • The liver plays an important role in the production and secretion of bile.
  • The quadrate lobe directs bile into the left  hepatic duct, not the right hepatic duct, while the caudate lobe drains bile into the right and left ducts.
  • The gallbladder works to concentrate and store bile.

Option C: Drains bile from the quadrate lobe into the right hepatic duct

  • The quadrate lobe directs bile into the left hepatic duct, not the right hepatic duct, while the caudate lobe drains bile into the right and left ducts.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presents in the clinic with complaints of abdominal bloating, pain, and nausea for the last 2 weeks. She also reports food intolerance. On detailed evaluation by MRCP, she is diagnosed with a pancreatic divisum. The term indicates:

choices.text: Failure of fusion of dorsal & ventral pancreatic buds
Formation of more than two pancreatic buds
Formation of only one pancreatic bud

questions.solution:
Option B: Failure of fusion of dorsal & ventral panreatic buds

  • Pancreas divisum is the most common congenital disability of the pancreas. 

  • It develops prenatally. The cause is unknown.

  • However, there is the failure of fusion of dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds during embryological development at the eighth week of intrauterine life.
  • Asymptomatic pancreas divisum does not require treatment.
  • The mainstay of treatment is endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with minor papilla sphincterotomy.

 

 

 

Option A: Duplication of Pancreas

  • It's not an untrue statement, according to the question asked above. A person cannot have a double pancreas.

Option C: Formation of more than two pancreatic buds

  • Pancreatic divisum is due to the failure of fusion of dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds during embryological development at the eighth week of intrauterine life. So, it's a false statement.

Option D: Formation of only one pancreatic bud

  • It's not a true statement according to the question regarding pancreatic divisum.

questions.text: A primigravida at 40 weeks of gestation presents with labour pains for half an hour. During a spontaneous vaginal delivery complicated by obstructed labour, an episiotomy is performed, and forceps are used. Examination reveals a second-degree tear involving a crack in the upper boundary of the superficial perineal space. Which structure is likely damaged?
questions.solution:
Option D: Perineal membrane

  • The perineum is damaged during childbirth, as shown in the woman in the clinical scenario above.
  • Risk factors include primigravida, obstructed labour, forceps delivery and episiotomy.
  • The main structure to be torn is the perineal body that supports the pelvic floor and is attached to the perineal membrane. It is the central point of the perineum.
  • The perineum is the lower part of the pelvic cavity. It is bounded anteriorly by the symphysis pubis, posteriorly by the tip of the coccyx and laterally by the ischial tuberosities.
  • The urogenital diaphragm is a triangular musculofascial diaphragm situated in the anterior part of the perineum. It fills in the gap of the pubic arch.
    • It is formed by the sphincter urethrae and the deep, transverse perineal muscles, which are enclosed between the superior and an inferior layer of the fascia of the urogenital diaphragm.
    • The inferior layer of the fascia is referred to as the perineal membrane.
  • The perineal membrane is perforated by the urethra in both sexes and the vagina in the females.
  • The perineal body and the ischial pubic ramus to which it attaches to provide a foundation for the erectile bodies of the external genitalia, the penis in males and the vulva in females, which are the superior superficial features of the triangle.
  • It divides the urogenital diaphragm into superficial and deep perineal pouches.
  • The perineal membrane forms the upper boundary of the superficial perineal space.

 

  • The diagram below demonstrates the perineum and the pelvic floor muscle. It shows the structure of the perineal membrane and its relations and attachments.

 

Option A: Pelvic diaphragm

  • The pelvic diaphragm is a basin-shaped muscular tissue that forms the inferior border of the abdominopelvic cavity. It isolates the pelvic cavity from the perineum and supports the abdominopelvic viscera.
  • The pelvic diaphragm has three components: levator ani muscles, coccygeus muscle, and fascia surrounding these muscles.
  • It extends from the symphysis pubis to the coccyx and from one lateral wall side to another.

Option B: Colles’ fascia

  • The abdominal fascia is continuous with the perineal fascia.
  • The perineal fascia is divided into two components: the deep fascia and the superficial fascia.
  • The superficial fascia is composed of two layers: superficial and deep layer.
    • The deep layer is known as the Colles’ fascia.
  • The deep membranous layer (Colles fascia) is attached posteriorly to the posterior border of the urogenital diaphragm, laterally to the margins of the public arch, and anteriorly, it is continuous with the membranous layer of the anterior abdominal wall (Scarpa’s fascia).

Option C: Superficial perineal fascia

  • The superficial perineal fascia has two layers: a superficial fatty layer and a deep membranous layer.
    • The superficial fatty layer (basics of Camper) extends to labia majora in females. In males, it is replaced by the dartos muscle in the scrotum. It is continuous with the fat of the ischiorectal fossa and the superficial fascia of the thighs.
    • The deep membranous layer (Colles’ fascia)

questions.text: Which of the following structures forms the posterior boundary of the carotid triangle?
questions.solution:
Option D: Sternocleidomastoid

  • The neck is divided into anterior and posterior triangles by the Sternocleidomastoid muscle. The anterior triangle is further divided into four triangles.
  1. Carotid Triangle
  2. Submental Triangle
  3. Submandibular Triangle
  4. The muscular triangle is also known as the infrahyoid triangle

Boundaries of Carotid Triangle:

  • Superior: Stylohyoid and posterior belly of digastric
  • Anterior: Superior belly of omohyoid
  • Posterior: Anterior margin of sternocleidomastoid muscle

Contents of Carotid Triangle:

  • The common carotid artery divides into internal and external carotid arteries within the carotid triangle
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Hypoglossal Nerve
  • Vagus nerve 
  • Carotid Sinus    

Its floor is formed by

  • Hyoglossus
  • Thyrohyoid membrane
  • Medial and inferior constrictor muscles.

 

Option A: Superior belly of the omohyoid

  • The superior belly of the omohyoid forms the anterior border of the carotid triangle.

Option B: Posterior belly of digastric

  • The posterior belly of the digastric forms the superior border of the carotid triangle.
  • The posterior belly of the digastric is attached to the hyoid bone & mastoid process.

Option C: Mylohyoid Muscle

  • The Mylohyoid muscle is not a part of the carotid triangle
  • It extends between the mandible and hyoid bone and is present on the floor of the Digastric Triangle.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presented with involuntary rhythmic movements of her hands for the past 3 months, worse at rest and affecting both hands, with a history of chronic liver disease, hypertension, and peripheral artery disease. What is the most likely diagnosis based on examination findings and the structure involved in the patient's pathology, as shown in the provided image?
questions.solution:
Options C: Paralysis agitans

  1. This is a paralysis agitans, also known as Parkinson's disease.
  2. The marked structure is the substantia nigra of the brain (dark due to neuro melanin) (in the mid-brain).
  3. Produce dopamine
  4. Lesion + → dopamine decreases → resulting in Parkinson's disease/paralysis agitans.
  5. A neurodegenerative disorder that affects predominately the dopamine-producing ("dopaminergic") neurons in a specific area of the brain called the substantia nigra.

Symptoms:

  • Symptoms generally develop slowly over the years. The progression of symptoms is often a bit different from one person to another due to the diversity of the disease. People with Parkinson's disease may experience:
  • The tremor, mainly at rest and described as pill rolling tremor in hands; other forms of tremor are possible
  • Slowness and paucity of movement (called bradykinesia and hypokinesia)
  • Limb stiffness (rigidity)
  • Gait and balance problems (postural instability)

Options A: Dementia

  • The most common cause of dementia is Alzheimer's disease.
  • Although Parkinson's disease can also cause dementia, it has other causes also, such as brain injury, infections etc

Options B: Alzheimer

  • It is a neurodegenerative disorder that is slow and progressive.
  • The most common cause of dementia is Alzheimer's disease.
  • Caused by neurofibrillary tangles and A-beta plaques in the hippocampus.

Options D: Chorea

 

  • Chorea is a purposeless involuntary movement, which may occur due to involvement of basal ganglia structures like Caudate nucleus.

questions.text: For a 2-week-old girl with a mass on her lower back since birth, born full-term without prenatal care. On examination, a non-tender mass, covered by skin, is present on the lower back above the gluteal crease. What course of treatment is recommended after a detailed workup?
questions.solution:
Option B: Surgical removal by age 6 months

  • Sacrococcygeal tumors are teratomas (a type of germ cell tumors) on the lower back at the coccyx level.

 

 

  • Aberrant migration of primordial germ cells (PGCs) from the yolk sac to the genital ridge leads to sacrococcygeal teratoma.
  • These are the most common congenital germ cell tumors and are more common in females than males.
  • Sacrococcygeal teratomas are usually diagnosed prenatally on routine ultrasound exams. However, as the woman in the above case did not receive prenatal care, she missed the tumor diagnosis.
  • In neonates, these teratomas present as a benign mass in the lower back, and no other defects are usually noted.
  • In neonates, the management of sacrococcygeal teratomas comprises surgical excision of the lesion because if the tumors are not excised timely, the risk of malignant transformation, ulceration, and hemorrhage increases.
  • So, the most appropriate treatment is surgical tumor resection by 6 months.

Option A: Immediate chemotherapy and radiation treatment

  • As most sacrococcygeal tumors are benign at the beginning of the fetus's life, it would be inappropriate to start immediate chemotherapy and radiation treatment. Moreover, these treatments have not proven useful in treating teratomas and negatively affect newborns.

Option C: Surgical removal at age 4–5 years

  • Sacrococcygeal teratomas are prenatal tumors, and the size of the tumors is large. Late treatment at the age of 4-5 is not appropriate as complications of the tumor can bother the child by this age, and the risk of the tumor becoming malignant is high if this age delays the treatment.

Option D: Surgical removal at age 13–15 years

  • By the age of 13-15, the risk of malignancy will be high. By this time, complications will arise, such as ureteric obstructions, GI obstructions, anemia, rupture of the tumor, compression of nerves leading to incontinence, and heart failure. So, the most appropriate time would be as early as possible, 6 months.

questions.text: A 27-year-old rugby player sustained a fracture to the right tibia after a collision injury. After his lower leg had been in a cast for 8 weeks, he found that the right gastrocnemius muscle was significantly smaller in circumference than it was before the fracture. This is due to:

choices.text: Decrease in the number of individual muscle fibers in the muscle.
Decrease in blood flow to the muscle caused by constriction from the cast.
Temporary reduction in actin and myosin protein synthesis.

questions.solution:
Option C: Temporary reduction in actin and myosin protein synthesis

Disuse atrophy:

  • The skeletal muscle continuously remodels in response to the level of its use.
  • For an extensive time, and the muscle is inactive, the rate of synthesis of the contractile proteins in individual muscle fibers decreases, which results in an overall reduction in muscle mass.
  • When a muscle remains unused for many weeks, the rate of degradation of the contractile proteins is more rapid than the replacement rate. Therefore, muscle atrophy occurs.
  • The pathway that appears to account for much of the protein degradation in a muscle undergoing atrophy is the ATP-dependent ubiquitin-proteosome pathway. Proteosomes are large protein complexes that degrade damaged or unneeded proteins by proteolysis, a chemical reaction that breaks peptide bonds.
  • Ubiquitin is a regulatory protein that labels which cells will be targeted for proteasomal degradation.

Option A: Decrease the number of individual muscle fibers in the muscle

  • A decrease in blood flow caused by constriction from a cast will result in signs of ischemia well before 8 weeks, e.g., pain, change in color to pale, skin changes, etc.
  • When a muscle loses its nerve supply, it no longer receives the contractile signals required to maintain normal muscle size.

Option B: Decrease in blood flow to the muscle caused by constriction from the cast

  • If a muscle is inactive for an extended time, the rate of synthesis of the contractile proteins in individual muscle fibers decreases, which results in an overall reduction in muscle mass.

Option D: Progressive denervation

  • Denervation is any loss of nerve supply regardless of the cause.
  • When a muscle loses its nerve supply, it no longer receives the contractile signals required to maintain normal muscle size. Therefore, atrophy begins almost immediately.
  • After about 2 months, degenerative changes also appear in the muscle fibers. If the nerve supply to the muscle grows rapidly, the full function return can occur in as little as 3 months.
  • The denervation atrophy is followed by the destruction of muscle fibers and replacement by fibrous and fatty tissue leading to contractures.
  • However, in this case, his lower leg has been in a cast for 8 weeks, and his right gastrocnemius muscle is significantly smaller in circumference. If it is for an extended time and the muscle is inactive, the rate of synthesis of the contractile proteins in individual muscle fibers decreases, which results in an overall reduction in muscle mass.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was brought to the emergency day after a road traffic accident 20 minutes ago. He has multiple lacerations to his upper extremities and sustained an open fracture to his lower extremity. Initial CBC reveals white blood cells count at 22 x 103 /µl, and subsequent complete blood count analysis after 5 hours reveals the white blood cells count at 7 x 103 /µl. Which of the following is the reason for the increase in white blood cell count on the initial blood report?

choices.text: Increased production of WBCs by the bone marrow
Release of pre-formed, mature WBCs into the circulation

questions.solution:
Option B: Release pre-formed, mature WBCs into the circulation

  • A traumatic physical event can result in the release of WBCs into circulation.
  • The increase in the given case may not be due to any inflammatory response, but instead, the increase is due to mechanical trauma and associated stress responses.
  • Stress causes an overproduction of white blood cells, which defend the body against diseases but can cause problems when produced in excess.
  • These extra cells can stick to artery walls, causing restrictions in blood flow and aiding the formation of clots that can cause blood-vessel blockages throughout the body.
  • When stimulation, like an increased level of cytokines, these stored WBCs are released into circulation.
  • But still, a physically traumatic event can result in the release of WBCs into circulation.

Option A: Increased production of WBCs by the bone marrow

  • Increased production of WBCs by the bone marrow defends your body against infections and disease. But, when too many white blood cells, it usually means you have an infection or inflammation in your body. Less commonly, a high white blood cell count could indicate certain blood cancers or bone marrow disorders.

Option C: Decreased destruction of WBCs

  • Decreased destruction of WBCs is usually caused by: Viral infections that temporarily disrupt the work of bone marrow.

Option D: Increased production of selectins

  • The selectins are physiologically important in inflammation, lymphocyte homing, immunological responses, and homing of bone marrow stem cells. They play a role in atherosclerosis, ischemia-reperfusion injury, inflammatory diseases, and the metastatic spreading of some cancers.

questions.text: During which phase of the cardiac cycle is the second heart sound (S2) generated?
questions.solution:
Option A: Protodiastole

  • As the ventricular diastole starts, ventricular pressure begins to fall.
  • Blood ejected out during systole starts flowing back toward the ventricles due to the falling ventricular pressure.
  • This sudden change in the direction of blood marks the phase of protodiastole.
  • The closure of semilunar valves stops this regurgitation of blood toward the ventricles. This closure of semilunar valves produces (option-1) S2.
  • Thus, S2 indicates the end of the protodiastole; S2 is said to occur in protodiastole. After S2, the isovolumic relaxation starts.

 

Sound   Associated Events
S1 First heart sound (sounds like lub) Closure of mitral and tricuspid valves
  Two bursts, a mitral M1 and a tricuspid T1 component  
S2

Second heart sound (sounds like dub)

An aortic A2 and a pulmonary P2 component

 Closure of aortic and pulmonary valves
OS Opening snap Opening of a stenotic mitral valve
S3 Third heat sound Diastolic filling gallop or ventricular or protodiastolic gallop
S4 Fourth heart sound The atrial sound that creates an atrial or presystolic gallop

 

Option B: Isovolumetric relaxation

  • When the ventricular pressure reduces significantly at the end of phase 4, the aortic and pulmonic valves close, causing the second heart sound (S2) and the beginning of the isovolumetric relaxation.
  • Valve closure is associated with the small backflow of blood into the ventricles and a characteristic notch in the aortic and pulmonary artery pressure tracings.

Option C: First rapid filling

  • When the ventricles continue to relax at the end of phase 5, the ventricular pressure will reduce their respective atrial pressure.
  • The AV valves rapidly open when this occurs, and passive ventricular filling begins.
  • Despite the blood coming from the atria, intraventricular pressure reduces because the ventricles are still relaxed.

Option D: Diastasis:

  • It is the middle stage of diastole during the cardiac cycle, where the initial passive filling of the ventricles has slowed, but before the atria contract to complete the active filling.

questions.text: N2 washout (or Fowler's method) - A subject takes a breath of 100% O2 and exhales through a one-way valve measuring nitrogen content and volume. A plot of the N2 concentration (as a % of total gas) vs expired volume is obtained by increasing the N2 concentration from zero to the percentage of N2 in the alveoli. Fowler's method is employed for the measurement of which of the following parameter?
questions.solution:
Option C: Anatomic dead space

  • Anatomic dead space refers to the air volume in the respiratory tract segments responsible for conducting air to the alveoli and respiratory bronchioles. Still, it does not take part in the gas exchange process itself.
  • Based on the single-breath nitrogen analysis technique.
  • A person is given 100% oxygen in single breaths, and that breath enters alveoli
  • Now the person starts exhaling. The first air that comes out has never reached the alveoli. It comes out of dead space only from the anatomic dead space.
  • The first part of exhaled air is the last part of inhaled air. So, when the person starts exhaling, he exhales the last part of inhaled air, which is air in anatomic dead space.
  • This first exhaled air is analyzed, & this air will contain only O2. This is Fowler's method.
  • Used to measure functional residual capacity

Option A: Residual volume

  • A gas dilution test measures residual volume. A person breathes from a container containing a documented amount of a gas (either 100% oxygen or a certain amount of helium in the air). The test measures how the concentration of the gases in the container changes. A person breathes from a container containing a documented amount of a gas (either 100% oxygen or a certain amount of helium in the air). The test measures how the concentration of the gases in the container changes.
  • Helium dilution method
  • Nitrogen washout method.

Option B: Alveolar PO2

  • The alveolar gas equation calculates alveolar oxygen partial pressure: PAO2 = (Patm - PH2O) FiO2 - PACO2 / RQ.

Option D: Physiologic dead space

  • The Bohr method uses a tracer gas such as carbon dioxide or nitrogen to determine dead airway space.
  • It is based on the assumption that the inspired concentration of the tracer gas is constant throughout the inspiration
  • Using a tracer gas such as carbon dioxide or nitrogen. It is based on the assumption that the inspired concentration of the tracer gas is constant throughout the inspiration

questions.text: A professor teaches first-year medical students about glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and the properties of a substance used to measure GFR. In addition to the requirement that it be freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted in the tubules, a substance suitable for measuring the GFR should be non-toxic and not metabolized by the body. Which of the following will most likely decrease GFR by more than 10% in a normal kidney?

choices.text: Decrease in renal arterial pressure from 100 to 85 mm Hg
50% increase in the glomerular capillary filtration coefficient

questions.solution:
Option C: 50% decrease in efferent arteriolar resistance

  • 50% reduction in efferent arteriolar resistance would cause a large decrease of GFR-greater than 10%.

Glomerular Filtration Rate

  • Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is defined as the total quantity of filtrate formed in all the nephrons of both kidneys in a given unit of time. Normal GFR is 125 mL/minute or about 180 L/day.
  • The Ideal substance to measure GFR is Inulin for the following reasons:
    • It is non-toxic.
    • It is freely filterable by the glomeruli; it is not bound to proteins.
    • It is neither secreted nor reabsorbed by the tubules.
    • It is not synthesized, stored, or destroyed by the kidney.
  • 50% reduction in efferent arteriolar resistance would cause a large decrease of GFR-greater than 10%.

Option A: Decrease in renal arterial pressure from 100 to 85 mm Hg

  • A decrease in renal artery pressure from 100 to 85 mm Hg would cause only a slight decrease in GFR in a normal, autoregulating kidney.

Option B: 50% decrease in afferent arteriolar resistance

  • A decrease in afferent arteriole resistance would tend to increase GFR.

Option D: 50% increase in the glomerular capillary filtration coefficient

  • 50% increase in the glomerular capillary filtration coefficient would tend to increase GFR.

questions.text: RIA is very sensitive in vitro assay technique used to measure concentrations of substances, usually measuring antigen concentrations (for example, hormone levels in the blood) by use of antibodies. If a radioimmunoassay is properly conducted and the amount of radioactive hormone bound to the antibody is low, what would this result indicate?

choices.text: Plasma levels of endogenous hormone are high
Plasma levels of endogenous hormone are low

questions.solution:
• In a radioimmunoassay, there is too little antibody to completely bind the radioactively tagged hormone and the hormone in the fluid (plasma) to be assayed.
  • Thus, there is a competition between the labeled and endogenous hormones for binding sites on the antibody. Consequently, if the amount of radioactive hormone bound to the antibody is low, this finding would indicate that plasma levels of the endogenous hormone are high.

questions.text: Which of the following cell types is mainly responsible for preventing the drug from reaching the CNS?
questions.solution:
Option B: Endothelial cells

  • The blood-brain barrier prevents circulating blood substances like bacteria and drugs from reaching the CSF or CNS. Three structures form it: tight junctions between nonfenestrated capillary endothelial cells, basement membrane, and astrocyte foot processes. Glucose and amino acids cross slowly by carrier-mediated transport mechanisms. Non-polar substances cross rapidly via diffusion.
  • The blood-brain barrier protects the brain's chemical environment from rapid changes in composition normally occurring in the rest of the body fluids.
  • The cause of the low permeability of these barriers is how the endothelial cells of the capillaries are joined to one another. The adjacent membranes of endothelial cells are tightly fused rather than having extensive slit pores between them, as is seen in most other body capillaries. These barriers often make it impossible to achieve effective concentrations of therapeutic drugs, such as protein antibodies and non-lipid soluble compounds in the CSF or parenchyma of the brain.
  • In some specialized areas of the brain, like the hypothalamus, pineal gland, and area postrema, substances diffuse easily into the tissue spaces. It is important because they have sensory receptors that respond to specific changes in the body fluids, such as changes in osmolality and glucose concentration, as well as receptors for peptide hormones that regulate thirst as angiotensin II.

Option A: Astrocyte

  • They are the most common glial cell types in CNS. Their functions include physical support, repair of extracellular K+ buffer, and removal of excess neurotransmitters.
  • They are an important component of the blood-brain barrier derived from neuroectoderm.

Option C: Glial cell

  • Glial cells differ from neurons in that they are small and have only one kind of process. They do not form chemical synapses and are the supporting cells of the CNS.
  • They readily divide and proliferate.
  • Glioma is a common type of primary tumor of the CNS.
  • These cells include astrocytes, microglia, oligodendrocytes, and Schwann cells.

Option D: Macrophage

  • Macrophages are specialized cells involved in detecting, phagocytosis, and destroying bacteria and other harmful organisms. They present antigens to T cells and initiate inflammation by releasing cytokines that activate other cells.
  • Macrophages originate from blood monocytes that leave the circulation to differentiate in different tissues.

questions.text: Which system has the best degree of temporal and spatial fidelity in transmitting somatosensory information?
questions.solution:
Option B: Dorsal column–medial lemniscal system

  • The dorsal roots of spinal nerves are the entry points for almost all sensory data from the somatic parts of the body. The sensory impulses go by one of two additional sensory routes, the dorsal column-medial lemniscal system or the anterolateral system, from the place of entrance into the cord and subsequently to the brain. The thalamus is the level where these two systems partially converge.
  • As its name suggests, the dorsal column-medial lemniscal system primarily sends impulses through the spinal cord's dorsal columns upward to the brain's medulla. The impulses then proceed upward through the brain stem and the medial lemniscus to the thalamus after synapsing and crossing to the opposing side in the medulla.
  • Large, myelinated nerve fibres part of the dorsal column-medial lemniscal system convey signals to the brain at speeds between 30 and 110 m/sec.
  • Because the nerve fibres of the dorsal column and medial lemniscal system are highly spatially oriented at their points of origin, they can transfer sensory data quickly and accurately in both time (temporal) and space (spatial).

Option A: Anterolateral system

  • After entering the spinal cord from the dorsal spinal nerve roots, signals in the anterolateral system synapse in the dorsal horns of the spinal grey matter, cross to the opposing side of the cord and ascend through the anterior and lateral white columns of the cord. They end at the thalamus and all lower brain stem levels.
  • In contrast to the dorsal column medial lemniscus system, the anterolateral system has substantially less spatial orientation and transmits sensations that do not need a fast or precise spatial transmission.
  • In contrast to the dorsal system, the anterolateral system can transmit a wide range of sensory modalities, including pain, warmth, cold, and basic tactile sensations. Only a few types of mechanoreceptive sensations are available to the dorsal system.

Option C: Corticospinal system

  • The corticospinal tract, also known as the pyramidal tract, is an output tract that relays information from the motor cortex to the spinal cord.
  • It does not transmit somatosensory information.
  • When it exits the cortex, it travels via the posterior limb of the internal capsule (between the caudate nucleus and the putamen of the basal ganglia) before descending into the brain stem and creating the pyramids of the medulla.
  • The majority of the pyramidal fibres then cross in the lower medulla to the opposing side and descend into the lateral corticospinal tracts of the cord, ultimately terminating mostly on interneurons in the intermediate regions of the grey matter of the cord; a few terminate on sensory relay neurons in the dorsal horn, and a very small number terminate directly on the anterior motor neurons that are responsible for muscle contraction.

Option D: Spinocerebellar system

  • Important sensory impulses are also directly sent to the cerebellum from the body's periphery by four routes, two of which are dorsal in the cord and two of which are ventral, two on each side.
  • Dorsal and ventral spinocerebellar tracts are the two most significant of these tracts.
  • The inferior cerebellar peduncle is the entrance point for the dorsal tract, which exits in the vermis and intermediate zones of the cerebellum on the opposite side of its origin.
  • The ventral tract enters the cerebellum but exits on both sides of the structure through the superior cerebellar peduncle.
  • Muscle spindles are the primary source of the signals that go via the dorsal spinocerebellar tracts, with smaller contributions coming from Golgi tendon organs, big tactile receptors on the skin, and joint receptors.
  • The peripheral receptors provide substantially less information to the ventral spinocerebellar pathways. Instead, they are primarily stimulated by motor impulses that enter the anterior horns of the spinal cord via (2) internal motor pattern generators inside the cord and (3) the brain through the corticospinal and rubrospinal tracts.

questions.text: Through which of the following layers does the light enter the retina?
questions.solution:
Option D: Retinal ganglion layer

  • Layers of the retina from inside to outside are:
    • Pigmented layer
    • The layer of rods and cones projecting to the pigment
    • Outer nuclear layer
    • Outer plexiform layer
    • Inner nuclear layer
    • Inner plexiform layer
    • Ganglionic layer
    • The layer of optic nerve fibers
    • Inner limiting membrane
  • The light from the lens, cornea, and vitreous humor enters the retina from inside the eye.
  • Light passes first from the ganglion cell layer, then through plexiform and nuclear layers, before reaching the layer of rods and cones.

Option A: Outer nuclear layer

  • Light strikes the retina on the retinal ganglion layer first.
  • The outer nuclear layer is not the first layer for the light to pass into the eye.

Option B: Inner nuclear layer

  • The inner nuclear layer is next to the inner plexiform layer.
  • Light enters the ganglionic cell layer and the inner plexiform layer to reach the inner nuclear layer.

Option C: Outer plexiform layer

  • The outer plexiform layer is not the first layer at which light strikes the retina.
  • It is far from the ganglionic cell layer, the first layer on which light rays strike in the retina.

questions.text: A neuron, the functional unit of the nervous system, is responsible for initiating and propagating nerve impulses. The axon's initial segment, just between the peak of the axon hillock and the initial (unmyelinated) segment, is also known as the trigger zone for the action potential. Which following is responsible for initiating a nerve impulse at the axon's initial segment?

choices.text: It has a lower threshold than the rest of the axon

questions.solution:
Option A: It has a lower threshold than the rest of the axon.

  • A neuron is the functional unit of the nervous system, and it initiates and propagates action potential to communicate with different body segments. A neuron has two main components; an axon and a cell body (soma).
  • The Axon hillock is the initial segment of the axon. Nerve impulses begin in this initial axon segment and not on the somal membrane adjacent to the excitatory synapses.
  • The primary reason for this is that the membrane at the axon hillock has several times greater concentrations of voltage-gated sodium channels. Therefore, the threshold for excitation at this site is lower than at the rest of the neuron.
  • It means that a relatively lower number of positively charged ions entering the cell at this point will lead to the initiation of a strong impulse.
  • In motor neurons, the initial segment is the portion of the cell with the lowest threshold for producing an action potential.

Option B: It is unmyelinated.

  • Initiation of nerve impulse occurs at the initial segment because it has a lower threshold due to the abundance of voltage-gated sodium channels.
  • In myelinated neurons, the axon is covered by the myelin sheath that acts as an insulator. Along the axon's length, unmyelinated points are present between these myelin sheaths, known as the nodes of Ranvier. Nerve impulse propagates by jumping from one node of Ranvier to the next. This helps to increase the speed of nerve impulse conduction, and these impulses are known as saltatory impulses.

Option C: Neurotransmitter release occurs here

  • The arrival of the nerve impulse at the presynaptic terminal releases calcium ions into the presynaptic terminal. These calcium ions are responsible for the fusion of neurotransmitter vesicles with the presynaptic membrane causing the release of neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft. The binding of the neurotransmitter to receptors on the postsynaptic membrane stimulates the regeneration of the action potential in the postsynaptic neuron at the axon's initial segment.
  • Common neurotransmitters include acetylcholine, serotonin, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine.

Option D: None of the above.

  • Nerve impulse propagation starts at the trigger zone (initial axon segment) due to its lower threshold than the rest of the neuron.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for producing  dicrotic notch on the arterial pulse waveform?
questions.solution:
Option B: Closure of the aortic valve

  • Incisura is the notch seen in arterial pulse tracing due to the closure of the aortic valve.
  • More peripheral arterial pulsations exhibit an analogous notch called the "dicrotic notch."
  • At the end of ventricular systole, there is a sudden change in the direction of blood (protodiastole), followed by the closure of the aortic valve.
  • These events are responsible for the notch, a sudden alteration in arterial tracing. It is followed by a slowly declining pressure wave, indicating ventricular diastole.
  • In normal patients with congenital aortic stenosis, the incisura ranged between 6 and 14 mm Hg.
  • In a normal person with aortic regurgitation, the incisura finishes as the regurgitation severity increases.
  • The incisura is smaller or absent in normal patients with calcific aortic stenosis.

Option A: First heart sound

  • It is produced due to the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valve.

Option C: Isovolumetric relaxation

  • It is the phase of ventricular filling.
  • In this phase, aortic and pulmonary valves remained closed.

Option D: Third heart sound

  • It is the protodiastolic gallop or also named diastolic filing gallop.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the different reflexes involved in the physiology of the respiratory system. He finds that in a newborn, the inflation of the lungs sends a signal to the respiratory centre in the medulla that causes further distention of the lung. This reflex is seen most often on the first day and may act as a way to establish and maintain a functional residual capacity. Which of the following reflex is being observed by the investigator?
questions.solution:
Option D:  Head’s paradoxical reflex

  • The Head's paradoxical reflex is mediated by rapidly adapting pulmonary stretch receptors.
  • It is a positive feedback reflex.
  • During the inspiratory phase, distension of the lungs leads to the transmission of signals to the respiratory group of neurons in the medulla via the vagus nerve. The feedback response then further allows for the distension of the lungs.
  • It plays an essential role in the expansion of the lungs during the first breath of a newborn.
  • It is paradoxical to the Hering-Breuer inflation reflex.

Option A: Hering-Breuer inflation reflex

  • Hering-Breuer reflex prevents over-extension of the lungs during inspiration.
  • When the lungs become over-stretched, the stretch receptors in the walls of the bronchi and bronchioles walls send signals to the dorsal respiratory group of neurons in the medulla through the vagus nerve, switching off the inspiratory ramp and stopping inspiration. This is called Hering-Breuer reflex.
  • This reflex also increases the rate of inspiration.
  • This reflex is only active at high tidal volumes.

Option B: Hering-Breuer deflation reflex

  • Hering-Breuer deflation reflex shortens the exhalation phase when the lung is deflated.
  • Stretch receptors send signals to the dorsal group of neurons of the respiratory centre in the medulla via the vagus nerve.
  • The respiratory center in the brain then stops expiration to prevent excessive deflation of the lungs. This is called the Hering-Breuer deflation reflex.

Option C:  J-reflex

  • The reflex characterized by apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension is called J-reflex.
  • J-reflex is mediated by J receptors located in the alveolar walls.
  • J-reflex is functional in events of pulmonary oedema, pulmonary emboli, congestive heart failure, and barotrauma.
  • J-reflex is due to a decrease in oxygenation and thus leads to increased breathing.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy experienced episodes of generalized skin rash, particularly in sun-exposed areas, and resolution within a week to 10 days. The pediatrician prescribed niacin and a high-protein diet, resulting in the rash resolving within a day or two during subsequent occurrences. What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Hartnup’s disease (also known as "pellagra-like dermatosis" or "Hartnup disorder") is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder affecting the absorption & reabsorption of nonpolar amino acids (particularly tryptophan). Tryptophan is used to synthesize serotonin, melatonin, and niacin. The deficiency of niacin leads to pellagra.
  • Cystinuria is a different transport defect, which affects dibasic amino acid transporter.
  • Ornithine translocase deficiency, also called hyperornithinemia-hyperammonemia-homocitrullinuria (HHH) syndrome, is a rare autosomal recessive, urea cycle transporter defect, which causes ammonia to accumulate in the blood.
  • Alkaptonuria is due to a defect in homogentisic acid oxidase.

questions.text: An obese young woman accidentally ingests a banned drug and develops a high-grade fever. It was once known to be used for weight reduction. The drug is known to affect ATP formation in the Electron Transport Chain. What could be that drug?
questions.solution:
Option C: 2, 4 dinitrophenol

  • The drug 2,4 dinitrophenol is an ionophore.
  • Ionophore allows proton to pass through & dissipates the electrochemical gradient generated by proton pumps.
  • Because it is a chemical ionophore, 2,4 DNP inhibits the last stage of the energy conversion process that is Uncouples the oxidation from phosphorylation. i.e. Oxidation continues without phosphorylation.
  • Because of this change potential energy of protons is lost in the form of heat rather than being converted to ATP which in turn results in increase in body temperature (hyperthermia) seen in this patient.

Option A: Barbiturate

  • Barbiturates such as amobarbital inhibit the electron transport from Complex I to Coenzyme Q.
  • So, they inhibit both oxidation and phosphorylation.
  • Barbiturate poisoning leads to hypothermia, not fever

Option B: Malonate

  • Malonate does not decouple oxidative phosphorylation.
  • It inhibits Electron Transport Chain Complex II.
  • It is an inhibitor of the TCA cycle (a competitive inhibitor of enzyme succinate dehydrogenase).

Option D: Rotenone

  • It does not decouple oxidative phosphorylation but inhibits it by inhibiting complex I.
  • Rotenone is produced naturally in the stem and seeds of certain plants.
  • It is a fish poison and is used for catching fish. It is not an over-the-counter drug.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with recurrent hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, growth retardation, and polyuria is found to have elevated glycogen levels in the liver and kidney. Further investigation reveals a mutation in the GLUT-2 transporter. Which of the following diseases is most likely associated with this GLUT-2 mutation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Fanconi-Bickel syndrome

  • Autosomal recessive condition caused due to allelic variants of GLUT-2 arisen due to mutations.
  • C/F
    • Resembles type I GSD (von Gierke’s disease) - Glycogen deposited in liver and kidney
    • Fasting hypoglycemia but postprandial hyperglycemia
    • Patients are usually dwarf, with rickets, aminoaciduria, phosphaturia, glucosuria, Proximal tubulopathy and hypercalciuria

Option A: Menke's disease

  • It is a condition of copper deficiency due to mutation in intestinal Cu transporter ATP7A
  • Cu stays in intestinal cells, unable to enter the blood, causing ↓ plasma Cu
  • It is characterized by:
    • Kinky hair
    • Greying of hair
    • Growth Retardation

Option C: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome

  • It is characterized by hemihypertrophy; one side of the body is significantly larger than the other.
  • Midface hypoplasia, macroglossia, omphalocele, and macrosomia may also present.

Option D: Dandy-Walker syndrome

  • It is a rare disorder affecting brain where cerebellum and fourth ventricle is mainly affected.
  • It is usually caused by chromosomal genetic condition causing impaired cell migration and division affecting development of the cerebellar vermis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented to the hospital complaining of intractable vomiting and inability to eat or drink for the past 3 days. His blood analysis still shows a normal glucose level. Which of the following processes is mainly responsible for the blood glucose maintenance in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Liver gluconeogenesis

  • The patient is in starvation, given that he has not taken any food for the past 3 days.
  • During short-term fasting, the liver produces and releases glucose mainly through glycogenolysis. However, during prolonged fasting, glycogen is depleted, and hepatocytes synthesize glucose through gluconeogenesis using lactate, pyruvate Pyruvate, glycerol, and amino acids.
  • Glucagon released during starvation will cause the activation of gluconeogenic enzymes in the liver, which will maintain the blood glucose needed for the functioning of vital organs such as the brain, heart, and RBCs. Therefore, the answer is liver gluconeogenesis.
  • The Fed state is mainly related to glycogen metabolism, while the fasted state shows a gluconeogenesis process from gluconeogenic substrates.
  • The figure below shows the role of the liver in the fed and fasting state under hormonal control.

Option B: Dietary Glucose

  • Dietary glucose can provide blood glucose up to 2 hours after feeding. The extra glucose consumed in food gets deposited in the liver and muscles as glycogen and fats in adipose tissues.

Option C: Muscle glycogenolysis

  • The glycogenolysis inside the muscles gives glucose-6-phosphate as an end-product, not D-Glucose, due to the absence of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase in muscles. Hence, muscle glycogen cannot contribute to blood glucose directly.

Option D: Liver glycogenolysis

  • Glycogen breakdown in the liver can maintain blood glucose for 12-18 hours. After that period, liver gluconeogenesis is the primary source of blood glucose during fasting/starvation.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child is brought to the emergency room by his parents with rapid breathing. He was cold, clammy, confused, and lethargic. His mother gave a history of accidental ingestion of automobile antifreeze. Ethanol is used as a treatment for this poisoning because:

choices.text: Inhibit binding of ethylene glycol to alcohol dehydrogenase
Stimulate the excretion of ethylene glycol

questions.solution:
Option C: Inhibit binding of ethylene glycol to alcohol dehydrogenase

  • As the metabolism of ethylene glycol is similar to ethanol and uses the same alcohol dehydrogenase, so for the treatment, ethanol is used as an antidote for ethylene glycol poisoning. Ethanol has low Km for alcohol dehydrogenase; thus, it inhibits the binding of ethylene glycol with the enzyme by competitive inhibition, causing the slowing down of glycolic acid production.

  • It can be administered as intravenous ethanol and is quite effective.
  • Patients treated with ethanol can suffer hypoglycemia, hepatotoxicity, and CNS depression, so close monitoring is required.
  • Hemodialysis may be required along with IV ethanol.
  • Fomepizole can also be used to treat ethylene glycol poisoning, depending on the availability of both ethanol and fomepizole.
  • The most common source of ethylene glycol is automotive antifreeze or radiator coolant, where concentrations are high. Other sources of ethylene glycol include windshield deicing agents, brake fluid, motor oil, developing solutions for hobby photographers, wood stains, solvents, and paints.

Option A: It conjugates with ethylene glycol

  • This statement is false because ethanol does not bind with ethylene glycol; instead, they both compete for alcohol dehydrogenase.

Option B: Inhibit enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase

  • This statement is false because ethanol does not inhibit the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase but uses it for further metabolism.

Option D: Stimulate the excretion of ethylene glycol

  • This statement is false because ethanol does not stimulate the excretion of ethylene glycol; it only binds with alcohol dehydrogenase and prevents the metabolism of ethylene glycol.

questions.text: A 20-month-old male infant presented with developmental delay, seizures, and eczema. His urine has a characteristic tom cat urine smell, and blood analysis indicated organic acidemia. The patient is advised to take biotin supplementation to treat which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Multiple carboxylase/biotinidase deficiency

  • Autosomal recessive disorder due to a defect in holocarboxylase synthase or biotinidase deficiency.
  • These are required to generate the active form of biotin required for carboxylation reactions (see fig).

Clinical features:-

  • Metabolic ketoacidosis
  • Diffuse rash
  • Alopecia
  • Seizures
  • Intellectual disability

Option B: Keto acid dehydrogenase deficiency

  • TPP (Thiamine pyrophosphate), not biotin, is the coenzyme for branch-chain dehydrogenase, the enzyme that catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of α-keto acids derived from leucine, isoleucine, and valine, three essential amino acids.

Option C: Transketolase deficiency

  • TPP (Thiamine pyrophosphate), not biotin, is the coenzyme of transketolase.

Option D: Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency

  • TPP (Thiamine pyrophosphate), not biotin, is the coenzyme of Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency.

questions.text: A 23-year-old tall male has feminine characteristics such as sparse facial hair, small testes, and gynecomastia. He also had poor coordination, language, and reading difficulties. Which of the following test is used to confirm this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Karyotyping

Karyotyping:

  • Study of chromosomes.
  • Best technique for monosomy/trisomy.
  • Chromosomes are stained, ordered, and numbered according to morphology, size, arm-length ratio, and banding pattern.
  • Sample used: Blood, bone marrow, amniotic fluid, placental tissue.
  • Fixative: Carnoy’s fixative (methanol and glacial acetic acid in ratio 3:1).
  • Most common stain: Geimsa/G-banding.
  • Limitations:
    • Can't be done in any phase of the cell cycle.
    • Can't detect amplifications, microdeletions, and complex translocations.
    • Low resolution, i.e., subchromosomal alterations, can't be detected.

Klinefelter’s syndrome (XXY) can be detected by karyotyping. This test will directly observe the presence of an extra X chromosome in his chromosome preparations.

Option A: Ultrasound abdomen

  • Ultrasound is a non-invasive procedure.
  • It is used to visualize structures within the body with help of sound waves.
  • It is not of any use to confirm the diagnosis of an extra X chromosome in Klinefelter's syndrome hence making it a wrong choice.

Option B: Echocardiography

  • It is medical imaging of the heart.
  • Used to assess the functioning of heart chambers and valves.
  • It is not of any help to confirm chromosomal numbering in Klinefelter's syndrome, making it the wrong choice

Option C: Triple test

  • It is performed during pregnancy.
  • It includes the levels of hCG, estriol, and AFP.
  • Estimation of risk of birth defects.
  • Cannot confirm the presence of an extra chromosome, making it the wrong choice for diagnosis of Klinefelter's syndrome

questions.text: What role do small nuclear ribonucleoprotein particles (snRNPs), the complexes formed by RNA and nucleoproteins, play in the process of splicing?

choices.text: Facilitate the looping of the two exons into the correct alignment for splicing
snRNP assembly is affected in spinal muscular atrophy

questions.solution: In Spliceosomal intron splicing snRNA- small nuclear RNA – U1, U2, U4, U5 and U6 are involved. They remove introns by forming base pairs with the consensus sequences at each end of the intron.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a symptom of ammonia intoxication?
questions.solution:
Option A: Slurring of speech

  • Disorders of the urea cycle led to elevated levels of ammonia in the blood. 
  • Severe ammonia toxicity can lead to coma and eventually death
  • One of the earliest symptoms of ammonia intoxication is haziness of vision and slurring of speech
  • Other clinical features of urea cycle defects: -
    • Increased blood glutamine
    • Decreased BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen)
    • Cerebral edema
    • Vomiting
    • Lethargy
    • Hyperventilation

Rifampicin and lactulose may be used in the treatment of hyperammonemia.

Option B: Abdominal pain

  • Abdominal pain is not associated with the disorder of the urea cycle.
  • Abdominal pain may occur due to various infectious and noninfectious causes.
  • It may be due to gastrointestinal, urological, gynecological causes, etc.

Option C: Diarrhea

  • Diarrhea is not associated with the disorder of the urea cycle.
  • Abdominal pain may occur due to various infectious and noninfectious causes
  • Severe diarrhea might lead to dehydration, electrolyte, and acid-base imbalance.

Option D: Constipation

  • Constipation is not associated with the disorder of the urea cycle
  • Constipation may trigger hepatic encephalopathy in chronic liver disease patient
  • Constipation can be caused by medications, irritable bowel syndrome, etc.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male athlete training for a marathon race is advised by his coach to increase his carbohydrate intake after the workout. The carbohydrate uptake will help to build up glycogen stores in the muscles. Glycogen synthase is the main enzyme involved in glycogen synthesis in the muscles. Which of the following acts as an activator of muscle glycogen synthase?
questions.solution:
Option C: Insulin

  • Glycogen synthesis (glycogenesis) in the resting muscle is an anabolic process.
  • Insulin is an anabolic hormone and therefore increases the rate of the anabolic pathways.
  • Insulin increases the activity of muscle glycogen synthase after the intake of carbohydrates & increases glycogen reserves in the liver & muscles.
  • It acts by cAMP-mediated dephosphorylation of glycogen synthase 
  • Simultaneously, it also decreases glycogen phosphorylase activity, thereby decreasing glycogenolysis.

Option A: Epinephrine

  • Epinephrine is a catabolic hormone.
  • It is released in the fasting state.
  • It will decrease glycogen synthesis by inhibiting glycogen synthase.
  • It will increase glycogenolysis.

Option B: Glucagon

  • Glucagon also is a catabolic hormone.
  • It is released mainly in the fasting state to promote glycogenolysis and suppress glycogenesis

Option D: cAMP

  • Phosphorylation of anabolic enzymes such as glycogen synthase and fatty acid synthase is carried out by cAMP.
  • The phosphorylated state of glycogen synthase is inactive, and glycogen formation is suppressed.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male athlete presents to the emergency with a history of chest discomfort. He says that he developed the condition while practicing for his upcoming marathon. The pain is relieved after a few minutes of rest. Which of the following represents the cell injury in this scenario?

choices.text: Detachment of ribosomes from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)

questions.solution:
Option A: Detachment of ribosomes from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)

  • Small transparent vacuoles can be seen inside the cytoplasm of reversibly wounded cells, reflecting swollen and pinched-off regions of the ER. This type of non-fatal injury is sometimes referred to as vacuolar degeneration or hydropic change.

  • Electron microscopy reveals the ultrastructural alterations of reversible cell damage, which consists of the following:

    • Changes in the plasma membrane, such as blebbing, blunting, and loss of polarity.
    • Microvilli
    • Mitochondrial alterations, such as swelling and the development of tiny white spots
    • Accumulation of “myelin figures” in the cytosol composed of phospholipids derived from damaged cellular membranes
    • Dilation of the ER, with the detachment of polysomes.
    • Nuclear alterations, with disaggregation of granular and fibrillar elements

Option B: Breakdown of plasma membrane

  • Significant disruptions in the function of the membrane (breakdown of plasma membrane) are a feature of irreversible cell injury.

  • This is an incorrect option as the scenario is regarding a reversible cell injury

Option C: Karyorrhexis

  • Karyorrhexis refers to a nuclear fragmentation of a dying cell

  • It is a feature of irreversible cell injury.

Option D: Irreversible mitochondrial dysfunction

  • The failure to repair mitochondrial dysfunction (a lack of oxidative phosphorylation and ATP synthesis) even after the resolution of the initial injury is one of the phenomena that typically characterize irreversible cell damage

questions.text: A 43-year-old man complains of a 1-week history of abdominal pain and yellow discolouration of his sclera. Physical examination shows right upper quadrant pain. Laboratory studies show increased serum levels of alkaline phosphatase (520 U/dL) and bilirubin (3.0 mg/dL). A liver biopsy reveals portal fibrosis, with scattered foreign bodies consistent with schistosome eggs. Which of the following inflammatory cells is most commonly to predominate in the portal tracts in the liver of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Eosinophils

  • The history is consistent with the parasitic infection, and eosinophils are the most common cells to respond to parasitic infections

Eosinophils:

  • Eosinophils are white blood cells that play an important role in the body's response to allergic reactions, asthma, and infection with parasites.
  • These cells protect immunity against certain parasites but also contribute to the inflammation that occurs in allergic disorders.
  • Sometimes, eosinophils cause inflammation in certain organs that result in symptoms.
  • Eosinophils usually account for less than 7% of the circulating white blood cells (100 to 500 eosinophils per microliter of blood [0.1 to 0.5 × 109 per litre]).

A low number of eosinophils

  • A low number of eosinophils in the blood (eosinopenia) can occur with Cushing syndrome, bloodstream infections (sepsis), and treatment with corticosteroids.
  • However, low numbers of eosinophils do not usually cause problems because other parts of the immune system compensate adequately.
  • A low number of eosinophils is usually detected by chance when a complete blood count is done for other reasons.
  • Treatment of the cause restores the normal number of eosinophils.

A high number of eosinophils:

  • The most common causes of a high number of eosinophils (called eosinophilia or hypereosinophilia) are:
  • Allergic disorders
  • Infections by parasites
  • Certain cancers
  • Allergic disorders, including drug sensitivities, asthma, allergic rhinitis, and atopic dermatitis, often increase the number of eosinophils. Many parasites, particularly ones that invade tissue, cause eosinophilia.
  • Cancers that cause eosinophilia include Hodgkin lymphoma, leukaemia, and certain myeloproliferative neoplasms.

Option A: Basophils

  • Basophils are usually increased during malignancy such as CML or during hypersensitivity reactions

Macrophages

  • Macrophages are involved in bacterial infections.
  • They do not play a significant role in parasitic infections

Option C: Macrophages

  • Macrophages are involved in bacterial infections.
  • They do not play a significant role in parasitic infections

Option D: Lymphocytes

  • Monocytes are increased in autoimmune infections.
  • They are also increased during the fungal and viral infections

questions.text: A 76-year-old female complains of chest pain, fever and productive cough with rust-coloured sputum. A chest X-ray reveals an infiltrate in the right middle lobe. Sputum cultures are positive for Streptococcus pneumoniae. Phagocytic cells in affected lung tissue generate bactericidal hypochlorous acid using the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Option C: Myeloperoxidase

  • The myeloperoxidase enzyme generates hypochlorous acid.

Reactive oxygen species-mediated killing of the microbes:

  • ROS are produced by the rapid assembly and activation of a multicomponent oxidase, NADPH oxidase (also called phagocyte oxidase), which oxidises reduced nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) and, in the process, reduces oxygen to superoxide anion (O2 • ).
  • In neutrophils, this oxidative reaction is triggered by activating signals accompanying phagocytosis and is called the respiratory burst.
  • Phagocyte oxidase is an enzyme complex consisting of at least seven proteins. Different enzyme components are located in the plasma membrane and the cytoplasm in resting neutrophils.
  • In response to activating stimuli, the cytosolic protein components translocate to the phagosomal membrane, where they assemble and form the functional enzyme complex.
  • Thus, the ROS are produced within the phagolysosome, where they can act on ingested particles without damaging the host cell.
  • O2 • is converted into hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), mostly by spontaneous dismutation. H2O2 is not able to kill microbes efficiently by itself.
  • However, the azurophilic granules of neutrophils contain the enzyme myeloperoxidase (MPO), which, in the presence of a halide such as Cl−, converts H2O2 to hypochlorite (HOCl˙), the active ingredient in household bleach.
  • The latter is a potent antimicrobial agent that destroys microbes by halogenation (in which the halide is bound covalently to cellular constituents) or by oxidation of proteins and lipids (lipid peroxidation).
  • The H2O2-MPOhalide system is the most potent bactericidal system of neutrophils. Nevertheless, inherited deficiency of MPO leads to a minimal increase in susceptibility to infection, emphasising the redundancy of microbicidal mechanisms in leukocytes.
  • H2O2 is also converted to hydroxyl radical (˙OH), another powerful destructive agent

Option A: Catalase

  • Catalase is involved in the degradation of H2O2.
  • A defect in this enzyme results in increased susceptibility to infection by catalase-positive organisms such as staphylococcus aureus.

Option B: Cyclooxygenase

  • Cyclooxygenases are involved in synthesising prostaglandin molecules which are important mediators of inflammation.
  • Arachidonic acid is synthesised due to the action of phospholipase A2 on the membranes and later acted upon by cyclooxygenases or lipoxygenases to generate inflammatory mediators such as prostaglandins, leukotrienes, lipoxins and thromboxane A2.

Option D: Superoxide dismutase

  • SOD is an enzyme which forms H202 from superoxide radicals.
  • The catalase enzyme further degrades this H202.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents with a 1-week history of febrile illness and chest pain. She has an erythematous, macular facial rash and tender joints, particularly in her left wrist and elbow. A complete blood count shows mild anaemia and decreased platelet count. She also has increased serum levels of ceruloplasmin, fibrinogen, α2-macroglobulin, serum amyloid A protein, and C-reactive protein. All these markers belong to which of the following families of proteins?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acute phase proteins

  • Acute-phase proteins are plasma proteins, mostly syn­thesized in the liver, whose plasma concentrations may increase several hundred­fold as part of the response to inflammatory stimuli. 
  • Three of the best ­known of these proteins are C­-reactive protein (CRP), fibrinogen, and serum amyloid A (SAA) protein. 
  • Synthesis of these mol­ecules in hepatocytes is stimulated by cytokines, espe­cially interleukin-6 (IL-­6), for C-reactive proteins and fibrinogen and interleukin-1 (IL­1) or tumour necrosis factor (TNF) for serum amyloid A (SAA). 
  • Many acute­ phase proteins, such as CRP and SAA, bind to microbial cell walls, and they may act as opsonins and fix complement. They also bind chroma­tin, possibly aiding in clearing necrotic cell nuclei.
  • Fibrinogen binds to red cells and causes them to form stacks (rouleaux) that sediment more rapidly at unit gravity than do individual red cells.
  • Changes in the plasma levels of acute phase proteins are mediated primarily by cytokines (IL-1, IL-6 and TNF-α).
  • Increased plasma levels of some acute phase proteins are reflected in an increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).
  • ESR is an index used clinically to monitor the activity of many other inflammatory diseases.

Option B: Anaphylatoxins

  • Anaphylatoxins such as (C3a and C5a) have effects similar to those of mast cell mediators that are involved in anaphylaxis.

Option C: Inhibitors of platelet activation

  • Prostacyclin PG I-2, nitric oxide, and adenosine diphosphatase are inhibitors of platelet activation secreted by endothelium.

Option D: Regulators of coagulation

  • The protein C system provides important control of blood coagulation by regulating the activities of factor VIIIa (FVIIIa) and factor Va (FVa), cofactors in the activation of factor X and prothrombin, respectively. 
  • The system comprises membrane-bound and circulating proteins that assemble into multi-molecular complexes on cell surfaces. 
  • Vitamin K-dependent protein C, the key component of the system, circulates in the blood as a zymogen to an anticoagulant serine protease. 
  • It is efficiently activated on the surface of endothelial cells by thrombin bound to the membrane protein thrombomodulin. 
  • The endothelial protein C receptor (EPCR) further stimulates protein C activation. Activated protein C (APC), together with its cofactor protein S inhibits coagulation by degrading FVIIIa and FVa on the surface of negatively charged phospholipid membranes.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presents to the surgical clinic complaining of swelling over the scalp  region, which gradually developed over 6 months. He now complains of pus discharge several times in the past month, associated with pain. On examination, swelling sized 3x2 cm, Firm, Fixed; Tenderness(+), Warmth(+), Punctum(+), Discharge(+). Incision & Drainage is done, and the wound is left open to heal. Which of the following is a  mechanism for healing in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Granulation tissue

  • Healing by secondary intention usually occurs via the formation of granulation tissue.

Healing by Second Intention

  • Healing by second intention, also called the secondary union, differs from primary healing in several respects.
  • In wounds causing large tissue deficits, the fibrin clot is larger, and there is more exudate and necrotic debris in the wounded area. Inflammation is more intense because large tissue defects have a greater volume of necrotic debris, exudate, and fibrin that must be removed. Consequently, large defects have a greater potential for secondary, inflammation-mediated injury.
  • Much larger amounts of granulation tissue are formed to fill a bigger gap caused by the larger deficit area. A greater volume of granulation tissue generally results in a greater mass of scar tissue.
  • At first, a provisional matrix containing fibrin, plasma fibronectin, and type III collagen is formed. Still, in about 2 weeks, this is replaced by a matrix composed primarily of type I collagen.
  • Ultimately the original granulation tissue scaffold is converted into a pale, avascular scar. The dermal appendages that have been destroyed in the line of the incision are permanently lost.
