By the end of the first month, the scar is made up of acellular connective tissue devoid of inflammatory infiltrate, covered by an intact epidermis.
  • Wound contraction helps close the wound by decreasing the gapbetween its dermal edges and reducing the wound surface area. Hence it is an important feature in healing by the secondary union. Wound contraction involves the formation of a network of myofibroblasts, which are modified fibroblasts which have contractile properties. Within 6 weeks, large skin defects may be reduced to 5% to 10% of their original size, largely by contraction.

Option A: Granuloma formation

  • A granuloma is a focal aggregate of immune cells that forms in response to a persistent inflammatory stimulus.
  • It characteristically demonstrates the compact organisation of mature macrophages, which may or may not be associated with other inflammatory cell types.

Option B: Scab formation

  • A scab is formed in the case of superficial abrasion.
  • When the wound is open, the healing occurs by secondary intention, and granulation tissue is formed.

Option D: Neovascularisation

  • Neovascularisation is a feature of wound healing.
  • It is also seen in the healing process.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman came with complaints of swallowing difficulties, dysarthria, fluctuating limb muscle weakness, and bilateral eyelid ptosis with incomplete occlusion. the symptoms decreased with rest and sleep. On examination, there was asymmetrical bilateral eyelid ptosis, unequal palpebral fissures with incomplete occlusion, limitation of facial movements and dysphagia. A neostigmine test was done with the improvement of symptoms post-injection. Which of the following is involved in the pathogenesis of the disease described here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and examination findings points out this as a case of Myasthenia gravis.

MYASTHENIA GRAVIS:

  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease caused by a defect of neuromuscular transmission due to antibody-mediated attack on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors or muscle-specific tyrosine kinase (MuSK) receptors at the postsynaptic neuromuscular junction.
  • It is characterized by ?uctuating muscle weakness and fatigability. Myasthenia is improved by acetylcholinesterase inhibitors or immunosuppressants and in selected cases, thymectomy can be performed.
  • Dysphagia and dysarthria are two of the common symptoms and are due to oropharyngeal muscle involvement. They can be the first symptoms of the disease and sometimes can be misdiagnosed as emotional problems, usually depression

- Post synaptic defect

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presented to the physician's office complaining of progressive generalised weakness as the day progressed. On physical examination, she had drooping of the eyelids bilaterally and proximal muscle weakness in the shoulders and hips. After laboratory testing, she was found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (AChR). Which of the following is most commonly associated with this disease?
questions.solution:
Option C: Thymic hyperplasia

  • The findings, such as weakness as the day progresses and antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, point towards Myasthenia gravis.

Thymic Hyperplasia

  • Thymic enlargement (hyperplasia) is associated with lymphoid follicles or germinal centres within the medulla. These germinal centres contain reactive B cells. Thymic follicular hyperplasia is found in patients with Myasthenia Gravis and other autoimmune diseases such as Systemic Lupus Erythematosus and Rheumatoid Arthritis. Removal of the hyperplastic thymus is beneficial in early disease.
  • About 30% of patients (particularly young patients) with Myasthenia Gravis have thymic hyperplasia. Anti-AChR mediated cases have bimodal age distribution with early onset before 50 years, more common in females and frequently associated with enlargement of the thymus due to the presence of B-cell follicles and germinal centres (follicular thymic hyperplasia).
  • Myasthenia gravis is an Autoimmune disease with fluctuating muscle weakness caused by autoantibodies that target the neuromuscular junction causing damage to the receptors and the neuromuscular junctions.
  • About 85% of patients have autoantibodies against post-synaptic ACh receptors.
  • The patient presents with ptosis (drooping eyelids) or diplopia (double vision due to weakness in extraocular muscle).

Option A: Thymoma

  • Thymoma occurs in middle-aged adults where late-onset cases of Myasthenia Gravis show more association with thymoma derived from the thymic epithelium.
  • The patients present with cough, dyspnea, and superior vena cava syndrome.
  • Thymoma is commonly associated with Myasthenia Gravis, in which concomitant thymoma is discovered in 15% to 20% of patients. Removal of this tumour often leads to improved neuromuscular disorders; other important disorders associated with Thymoma are Pure red cell aplasia, hypogammaglobulinemia, and multi-organ autoimmunity.

Option B: Thymic carcinoma

  • Thymic carcinoma is type II malignant thymoma which is a rare thymoma.
  • However, it occurs in late-onset Myasthenia cases and is not seen in young individuals such as this patient.

Option D: Lymphoma

  • Myasthenia gravis is associated with thymic hyperplasia and thymoma.
  • It commonly occurs with thymic hyperplasia in young individuals with the early-onset disease and late-onset in middle-aged adults; it is associated with thymoma.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient was brought by her mother with a crown fracture of maxillary central incisors due to a fall 2 hours back. She has been mentally disabled since birth. She is morbidly obese and has narrow shoulders. Further tests reveal maternal disomy of chromosome 15. What is the cause of obesity in the given disease?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ghrelin

  • The case mentioned above has features suggesting Prader-Willi syndrome and obesity are due to ghrelin.
  • When two copies of a chromosome come from the same parent rather than from the mother and the father, this condition is referred to as uniparental disomy:
    • When a baby receives duplicate copies of a certain piece of chromosome 15 from the father, Angelman syndrome may develop (rather than one from the mother and one from the father).
    • On the other side, PWS (Prader-Willi syndrome) can occur when a newborn receives both copies of chromosome no.5 from the mother.
  • Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) is a genetic condition occurring in 1 of 10,000–16,000 live births. It is characterised by excessive appetite, massive progressive obesity, short stature, and mental retardation.
  • The cause of obesity is thought to be increased levels of ghrelin. The majority of individuals have hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and GH deficiency.

Option A: LH

  • There is no role of LH in PWS-induced obesity.
  • Obesity in PWS is due to ghrelin leading to hyperphagia.

Option B: FSH

  • FSH has no role in causing obesity.
  • PWS causes obesity due to increased ghrelin, a growth hormone secretagogue leading to hyperphagia.

Option C: Growth hormone

  • Obesity is due to increased ghrelin, a growth hormone secretagogue.
  • Growth hormone has no role in inducing obesity in patients with PWS.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl child with a known case of sickle cell disease came for a blood transfusion. Her history is significant for recurrent childhood infections and acute chest syndrome. Her father also has sickle cell trait, and her mother has inflammatory bowel disease. On examination, swelling of fingers was noted, as shown in the picture below. She also reports she marked pain in her hands and feet.



In sickle cell disease, which of the following does not influence the degree of sickling of red cells?
questions.solution:
Option C: Intake of primaquine

  • Intake of primaquine triggers hemolysis in G6PD deficiency and is unrelated to sickle cell disease/sickling.
  • The picture in the question explains dactylitis, usually seen in vaso-occlusive crisis in sickle cell disease.

 

 

  • Sickle cell anaemia is a type of intrinsic hemolytic anaemia which results in both extravascular and intravascular hemolysis.
  • Sickle cell disease is caused by a point mutation in which glutamic acid is replaced by valine at position 6 of the beta chain, generating a sticky patch on the surface of HbS.
  • The sticky patch on the surface of adjacent HbS molecules causes their polymerization [in dehydration & deoxygenation], forming long fibrous precipitates.
  • HbA, HbF can also weakly interact with HbS & prevent its polymerization (HbF >> HbA). Therefore individuals with the co-inherited conditions of hereditary persistence of fetal Hb (HPFH) have less severe due to reduced sickling.
  • Vaso occlusive crises include priapism, dactylitis, acute chest syndrome, avascular necrosis of the head of the femur, stroke, etc.
  • Mutation promotes the polymerization of deoxygenated haemoglobin, leading to red cell distortion (sickling), hemolytic anaemia, microvascular obstruction, and ischemic tissue damage.
  • Low oxygen, high altitude, and acidosis precipitate sickling. Intracellular dehydration increases the MCHC and facilitates sickling.
  • The mainstay of treatment is an inhibitor of DNA synthesis, hydroxyurea. Hydroxyurea increases the concentration of HbF.

 

Option A: Hereditary persistence of fetal haemoglobin

  • HbF is protective against sickle cell disease.
  • Hydroxyurea used in the management of sickle cell disease increases the concentration of HbF.

 

Option B: Intracellular pH

  • A decrease in intracellular pH reduces the oxygen affinity of haemoglobin.
  • Thereby increasing the fraction of deoxygenated HbS at any given oxygen tension and augmenting the tendency for sickling.

 

Option D: Co-existing α-thalassemia

  • Condition-reducing MCHC also leads to less severe disease, e.g., an individual who is homozygous for HbS also has coexistent α-thalassemia, which reduces Hb synthesis and leads to milder disease.

questions.text: A five-year-old boy is brought to your clinic by his mother with complaints of fever and fatigue. His mother states that he frequently gets ill. The patient's fever is associated with joint pain. The patient's examination findings are positive for hepatosplenomegaly and lymph node enlargement. Further investigations reveal a diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia. The blast cells are positive for the cell marker CD95. CD95 is an important cell marked for which of the following processes?
questions.solution:
Option B: Extrinsic pathway of apoptosis

  • Apoptosis is the programmed cell death that occurs in multicellular organisms.
  • It is characterized by the following:
    • Blebbing
    • Cell shrinkage
    • Nuclear fragmentation
    • Chromatin condensation
    • DNA fragmentation
    • mRNA decay
  • Apoptosis is a highly regulated and controlled process.
  • It can be initiated through:
    • Intrinsic pathway
    • Extrinsic pathway
  • The extrinsic pathway is activated by extracellular ligands binding to cell-surface death receptors, which leads to the formation of the death-inducing signalling complex (DISC)
  • The extrinsic pathway can be activated by:
    • TNF (tumour necrosis factor) pathway
    • Fas (first apoptosis signal) pathway
  • The fas receptor is also known as Apo-1 or CD95
  • CD95 is a transmembrane protein of the TNF family which binds the Fas ligand (FasL)
  • This complex results in the formation of a death-inducing signalling complex (DISC), which contains the FADD (fas-associated death domain), caspase-8 and caspase-10
  • Formation of DISC leads to the initiation of apoptosis.

Option A: Intrinsic pathway of apoptosis

  • The intrinsic pathway is also known as the mitochondrial pathway.
  • Cytochrome c is released from the mitochondria by proteins Bax and Bak.
  • Cytochrome c binds with apoptotic protease activating factor-1 (Apaf-1) and ATP.
  • This combination further binds to pro-caspase-9 to create a protein complex called an apoptosome.
  • This apoptosome cleaves the pro-caspase to its active form, which initiates apoptosis.

Option C: Necrosis of cell

  • The premature death of cells due to cell injury is called necrosis.
  • Necrosis is caused by external factors, such as infection or trauma, resulting in cellular components' unregulated destruction.

Option D: Cellular adaption

  • Cellular adaptation is the changes made by a cell in response to any change.
  • This adaptation may be physiological or pathological.

questions.text: A 56-year-old postmenopausal female presents to the gynaecological outpatient department due to painful and heavy menstrual bleeding for the past 3 days. Her last menstrual period (LMP) was 10 years ago. Examination reveals a non-bloody vaginal discharge. An endometrial biopsy reveals atypical cells. Which of the following is not associated with the patient’s condition?

choices.text: The process occurs in labile cells
There is an increase in the number of cells.
The risk of malignancy is present in certain cases.
Bone marrow cannot undergo this process.

questions.solution:
Option D: Bone marrow cannot undergo this process.

  • The patient presents with abnormal uterine bleeding, dysmenorrhea, and non-bloody vaginal discharge. The endometrial biopsy revealed atypical cells. All these clinical features lead to the diagnosis of endometrial hyperplasia.
  • Hyperplasia occurs in labile cells (capable of dividing).
  • It is an increase in the number of cells of an organ or tissue in response to stimulus or stress.
  • Hyperplasia can be physiologic or pathologic.
  • Most forms of pathologic hyperplasia are caused by excessive or inappropriate actions of hormones or growth factors acting on target cells.
  • Pathologic hyperplasia may eventually lead to cancerous proliferation.
  • Endometrial hyperplasia is an example of abnormal hormone-induced hyperplasia, and patients with endometrial hyperplasia are at increased risk for developing endometrial cancer.
  • Bone marrow can undergo rapid hyperplasia in response to a deficiency of terminally differentiated/mature blood cells (anemia, leucopenia, and/or thrombocytopenia).

Option A: The process occurs in labile cells.

  • Hyperplasia occurs in labile cells, which replace the cells lost from the body by dividing continuously.
  • Examples of labile cells include
    • Epidermis
    • Epithelia of ducts
    • Hematopoietic stem cells.

Option B: There is an increase in the number of cells.

  • The number of cells is increased in cellular hyperplasia.
  • It is an increase in the number of cells of an organ or tissue in response to stimulus or stress.

Option C: Risk of malignancy is present in certain cases.

  • Pathological hyperplasia can be a risk factor for malignancy.
  • An abnormal stressor may lead to uncontrollable divisions, which result in malignancies.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of easy bruising and fatigue. She appears pale. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Examination shows a palm-sized hematoma on her left leg. Abdominal examination shows an enlarged liver and spleen. Her haemoglobin concentration is 9.5 g/dL, her leukocyte count is 12,300/mm3, her platelet count is 55,000/mm3, and her fibrinogen concentration is 120 mg/dL. Cytogenetic analysis of leukocytes shows a reciprocal translocation of chromosomes 15 and 17. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Acute promyelocytic leukaemia

  • A chromosomal t(15;17) translocation is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukaemia (M3), which would explain this patient's B symptoms (low-grade fever, fatigue) and signs of coagulopathy (easy bruising, fibrinogen).

Acute Myelogenous Leukemia:

  • Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) is adults' most common acute leukaemia.
  • AML comprises a heterogeneous group of cancers of blood cells that arise from genetic and epigenetic changes in hematopoietic stem and/or progenitor cells that exhibit abnormal growth and differentiation.
  • Most patients with AML present with findings of cytopenias (e.g., fatigue, infections, bleeding), but some exhibit only laboratory abnormalities.
  • Others present with a clinical emergency, including hyperleukocytosis/leukostasis, tumour lysis syndrome (TLS), disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), or involvement of the central nervous system (CNS) and require urgent management.
  • AML is associated with characteristic non-random chromosomal and genetic abnormalities, many of which are used to classify AML and are associated with response to therapy and prognosis.
  • Treatment decisions are informed by comorbid illnesses, age, AML category, and other factors.  
  • (APL)M3-AML is the most common type of AML associated with DIC (Acute promyelocytic leukaemia).
  • TREATMENT
    • All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA), a vitamin A analogue, causes neoplastic promyelocytes to differentiate into neutrophils, rapidly lowering the risk of DIC.
    • AsO3 is another useful agent (arsenic trioxide)

Option A: Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia

  • ALL can present with hepatosplenomegaly and pancytopenia.
  • T-ALL involves the mediastinum, while B-ALL involves the CNS
  • DIC is not seen in ALL

Option B: Acute megakaryocytic leukaemia

  • In this variant of AML, blasts of megakaryocytic lineage predominate
  • Detected with antibodies against megakaryocyte-specific markers (GPIIb/IIIa or vWF)
  • Often associated with marrow fibrosis
  • Most common AML in Down syndrome
  • DIC is not seen.

Option D: Chronic myelogenous leukaemia

  • Peak incidence: 45–85 years; median age: 64 years.
  • Defined by the Philadelphia chromosome (t[9;22], BCR-ABL) and myeloid stem cell proliferation.
  • Presents with dysregulated production of mature and maturing granulocytes (e.g., neutrophils, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, basophils ) and splenomegaly.
  • May accelerate and transform to AML or ALL ("blast crisis").
  • Responds to BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., imatinib).
  • DIC is not a feature of this disorder.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male presents to the outpatient department due to fatigue on exertion for 2 weeks. He has no other associated symptoms and no medical disorder history. His recent laboratory investigations are as follows:


	
		
			Hb
			10.6g/dl
		
		
			MCV
			92fL 
		
		
			Neutrophils
			1.3x103/microliter
		
		
			Platelets
			117x109/microliter
		
		
			Creatinine
			0.9mg/dl
		
		
			Serum calcium
			11.2mg/dl
		
		
			Serum albumin
			3.8mg/dl
		
	


A skeletal examination reveals occult lytic lesions in the skull and bilateral humeri. A serum protein electrophoresis reveals elevated levels of monoclonal Ig A protein. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Multiple myeloma

  • The patient presents with the clinical features (bone pains, lethargy, anaemia, hypercalcemia, lytic lesions in the bones, and elevated IgA) of multiple myeloma.
  • Multiple myeloma is one of the most common lymphoid malignancies.
  • It usually presents in old age with the characteristic features as follows:
    • Bone pains/ pathologic fractures
    • Confusion (due to hypercalcemia)
    • Weakness and lethargy (due to hypercalcemia)
    • Recurrent bacterial infections
    • Renal insufficiency/dysfunction (Bence-jones proteinuria/renal failure)
  • The chromosomal translocation resulting in the fusion of IgH locus on chromosome 14 with oncogenes cyclin D1 and cyclin D3 genes is responsible for multiple myeloma.
  • Interleukin 6 (IL-6) and translocations of MYC are also involved in the pathogenesis of multiple myeloma.
  • Hypercalcemia and pathologic bone fractures occur due to the activation of osteoclasts by upregulating the expression of the receptor activator of NF-kB ligand (RANKL) in the bone marrow stromal cells.
  • Renal dysfunction occurs due to obstructive proteinaceous casts in the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts, light chain deposition in the glomeruli or interstitium, hypercalcemia and bacterial pyelonephritis.

Option B: Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia

  • Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) occurs in children mainly.
  • They usually present with anaemia, recurrent bacterial infections and petechiae.
  • Hypercalcemia, lytic skeletal lesions, elevated IgA, and renal dysfunction are not ALL features.

Option C: Hairy cell leukaemia

  • Hairy cell leukaemia presents with pancytopenia and splenomegaly.
  • Hairy cells are seen on microscopic examination.
  • Hypercalcemia and renal dysfunction are not seen.

Option D: Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma

  • IgM is the predominant form of immunoglobulin in Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma).
  • It presents as hyperviscosity syndrome.
  • Renal dysfunction and bone destruction are rare.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with significant sudden right-sided flank pain that started after he assisted his father in painting his bedroom ceiling this morning. On physical examination, his vitals are normal, but there is an ecchymosis in the right flank that is painful to touch. He has always been prone to bruising. His brother also has the same issue. His workup shows that clotting factor VIII levels in the blood are less than 2% normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's bleeding tendency?

choices.text: Circulating antibodies directed against factor VIII
Decreased hepatic synthesis of multiple coagulation factors
Genetic defect involving the factor VIII gene

questions.solution:
Option D: Genetic defect involving the factor VIII gene

  • Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder of blood clotting that results in spontaneous bleeding, particularly into joints, muscles, and internal organs and easy bruising.
  • Classic haemophilia results from mutations in the gene encoding factor VIII.
  • The Intrinsic Pathway of coagulation is affected.
  • Factor VIII-a complex is the most important activator of factor X required for conversion of prothrombin to thrombin

Option A: Circulating antibodies directed against factor VIII

  • The development of alloantibody neutralizing factor VIII (FVIII) coagulant activity (inhibitors) represents the main complication in treating haemophilia A.
  • It occurs in approximately one-third of previously untreated patients and causes substantial morbidity and mortality for patients and increased costs for the health care system.
  • The circulating antibodies are one of the complications and not the primary pathology.

Option B:  Decreased hepatic synthesis of multiple coagulation factors

  • The decreased capacity of the liver to synthesize proteins is the main cause of decreased blood levels of clotting factors II, V, VII, IX, and X and of antithrombin III in patients with liver disease. 
  • In this scenario, only Factor VIII deficiency is seen.

Option C: Deficiency of Vitamin K

  • Vitamin K deficiency is rare in adults because many  foods we eat contain adequate amounts of K1, and the body makes K2 on its own.
  • Plus, the body is good at recycling its supply of vitamin K.
  • However, certain conditions and some drugs can interfere with vitamin K absorption and creation, making it possible to become deficient.
  • The main symptom of vitamin K deficiency is excessive bleeding.
  • People at risk generally take anticoagulants, take antibiotics, or have a condition where fat absorption is a problem as it is a fat-soluble vitamin.
  • The treatment for vitamin K is the drug phytonadione, which is vitamin K1

questions.text: Following a car accident, a 19-year-old boy is transported to the emergency room in shock. He receives 5 units of blood transfusion. The patient experiences fever, nausea, vomiting, and chest pain after the transfusion. Indirect serum bilirubin is high, serum haptoglobin is decreased, and the Coombs test is positive. Which of the following diagnoses is the most likely?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hemolytic transfusion reaction

  • A hemolytic transfusion reaction occurs when grossly incompatible blood is administered to patients with preformed alloantibodies.
  • It is an acute reaction characterised by the following:
  • High-grade fever
  • Chills
  • Rigours
  • Flank Pain
  • Oozing of blood from venipuncture
  • Massive hemolysis of the transfused blood may be associated with severe complications, including hypotension, renal failure, and even death.
  • It is usually caused by clerical errors that lead to the transfusion of mismatched blood.

Option A: Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia (AIHA)

  • Normocytic anaemia is usually idiopathic and Coombs ⊕. Two types:
  • Warm AIHA: It is a chronic anaemia in which primarily IgG causes extravascular hemolysis. Seen in Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) and with certain drugs (e.g., β-lactams, α-methyldopa).
  • Cold AIHA: It is an acute anaemia in which primarily IgM + complement causes RBC agglutination and extravascular hemolysis upon exposure to cold, painful, blue fingers and toes. Seen in CLL, Mycoplasma pneumoniae infections, and infectious mononucleosis.
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia is not associated with blood transfusion.

Option B: Disseminated intravascular coagulation

  • Widespread clotting factor activation thromboembolic state with excessive clotting factor consumption thromboses, haemorrhages (e.g., blood oozing from puncture sites).
  • It may be acute (life-threatening) or chronic (if clotting factor production can compensate for consumption).
  • Causes are heat stroke, snake bites, sepsis (gram ⊝), trauma, obstetric complications, acute pancreatitis, malignancy, nephrotic syndrome, and transfusion.
  • Laboratory investigations show: schistocytes, increased fibrin degradation products (d-dimers), decreased fibrinogen and decreased factors V and VIII
  • It is not associated with blood transfusion.
  • It is also not associated with a positive Coomb test

Option D: Hemolytic uremic syndrome

  • The hemolytic uremic syndrome is a triad of anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury due to microthrombi forming on damaged endothelium causes mechanical hemolysis (with schistocytes on peripheral blood smear), platelet consumption, andrenal blood flow.
  • It is associated with the Shiga toxin-producing serotype of Enterohemorrhagic E. coli O157:H7
  • It is not associated with blood transfusion.
  • It is also not associated with a positive Coomb test.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man visits the clinic with a complaint of vague abdominal distress for the last few weeks. The patient's weight has been stable. He has a history of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis and has been taking medications to provide symptomatic relief. The gastric lesion shown in the figure is resected following initial endoscopic discovery. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Chronic gastric peptic ulcer

  • This patient with abdominal discomfort, a long-standing history of analgesic use for symptomatic relief, and the image showing characteristic radiating folds of gastric mucosa starting at the ulcer margins, most likely has a chronic gastric peptic ulcer.
  • The incidence of peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is falling along with the reduced prevalence of H. pylori infection (owing to successful H. pylori eradication therapy).
  • However, PUD in patients older than 60 years has increased due to growing NSAID use (esp. selective COX-2 inhibitors).
  • The most common form of PUD occurs within the gastric antrum or duodenum as a result of chronic H. pylori-induced antral gastritis, which is associated with increased gastric acid secretion and decreased duodenal bicarbonate secretion.

Risk factors for Helicobacter pylori infection

  • Cigarette use (synergizes with H. pylori for gastric PUD)
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
  • Illicit drugs, e.g., cocaine, that reduce mucosal blood flow
  • NSAIDs (potentiated by corticosteroids)
  • Alcoholic cirrhosis (primarily duodenal PUD)
  • Psychological stress (can increase gastric acid secretion)
  • Endocrine cell hyperplasia (can stimulate parietal cell growth and gastric acid secretion)
  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (PUD of stomach, duodenum, and jejunum)
  • Viral infection (CMV, herpes simplex virus)

Option B: Gastric carcinoma

  • It presents with features of:
    • Upper GI bleeding
    • Gastric outlet obstruction
    • Significant weight loss

Option C: Ménétrier disease

  • It is characterized by foveolar hyperplasia leading to non-specific GIT-related symptoms and protein-losing gastropathy.
  • Endoscopy findings include prominent rugae involving the gastric fundus.

Option D: Gastroesophageal reflux disease

  • It is characterized by epigastric discomfort, most commonly occurring in adults with a sedentary lifestyle.
  • It is most commonly reported after the intake of a meal in obese individuals.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man arrives in the ER in an altered state after a suicide attempt with medication. He's dizzy, slurring his words and has low blood pressure. The doctor plans to start alkaline diuresis. What caused his condition?
questions.solution:
• Phenobarbitone - is a derivative of barbituric acid (weakly acidic drug) and its excretion can be enhanced by making the urine alkaline.
  • Absorption and reabsorption of a drug depends on its lipid solubility.
  • When a drug is in a similar medium (acidic drug in acidic medium or a basic drug in basic medium), it easily crosses membrane in its non-ionized form and gets absorbed/ reabsorbed.
  • Thus, in acidic drug poisoning (salicylate, barbiturates etc.) urine should be alkalinized with sodium bicarbonate because weak acids are in ionized form in alkaline urine and thus are easily excreted.
  • Similarly, for basic drug poisoning (e.g. morphine, amphetamine etc.), urine should be acidified using ammonium chloride.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male presents with diplopia, slurred speech, breathing difficulty, drooping eyelids, and fatigue for 2 weeks, worsening progressively throughout the day and improving with rest. No other abnormalities or chronic illnesses reported. Vital signs stable, with no other physical abnormalities. Doctor prescribed neostigmine over physostigmine. What justifies this drug preference?

choices.text: It has a longer duration of action
It doesn't cross BBB effectively and has no central action

questions.solution:
Option C: It has additional direct agonistic action on nicotinic receptors at the muscle end plate

  • This is a case of myasthenia gravis in which the patient presents with complaints of diplopia, slurred speech, difficulty in breathing, drooping of eyelids and generalised fatigue for 2 weeks.
  • The patient further gives a history that his symptoms worsened progressively through the day, and he comparatively feels better with rest. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities.
  • All these symptoms suggest myasthenia gravis.
  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease which weakens the muscles. The symptoms of this disease usually appear after periods of activity and improve on rest.
  • The doctor prescribed neostigmine to the patient for the treatment of myasthenia gravis.
  • The doctor preferred neostigmine over physostigmine because neostigmine has additional direct agonistic action on nicotinic receptors at the muscle end plate.

Option A: It is better absorbed orally

  • Neostigmine is not preferred over physostigmine in the treatment of myasthenia gravis because of better absorption orally.
  • Actually, physostigmine has better GIT absorption than neostigmine.

Option B: It has a longer duration of action

  • The duration of physostigmine is longer than the neostigmine.
  • So, we can’t choose this option.

Option D: It penetrates the blood-brain barrier

  • Neostigmine and physostigmine both penetrate the blood-brain barrier.
  • In fact, the penetration of the blood-brain barrier of neostigmine is less than physostigmine.​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 38-year-old female in the emergency department presents with weakness, sudden palpitations, sweating, and reduced urine output. Her vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C, respiratory rate of 24 cycles/minute, and blood pressure of 88/64 mmHg. W ith a history of myocardial infarction, she's administered dopamine infusion. Why choose dopamine over dobutamine in this case?

choices.text: It has additional renal vasodilatory effect

questions.solution:
Option A: It has an additional vasodilatory effect

  • This is a case of cardiogenic shock with oliguric failure in which the patient presents with complaints of weakness, sudden onset palpitation and sweating associated with decreased urine output.
  • Dopamine is the drug of choice for a cardiogenic shock with oliguric renal failure.
  • It acts on D1 (at a dose of 1-2 μg/kg/ min.), β1 (at 2-10 μg/kg/min.) and α1 (at > 10 μg/kg/min.) receptors.
  • It is a sympathomimetic agent with prominent dopaminergic and B1 adrenergic effects, which may be used for inotropic support in patients with refractory heart failure. 
  • It causes renal vasodilation by acting on D1 receptors and maintains renal perfusion and GFR.
  • Unlike dopamine, dobutamine does not seem to affect dopaminergic receptors and causes no renal or mesenteric vasodilation and thus cannot affect renal perfusion.
  • Low-dose dopamine infusion has been used in combination with loop diuretics to augment diuresis and improve renal blood flow in patients with acute decompensated heart failure.

Option B: It increases cardiac output

  • Both dopamine and dobutamine can increase cardiac output.
  • They increase cardiac output by acting on B1 receptors.

Option C: It causes peripheral vasoconstriction only

  • Dopamine can cause peripheral vasoconstriction at high doses in addition to its vasodilation in renal, mesenteric and intracerebral beds.

Option D: It has prolonged action

  • Both dopamine and dobutamine have the same duration of action.
  • The duration of action of these drugs is 10 minutes.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presents with fever, anuria, nausea, and lethargy. On examination, the patient has a temperature of 40°C, respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min, blood pressure of 94/66 mmHg, and heart rate of 104 beats/min. His ECG reveals tall T waves. His serum electrolytes reveal Na+ 140 mmol/L, K+ 6.0 mmol/L, Cl-100 mmol/L, and HCO3- 24 mmol/L. Which of the following will be used for the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Calcium gluconate

  • In the clinical scenario, the patient is experiencing oliguria, which is suggestive of Acute Kidney Injury. Furthermore, low blood pressure, high heart rate, and tall T waves are telltale signs of Hyperkalemia. This is further supplemented by a high value of K+ (normal range 3.7-5.1 mmol/L) in the lab reports.
  • Calcium gluconate is the first-line agent in Hyperkalemia.
  • It reduces the abnormally high membrane potential of cells, especially cardiomyocytes.
  • Thus, neutralizing the effect of K+ on body cells.
  • A schematic chart for the treatment of hyperkalemia is shown below:

Option B: Magnesium Sulphate

  • Magnesium sulphate is an antihypertensive drug.
  • It is mainly used in eclampsia. It will worsen Hyperkalemia, as elevated levels of magnesium cause elevated K+ levels in the body.

Option C: Calcium Channel Blocker

  • Calcium channel blockers are antihypertensive drugs.
  • They will only worsen the hypotension of Hyperkalemia. They are not required in the management of Hyperkalemia.

Option D: IV KCl

  • IV KCl is used for the management of hypokalemia.
  • Its use in hyperkalemia is counterproductive.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male comes to your clinic with complaints of excessive thirst and excessive urination in the past 2-3 months. The patient sought a consultation since he had two episodes of bedwetting in the past week. On examination, you noticed that the patient had dry skin and also complained of mild constipation. You order fasting, random blood sugar, and an ultrasound of kidney, ureters, and, bladder (KUB), all of which turn out to be normal. Urinary and serum osmolality is consistent with diabetes insipidus. What would be the rationale for opting intranasal desmopressin spray over vasopressin?

choices.text: It causes less formation of factor VIII
It is more selective for the V2 receptor subtype
Provides greater relief of excessive thirst the patient is experiencing

questions.solution:
Option C: It is more selective for the V2 receptor subtype

  • Desmopressin is a selective agonist of V2 receptors of vasopressin. V2 receptors are present in the kidney and on the endothelium, whereas V1 receptors are present in blood vessels. Therefore, Desmopressin is less likely to cause vasoconstriction than vasopressin.

Option A: It causes less formation of factor VIII

  • Desmopressin can release factor VIII and vWF, similar to vasopressin.

Option B: It causes less hypernatremia

  • Desmopressin has a similar risk of causing hyponatremia due to the retention of water.

Option D: Provides greater relief of excessive thirst the patient is experiencing

  • Both desmopressin and vasopressin can provide similar relief from excessive thirst.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old female presents to the emergency with complaints of difficulty in breathing. She reports no associated cough or fever. On examination, her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), her pulse is 120/min, her respiration rate is 28/min, and her blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. There are scattered wheezes on pulmonary examination. A chest x-ray is shown below:



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Option A: Short-acting beta 2 agonists

  • This patient is most likely suffering from acute exacerbation of asthma. The management of acute exacerbation of asthma involves the use of short-acting beta 2 agonists like salbutamol.
  • Short-acting beta 2 agonist drugs are the drugs of choice for treating acute exacerbation of severe asthma. The management of asthma is summarised as follows:

Option B: Long-acting beta 2 agonist

  • Long-acting beta-agonists are a class of bronchodilator drugs with a long duration of action (≥ 12 hours).
  • Their onset of action is variable, which is quick for formoterol and longer for salmeterol.
  • These drugs are used for the long-term control of asthma and COPD symptoms. Usually administered via a nebuliser or metered-dosed inhaler.

Option C: Oral theophylline

  • Oral theophylline is used in the management of asthma. However, it has no role in the treatment of acute exacerbation of asthma.

Option D: Inhaled ipratropium bromide

  • These drugs are used in the treatment of COPD. However, these are not preferred for the treatment of asthma.

questions.text: A 20-year-old foreigner, who had recently come to India for vacation, comes to the emergency with complaints of acute, multiple episodes of loose bowel movement for the last few days and informs that he is a diagnosed case of Ulcerative colitis. On physical examination, he has tachycardia and is mildly febrile. Which of the following medications would be appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Prednisolone

  • In this scenario, a diagnosed case of ulcerative colitis presents with multiple episodes of loose stools and abdominal cramps for the last few days, suggestive of acute exacerbation of ulcerative colitis.
  • Corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment for acute exacerbation of ulcerative colitis.
  • Prednisolone (40-60 mg/day) is highly effective in controlling symptoms as well as it is the drug of choice for moderately severe exacerbations of ulcerative colitis.
  • The relief usually starts within 3- 7 days and remission is induced in 2-3 weeks.
  •  In more severe diseases, relief therapy may be initiated with intravenous methylprednisolone 40- 60 mg 12 to 24 hourly for a few days.
  •  Hydrocortisone enema can be used for topical treatment of proctitis and distal ulcerative colitis but is less effective than oral treatment.
  • Corticosteroids are generally used for the short term, tapered over 8- 12 weeks and discontinued after remission is induced.

Option B: Sulfasalazine

  • It is a compound of 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA).
  • Sulfasalazine reduces the number of stools, abdominal cramps, and fever but is less effective than corticosteroids.
  • It is suitable for mild to moderate exacerbation only. It may induce remission over a few weeks in many patients of ulcerative colitis, but relapses are common after stoppage.

Option C: Mesalazine

  • It is a compound of 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA).
  • The use of mesalazine is in preventing relapse of ulcerative colitis
  • It is used to treat mild-to-moderate exacerbations and as an adjunct to corticosteroids in more severe active diseases.

 Option D:  Vancomycin

  • It is an antimicrobial drug. It inhibits cell wall synthesis.
  • It is primarily bactericidal and active against gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria as well as Methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presented in the OPD with complaints of excessive thirst. He also reports has polyuria and polyphagia. He suspects it could be diabetes mellitus and orders fasting blood sugar, postprandial blood sugar & HbA1c. The HbA1c was about 12%, and the blood sugar values were over 240. He decides to start the patient on subcutaneous insulin therapy and educate the patient regarding the same. What is the mechanism of action of the therapy prescribed?
questions.solution:
Option B: Stimulation of Enzymatic receptor

  • Insulin acts by stimulation of Tyrosine kinase receptor → enzymatic receptor.
  • A full insulin receptor consists of two covalently linked heterodimers.
  • Tyrosine kinase receptor contains α subunit, which is entirely extracellular and constitutes the recognition site, and a β subunit that spans the membrane.
  • The β subunit contains tyrosine kinase.

Option A: Stimulation of Ionotropic receptor

  • Ionotropic receptors are coupled with some ion channels.
  •  When they bind a ligand, activation of the receptor results in a conformational change, rendering the ion channel open. In other words, they are the ligand-gated ion channels. The binding of the ligand results in the opening of ion channels
  • Ionotropic receptors allow ions to diffuse down their electrochemical gradient.

Option C: Stimulation of Metabotropic Receptors

  • A metabotropic receptor, also referred to by the broader term G-protein-coupled receptor, is a type of membrane receptor that initiates a number of metabolic steps to modulate cell activity. The nervous system utilizes two types of receptors: metabotropic and ionotropic receptors.
  • When a metabotropic receptor is activated, a series of intracellular events are triggered that can also result in ion channels opening or other intracellular events but involve a range of second messenger chemicals.

Option D: Stimulation of Nuclear receptor

  • Nuclear receptors are activated by lipid-soluble signals (e.g., steroid hormones) that cross the plasma membrane.
  • Once activated, most function as transcription factors to control gene expression for numerous biological processes.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the clinic with tremors in his hand. Cogwheel rigidity is seen in the arm. Which antiparkinsonian drug works by directly activating dopaminergic D2 receptors in the striatum?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pramipexole

  • Pramipexole is used to treat the symptoms of Parkinson's disease
  • It may be used alone or in combination with other medicines (e.g., Levodopa)
  • Pramipexole is a dopamine agonist
  • It works on the nervous system to help treat the symptoms of Parkinson's disease
  • It works by acting in place of dopamine, a natural substance in the brain that is needed to control movement.

Option B: Entacapone

  • Entacapone is an inhibitor of catechol-O-methyltransferase
  • Catechol-O-methyltransferase catalysis is a relatively minor pathway of dopamine metabolism
  • It, therefore, enhances the action of dopamine

Option C: Benserazide

  • Benserazide is a peripheral decarboxylase inhibitor
  • It increases the amount of levodopa crossing into the brain
  • subsequent conversion to dopamine

Option D: Selegiline

  • This medicine works to increase and extend the effects of Levodopa
  • It may help to slow the progress of Parkinson's disease

questions.text: What treatment is recommended for a 45-year-old male with schizophrenia who developed fever, diarrhea, confusion, high blood pressure, rapid pulse, muscle rigidity, hyperkalemia, and increased creatine kinase after 8 days of haloperidol treatment?
questions.solution:
Option C: Dantrolene

  • The patient has a history of schizophrenia and has recently started using haloperidol. Haloperidol is a first-generation (conventional) antipsychotic that works by competitive blockade of dopamine D2 receptors.
  • The signs and symptoms of generalized muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, autonomic instability (labile blood pressure, diarrhoea, and tachycardia), and altered mental status; associated with antipsychotics are indicative of neuroleptic malignant syndrome. 
  • The neuroleptic malignant syndrome can result in (as in this case) elevation of serum potassium and creatine kinase due to vigorous muscle contraction.
  • The management plan for the neuroleptic malignant syndrome includes:
    • Prompt discontinuation of the antipsychotic drug (haloperidol in this case)
    • Supportive care includes assessing and maintaining the airway, breathing, and circulation.
    • Pharmacotherapy comprises the use of dantrolene. Dantrolene is an antagonist of the Ryanodine receptor and works by preventing the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal muscle cells. This leads to a decrease in the magnitude of muscle rigidity, and resultantly hyperthermia is inhibited too.

Option A: Diazepam

  • Diazepam belongs to the benzodiazepine class of drugs.
  • Benzodiazepines can help relieve psychomotor agitation in such cases; however, dantrolene is the pharmacotherapy of choice for managing neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Option B: Flumazenil

  • Flumazenil is used to treat the toxicity of benzodiazepines. It is not used in the management of the neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Option D: High dose of haloperidol

  • The patient’s current signs and symptoms are already caused by the adverse reaction to haloperidol. So, the management includes discontinuation of this drug.

questions.text: An investigator develops a new drug used to treat arrhythmias. Before this drug is tested in humans, it is tested in animals. This is known as a preclinical study and is considered mandatory. To study sub-acute toxicities, the drug is given to animals for how much time?
questions.solution:
Option B: 2-12 weeks

  • Repeated drugs are given to animals for 2-12 weeks to test the sub-acute toxicity.

PRECLINICAL TOXICITY STUDIES

Acute toxicity studies
  • Single escalating doses are given to a small group of animals, and the animals are observed for 1-3 days.
  • LD50 is calculated.
  • Organ toxicity is examined by histopathology.

Sub-acute toxicity studies
  • Repeated doses of the drug are given for 2-12 weeks.
  • Animals are examined for overt effects, food intake, body weight, and haematology.

Chronic toxicity studies
  • The drug is given for 6-12 months.
  • Animals are examined for overt effects, food intake, body weight, and haematology.

 

Option A: Single dose

  • A single dose of the drug is given to the animals when testing the acute toxicities of a drug.

 

Option C: 6-12 months

  • When an investigator has to examine the chronic toxicities of a drug, the drug is given to animals for 6-12 months, and certain body parameters are examined.

 

Option D: 1-3 years

  • A duration of 1-3 years is not reasonable to test the sub-acute toxicities while doing the preclinical toxicity studies of a drug.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should be avoided in a patient with variant angina?
questions.solution:
Option C: Propranolol

  • Based on the symptoms of severe and squeezing left-sided chest pain, history of hypertension and diabetes, and transient ST elevation in this patient, the likely diagnosis is variant angina.
  • Variant angina, also known as vasospastic angina, results from a transient coronary spasm. It has no particular relation with exertion as it may also occur at rest, usually in the morning.
  • Management includes:
  • Smoking cessation
  • Avoidance of beta-blocker (non-selective in particular) as they may prevent beta 2 mediated coronary vasodilation and may result in additional vasoconstriction, thus precipitating coronary vasospasm and worsening the ischemia
  • Similarly, other agents with vasoconstrictive potential should also be avoided; these include: Triptans, High-dose aspirin (> 325 mg) , Alcohol and other recreational drugs 
  • The drug of choice is sublingual nitroglycerine.

Option A: Diltiazem

  • It is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that acts mainly on the heart and decreases heart contractility and heart rate.
  • It causes vasodilation of coronary vessels by the relaxation of smooth muscles. It is a cardinal drug in the management of acute attacks of coronary vasospasm as well as for prevention.

Option B: Nitrates

  • Nitrates act by the relaxation of smooth muscles of coronary vessels.
  • These are the drug of choice for vasospastic angina as they relieve coronary vasospasm, thereby increasing blood flow and decreasing ischemic injury of the myocardium.

Option D: Verapamil

  • It is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that acts mainly on the heart and decreases heart contractility and heart rate.
  • It causes vasodilation of coronary vessels by the relaxation of smooth muscles. It is a cardinal drug in the management of acute attacks of coronary vasospasm as well as for prevention.

questions.text: A 2-year-old baby is brought to the hospital by his mother ,who is complaining of a large portion of skin peeling away, redness of the skin, fever, and blister formation over the last 48 hours. On examination, the child is irritable, lethargic and crying excessively. The condition is shown in the image given below. Which of the following is true regarding the toxin released by the causative agent in this case?

choices.text: Beta haemolysin doesn’t show hot or cold phenomenon
An exfoliative toxin is not involved in Ritters disease

questions.solution:
Option B:  Mainly enterotoxins

  • The clinical data and the image suggest Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome caused by Staphylococcal aureus.
  • The staphylococcal toxin is mainly enterotoxin.

β Hemolysin:

  • Sphingomyelinase
  • Exhibits hot-cold phenomenon

β hemolysis is better seen at 37ºC

  • Staphylococcus does not produce endotoxin.
  • Endotoxin
    • Produced by gram (-) ve organisms, the only gram (+) ve organism secreting endotoxin is listeria.

Endotoxins are part of Gram-negative bacteria's outer membrane of the cell wall.

Enterotoxins:

Type A is responsible for most cases of food poisoning.

Epidermolysis toxin (Exfoliative toxin) causes:

  • Scalded skin syndrome (Nikolsky sign-epidermal layer separated). Refer to the image below.
  • Severe- Ritter disease (newborn), toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) (adult)
  • Milder- Pemphigus neonatorum, bullous impetigo
  • Exfoliative toxin A - encoded by beta located on a phage, is heat stable.
  • Exfoliative toxin B- plasmid-mediated and heat-labile.

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome:

  • Epidermolysis exotoxins (Exfoliative) A and B are induced by S. aureus → detachment within the epidermal layer by breaking down the desmosomes.
  • Exotoxins cleave desmoglein-1, which holds the granulosum and spinosum layers together, similar to the pathophysiology of the autoimmune skin disease 'pemphigus vulgaris.'

Option A:  Beta hemolysin doesn't show hot, or cold phenomenon

  • β Hemolysin:
    • Sphingomyelinase
    • Exhibits hot-cold phenomenon
    • β hemolysis is better seen at 37ºC

Option C: Exotoxin causes food poisoning

  • Enterotoxins:
    • Type A is responsible for most cases of food poisoning. Exotoxin is not involved in causing food poisoning.

Option D:  An exfoliative toxin is not involved in Ritter's disease

  • Epidermolysis toxin (Exfoliative toxin) causes:
    • Scalded skin syndrome (Nikolsky sign-epidermal layer separated).
    • Severe- Ritter disease (newborn), toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) (adult).
    • Milder- Pemphigus neonatorum, bullous impetigo.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presents to the physician complaining of cough for three weeks, chills, fever and extreme weight loss. The blood sample was sent to the laboratory for testing. In the laboratory, an interferon-gamma release assay was used for the diagnosis. Which of the following statements regarding the Interferon-gamma release assays used for the diagnosis is correct?

choices.text: 1st generation Quantiferon-TB does not use ESAT-6
2nd generation Quantiferon-TB (gold) used ESAT-6 and CFP-10
These tests can distinguish between M. tuberculosis and M. Bovis
None of the non-tubercular mycobacteria gives a positive reaction with this test

questions.solution:
Option B: 2nd generation Quantiferon-TB(gold) used ESAT-6 and CFP-10

  • This is a case of tuberculosis in which the patient presents with complaints of cough, fever, chills, and extreme weight loss for 3 weeks.
  • 2nd generation Quantiferon-TB (gold) used ESAT-6 and CFP-10.
  • Interferon-gamma release assays -IGRA (Quantiferon TB):
  • Cell-mediated immune (CMI) responses to peptide antigens that stimulate mycobacterial proteins.
  • Available assays are:
    • Quantiferon TB (1st generation): measured cell-mediated immunity to the same tuberculin purified protein derivative.
    • Quantiferon TB Gold (QFT, 2nd generation): Whole blood enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay.
  • In vitro assay for diagnosis of latent tuberculosis measures INF-γ released by T cells in response to highly specific TB antigens ESAT-6 and CFP-10.
  • ESAT-6, CFP-10, and TB7.7 (p4) are absent from all BCG strains and most nontuberculous mycobacteria except M. kansasii, M. szulgai, and M. marinum.
  • Serological tests are banned in India for MTB diagnosis.

Option A: 1st generation Quantiferon-TB does not use ESAT-6

  • 1st generation Quantiferon-TB also uses ESAT-6.

Option C: These tests can distinguish between M. tuberculosis and M. Bovis

  • The tests mentioned in the case cannot distinguish between M. Tuberculosis and M. Bovis.

Option D: None of the non-tubercular mycobacteria gives a positive reaction with this test

  • The non-tubercular mycobacteria can positively react to the test mentioned in this case.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of fever, diarrhea, rose spots on his back, stomach pain and vomiting for 1 week. He has no history of any chronic illnesses. He is vitally stable, and the remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The growth obtained on the sample culture is shown in the image below. Choose the right statement on the basis of given media and colony characteristics.

choices.text: Jet black-coloured colonies of S. typhi on Wilson Blair's agar.
Jet black-coloured colonies of S. typhi on Deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA).
Brown black-coloured colonies of S. typhi on Wilson Blair's agar.
Brown black coloured colonies of S. paratyphi A on Wilson Blair's agar

questions.solution:
Option A: Jet black colored colonies of S. typhi on Wilson Blair's agar

  • This is a case of typhoid fever in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, diarrhea, rose spots on his back, stomach pain and vomiting for 1 week.
  • Typhoid fever is caused by salmonella typhi.
  • In the given image, jet black-colored colonies of Salmonella typhi are seen on Wilson Blair's agar which is the best selective media.
  • In any case of typhoid fever, the investigation of choice is blood culture if the patient presents with 2 weeks of infection, but if the patient presents after 2 weeks of infection, then the investigation of choice is stool culture.

Wilson Blair's agar:

  • Bismuth sulphite, brilliant green - inhibitors → hinder the growth of most bacteria while allowing salmonella to grow.
  • Ferrous sulphate- Reacts with H2S → formation of ferrous sulfide→ brown-black colouration and also diffuses into the surrounding medium, giving a brown–black halo.

Option B: Jet black coloured colonies of S. typhi on Deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA)

  • S.typhi on deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA agar):
  • Pale colonies with a black center.
  •  H2S-producing organisms show a black center. Refer to the image below.

Option C: Brown, black-colored colonies of S. typhi on Wilson Blair's agar

  • Brown, black-colored colonies of salmonella typhi are not seen in Wilson Blair's agar.
  • On Wilson Blair’s agar, jet black colonies of salmonella typhi are seen

Option D: Brown, black-colored colonies of S. paratyphi A on Wilson Blair’s agar

  • The brown-black-colored colonies of S. paratyphi A are not seen on Wilson Blair's agar.
  • Wilson Blair’s agar shows jet black colonies for salmonella typhi.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of being tired all the time and having a slight fever for two weeks. He recently returned from a trip to Las Vegas, where he indulged in some of the infamous nightlife. He has no history of any chronic illnesses. The patient is vitally stable and his physical examination is unremarkable except for a macular rash over his trunk and on the palms of his hands. There are no lesions or ulcers on the penis. Which of the following organism is causing the patient's current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option C: Treponema pallidum

  • This is a case of syphilis in which the patient presents with complaints of being tired all the time and having a slight fever for two weeks. On examination, there is a macular rash over his trunk and on the palms of his hands.
  • Treponema pallidum is causing syphilis in this case.

Treponema pallidum:

  • It is transmitted through unprotected sexual activity with an infected individual.
  • It usually presents with the symptoms of secondary syphilis, which includes malaise, mild fever, and rash on the palms and trunk.
  • The primary lesion (chancre) may go unnoticed because it is painless and subsides in a few weeks.

Option A: Chlamydia trachomatis

  • It causes non-gonococcal urethritis.
  • Serotypes L1, L2, and L3: cause lymphogranuloma venereum.

Option B: Neisseria gonorrhoeae

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae can cause:
    • Urethritis
    • Cervicitis

Option D: Borrelia burgdorferi

  • Borrelia burgdorferi: Lyme disease
  • It is transmitted to humans through the bite of ticks.
  • Typical symptoms include fever, headache, fatigue, and a characteristic skin rash called Erythema migrans.

questions.text: A 30 years old male presented with discrete hypopigmented macules on his upper back. The patient works as a labourer in a steel mill. On examination of skin scrapings with 10% KOH under a microscope, spaghetti and meatball appearances were seen. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option

Option A:  Tinea versicolor

  • The given clinical and microscopic findings are characteristic of Tinea versicolor.
  • Tinea versicolor is caused by Malassezia furfur.
  • It infects people in hot and humid environments or those who sweat easily.
  •  Malassezia furfur is round in shape and produces filaments that give it a characteristic spaghetti and meatball appearance under the microscope.
  • The yeast-like fungus produces azelaic acid, which causes hypopigmentation of the skin.
  • Examination under Wood’s lamp shows yellow fluorescence produced by the yeast.

Other Options

Option B: Tinea corporis

  • Tinea corporis is caused by dermatophytes.
  • It causes enlarging raised red rings with a central area of clearing on the body.
  • Examination of the infected tissue shows characteristic hyphae formed by the causative fungus species.
  • Tinea corporis can be treated with topical azoles or oral terbinafine.

Option C: Mixed mycotic infections

  • Mixed mycotic functions cause several different symptoms and involve different body areas.
  • It may cause systemic symptoms as well.
  • The microscopic examination of the affected tissue shows multiple different shapes and color colonies.
  • Mixed mycotic infections are not the cause of hypopigmentation in this patient.

Option D: Candidiasis only

  • Candidiasis causes infection of the skin and mucosal tissues.
  • Cutaneous lesions caused by candidiasis are found in the intertriginous areas and under the nails.
  • Candidiasis causes erythematous, scaling or moist lesions with sharply demarcated borders. Papular lesions are most common in candidiasis.
  • Mucosal lesions include oral thrush and vaginitis.
  • Gram-stained smears from lesions show budding gram-positive cells.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male from a rural village with a history of swimming in the pond presents to the physician with complaints of fever, headache, confusion and vomiting. On further examination, the physician suspected a parasitic infection. He sent the sample for culture to identify the causative organism. Which selective medium is most likely to be used for isolating the organism in this case?

choices.text: Nutrient agar rich with E. coli

questions.solution:
Option C: Non-Nutrient agar with E. Coli

  • This is a case of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, headache, confusion and vomiting.
  • The typical history of swimming in pond points towards Naegleria fowleri.
  • The selective medium for Naegleria fowleri is non-nutrient agar with E. coli.
  • CSF sample can be cultivated on non-nutrient agar (Page's saline and 1.5% agar), lawn cultured with E. coli.
  • Naegleria feeds on bacteria and crawls over the lawn culture of E. coli to produce trails.
  • CSF examination:
  • Trophozoites of N. fowleri are seen
  • Neutrophils present

Option A: Nutrient agar rich with E. Coli

  • The nutrient agar rich in E. Coli is not used as a selective medium for Naegleria fowleri; only non-nutrient agar rich with E.coli is selective.

Option B: Novy-MacNeal-Nicolle media

  • NNN (Novy-MacNeal-Nicolle) Media is used for the culture of Leishmania and Trypanosoma.

Option D: Diamond Media

  • Diamond media (Axenic culture) is used to isolate Trichomonas and Entamoeba histolytica.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to OPD with a complaint of abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting for the last two days. She also reports headaches, insomnia and generalised weakness. His examination reveals a high blood pressure of 160/110mmHg with a pulse rate of 90 beats per minute. On examination, hepatomegaly is noticed. Additionally, her vitamin B-12 levels are low. The clinical diagnosis of malignant hydatid disease is made. Which of the following is true about malignant hydatid disease in the patient?

choices.text: Hydatid disease in the immunocompromised host

questions.solution:
Option B: Infection with E. multilocularis

  • The scenario is hydatid disease, in which there is abdominal pain and hepatomegaly. Hydatid disease is an infection with Echinococcus multilocularis.
  • The liver is the most common organ affected (98% of cases).
  • The disease may resemble a slowly growing carcinoma and cause intrahepatic portal hypertension symptoms.
  • Hepatomegaly and hypertension are seen.
  • The cyst appears as a solid, firm mass with an irregular outer layer and can migrate rapidly to other organs to mimic a malignant tumour.
  • Man is an accidental intermediate host.
  • Definitive agent- Foxes and wolves (and also dogs and cats).
  • Intermediate hosts- Small wild rodents like squirrels, voles, mice, etc.
  • This disease is found in Russia, Kazakhstan, China, etc.

Option A: Malignant changes into hydatid cyst

  • There are no malignant changes in hydatid disease.
  • Humans are not included in the parasitic life cycle of Echinococcus granulosus.

Option C: Hydatid disease in the immunocompromised host

  • The scenario mentioned above is hydatid disease.
  • Cystic and alveolar echinococcosis occurs in the immunocompromised host.

Option D: Caused by Echinococcus granulosus

  • Hydatid disease is an infection with Echinococcus multilocularis.
  • Cystic Echinococcosis (C.E.), also known as hydatid disease, is caused by infection with the larval stage of Echinococcus granulosus.

questions.text: A 5-month-old child is brought to the hospital by his mother with complaints of recurrent diarrhoea and fever. She is worried about admitting her child again this month. On complete physical examination, the baby has a whitish plaque in the mouth, and diaper area rashes look like a fungal infection. The patient is advised to go for molecular genetic testing and the results of which showed an Adenosine deaminase (ADA) enzyme deficiency. This deficiency is associated with which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)

  • Adenosine deaminase (enzyme) deficiency is associated with Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).
  • Defect in common gamma chain of IL2 receptor.
  • Defect in receptors of interleukins 4, 7 and 9.
  • 2nd Most common defect is Adenosine deaminase deficiency.
  • Rag 1 & Rag 2 genes defect total absence of T and B cells.
  • Deficiency of PNP (purine nucleoside phosphorylase).
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency is a rare disorder characterized by the defective functioning of B and T cells.
  • An individual is normal at birth, but they fail to thrive as age increases.
  • The patient suffers from different recurrent infections, including viral, bacterial and fungal.
  • Treatment is by bone marrow transplant, IV immunoglobulin and PCP prophylaxis. Usually fatal if untreated.

Option B: X-linked agammaglobulinemia

  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA)/ Bruton's agammaglobulinemia
  • Defect in B tyrosine Kinase gene: blocks B cell maturation.
  • Decrease immunoglobulins of all classes.
  • Normal Cell-mediated immunity.
  • Up to 6 months of neonatal life, nothing happens due to maternal Antibodies. After that, severe infections occur.

Option C: Transient Hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy

  • There is delayed onset of normal IgG synthesis,
  • It’s a self-limiting condition.

Option D: Chronic granulomatous disease

  • X-linked recessive defect in NADPH oxidase, resulting in an inability to form reactive oxygen compounds and decreased respiratory burst used to kill certain ingested pathogens.
  • Affected individuals will be more susceptible to catalase-positive organisms.
  • Nitro Blue Tetrazolium test → Negative

questions.text: In which phase of bacterial growth does sporulation occur?
questions.solution:
Option C: Stationary phase

  • Spores are formed in the stationary phase.

Spores:

  • Highly resistant resting Forms.

Spore-forming Bacteria:

  • B → Bacillus anthracis.
  • S → Sporosarcina.
  • C → Clostridium.
    • Drum stick appearance is seen in Clostridium tetani.
    • Most Clostridia have sub-terminal spores.
    • Central spore has been seen in Clostridium bifermentans.

Stationary phase

  • The stationary phase is usually due to a growth-limiting factor, such as the derivation of an essential nutrient, and the formation of an inhibitory product, such as an organic acid.
  • The stationary phase results from a situation where growth and death rates are the same.
  • The new cells created are limited by the growth factor, and as a result, the cell growth rate synchronizes with the death rate of the cell.
  • The curve's smooth, horizontal linear part results during the stationary phase.
  • Mutations can be during the stationary phase. Endogenously generated reactive oxygen species are a significant source of such damage.

Option  A: Decline phase

  • Decline or death phase of bacteria.
  • Bacteria die; it could be due to lack of nutrients, environmental temperature above or below the tolerance band for the species, or other damaging conditions.

Option B: Lag phase

  • In this phase, bacteria adapt to the growth conditions. It is the period, individual bacteria are maturing and unable to divide. Synthesis of enzymes, RNA, and other molecules occurs during the bacterial growth cycle lag phase.
  • In this phase, cell changes are minor because the cells do not reproduce immediately in a new medium.
  • This little to no cell division period is called the lag phase and can last 1 hour to several days. During this phase, cells are not dormant.

Option D: Log phase

  •  The period of growth of a population of cells (as of a microorganism) in a culture medium during which numbers increase exponentially and is represented by a part of the growth curve that is a straight line segment if the logarithm of numbers is plotted against time.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge, and bilateral nasal blockage for one year. She has had a history of asthma and allergy since childhood. On examination, multiple ethmoidal polyps are noted with mucosal thickening and secretions are impacted in both nasal cavities. A biopsy is taken, and the material is cultured, which shows the growth of many hyphae with dichotomous branching, typically at 45 degrees. Which of the following is the most likely responsible organism for causing the disease?
questions.solution:
Option A: Aspergillus fumigatus

  • The most likely responsible organism is Aspergillus fumigatus.
  • Key points towards diagnosis:
    • Recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge, bilateral nasal blockade.
    • History of asthma and allergy
    • Hyphae with dichotomous branching at 45 degree

  • All symptoms point towards Aspergillus infection.
  • It is the most common type of fungal infection of the nose, and paranasal sinuses due to Aspergillus.
  • Aspergillus has septate hyphae that branch typically at 45 degrees (V-shaped).
  • Hyphae with dichotomous branching at 45 degrees

 

Option B: Rhizopus

  • Broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide-angle branching are seen in members of Zygomycetes. i.e. Rhizopus.
  • Rhizopus is a fungus that can cause systemic mucormycosis.
  • This can exist in multiple forms like Rhinocerebral mucormycosis, disseminated, pulmonary, dermal, and cutaneous.
  • Rhinocerebral zygomycosis is a serious fulminating infection, angioinvasive, thrombosis, and ischaemic tissue necrosis.

Option C: Mucor

  • Broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide-angle branching are seen in members of Zygomycetes. i.e. Mucor
  • Mucormycosis (previously called Zygomycosis) is serious fulminant sinusitis but a rare fungal infection caused by a group of moulds called Mucormycetes
  • Treatment is by the combination of anti-fungal therapy, surgical debridement, and elimination of predisposing factors.

Option D: Candida

  • Candida: Gram-positive oval budding yeast cell with pseudohyphae.
  • It is a normal commensal of the oral cavity, gut, and vagina.
  • It causes problems only if the immunity is decreased or normal skin or mucous membrane is breached.

questions.text: As part of the autopsy of the body of a young man, the doctor had an X-ray done to determine the ossification status of the bone to narrow down on the age. The following image was the x-ray of the hip joint done postmortem. He notices that the center for the head, greater and lesser trochanter of the femur appeared but has not fused. The triradiate cartilage has not obliterated. Which age range will the doctor interpret the victim to be of, on viewing below X-Ray?
questions.solution:
Option B : Less than 15 years

  • Here in question, center for the head, greater and lesser trochanter of femur appeared but not fused; triradiate cartilage not obliterated. So the age is more than 11 years and less than 15 years.

questions.text: A Person was admitted with diarrhoea, vomiting, low-grade fever, breathlessness, abdominal and lower limb pain and later became semiconscious, cyanotic, tachypneic, tachycardic and hypotensive and died. Autopsy finding revealed inflamed intestines with "rice-water" like contents and "red-velvety appearance" stomach mucosa. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Option A: Arsenic poisoning

  • Gastrointestinal congestion is a feature of acute arsenic poisoning.
  • Focal hemorrhages giving rise to a flea-bitten appearance are said to be characteristic. Intestines may be inflamed and may contain “rice water” contents.

Option B: Sulphuric acid poisoning

  • Sulphuric acid poisoning: Colorless, Odorless, Non-fuming.
  • Signs & symptoms: Brown to black streak from the angle of mouth, Black tongue, Chalky white teeth, Black necrotic stomach or black charred stomach, Blotting paper stomach, Gastric perforation, The mind remains clear until death.
  • Fatal dose: 5-10 ml, Fatal period: 12-24 hours.
  • Sulphuric acid is the most common substance associated with vitriolage.

Option C: Phosphorus poisoning

  • Signs and Symptoms of acute phosphorus poisoning:
    • Garlicky odor, Luminous vomit and stool because of the presence of phosphorus.
    • Fumes emanate from the stools (smoking or smoky stool syndrome). Acute poisoning causes liver cell necrosis, fatty liver, and acute yellow atrophy.
  • Chronic Phosphorus Poisoning (Phossy Jaw/Glass Jaw/Lucifer’s Jaw):
    • Due to inhalation of fumes over years. Toothache (earliest symptom) & swelling of the jaw; Loosening of the teeth & Necrosis of the lower jaw. Sequestration of bone in the mandible & multiple sinuses discharging foul-smelling pus.

Option D: Viper snake bite

  • Viper snake bite leaves one, two, or three puncture marks on the skin, but you won't always see any marks.
  • Symptoms of a pit viper snakebite usually appear within a few minutes to a few hours after a bite and may include: Severe, immediate pain with rapid swelling, Bruising of the skin, Trouble breathing, Changes in heart rate or rhythm.

questions.text: The derivatives of the cannabis plant are known by many names – marijuana, weed, pot, ganja, charas, hashish, and more. They have a socio-religious association in India dating back hundreds of years, but never before have cannabis products been under so much scrutiny as they are now. The arrest of a Bollywood actress (now out on bail) by the NCB in the drug case related to another Actor's death has led to a larger debate. Which among the following is the active component of Ganja?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tetrahydrocannabinol:

  • Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) is the principal psychoactive constituent of cannabis.
  • It is used in the following forms: Bhang, Marijuana, Ganja, and Charas or hashish.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - LSD:

  • Lysergic Acid Diethylamide (LSD): LSD presumably produces its effects by an action on the 5-HT levels in the brain. Although tolerance and psychological dependence occur with LSD use, no physical dependence or withdrawal syndrome is seen. A common pattern of LSD use is trip (occasional use followed by a long period of abstinence).

Option C - Ethyl alcohol:

  • Ethanol (ethyl alcohol) acts mainly on the CNS. It acts as a depressant of specialized and sensitive cells of cerebral cortex (centers regulating conduct, judgment and self-criticism) with release of inhibitory tone, leading to unrestrained behavior. This is followed by depression of vital centers of medulla producing coma and death. Alcohol also acts as a hypnotic, diaphoretic, and in small doses as an appetizer.

Option D - N-Methyl tryptophan:

  • It is not an active component of Ganja

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has died during childbirth. The family of the deceased claim that the negligence of the doctor led to her death. A case has been filed against the doctor in court. Which of the following is guaranteed by the defence lawyer for the defendant as not constituting negligence?

choices.text: He has exercised reasonable care and skill
He has not obtained informed consent from patient
He fails to give proper instructions
Others suffer the disease from his patient

questions.solution:
Option A: He has exercised reasonable care and skill

  • The defendant's lawyer assures him that he will not be held guilty of negligence if he has exercised reasonable care and skill.
  • Medical Negligence: Simply a failure to exercise reasonable care and skill.

Option B: He has not obtained informed consent from patient

  • If the doctor has not obtained informed consent from the patient, he will be held guilty of negligence and arrested under medical negligence case.

Option C: He fails to give proper instructions

  • If the doctor fails to give proper instructions, he will be held guilty of negligence and arrested under medical negligence case.

Option D: Others suffer the disease from his patient

  • If the doctor let others suffer the disease from his patient, he will be held guilty of negligence and arrested under medical negligence case.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman has consulted the doctor to abort her 10-week-old fetus. The woman allegedly has been harassed by her in-laws and is not willing to continue with the pregnancy. The husband and his parents are threatening the doctor to not proceed with the abortion. According to the MTP Act of 1971, consent from whom is needed by the doctor to legally proceed with the abortion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - pregnant women:

  • Only the consent of the pregnant woman is necessary.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Guardian:

  • For a minor or insane person – consent from a guardian is required.

Option C - Pregnant women and husband:

  • Only the consent of the pregnant woman is necessary.
  • Consent from the husband is not necessary.

Option D - Husband of the lady:

  • Consent from husband- not necessary.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male was found unconscious under the tree and was brought to the emergency department where he regained consciousness. He said that he had taken shelter under a tree during a storm. He also said that he remembered nothing after the sound of the lightning. His arterial BP was 135/70 mmHg, his pulse was 80 per minute, and his fingertip O2 saturation was 98%. The results of a neurological examination were normal and his GCS score was 15. His hearing and the tympanic membrane are normal. There were significant Lichtenberg figures on the patient's back, extending over the right scapula. These characteristic burns are also known as?
questions.solution:
Option D: Filigree burn

  • Filigree burns or Arborescent or fern-like injury or Lichtenberg figure occurs when an individual struck by the negative lightning bolt is then hit by a secondary positive flashover from a nearby grounded object.

Option A: Crocodile flash burn

  • Crocodile flash burns: Multiple burnt or punched-out lesions are produced due to the air dancing over the body surface over large areas.

Option B: Adipocere
