  • Adipocere is a variation of putrefaction. It is seen most commonly in bodies immersed in water or in damp, warm environments.
  • In adipocere, fat undergoes hydrolysis to the free fatty acids by virtue of bacterial enzymes and endogenous lipases.

Option C: Lightning tattoo

  • Mummification: Another modified form of putrefaction, where drying and desiccation of the tissues occur instead of liquefaction, depending upon the conditions prevalent at the terminal stages.

questions.text: A 22-month-old female child was reported to the hospital with a chief complaint of swelling on the left cheek region. There was a history of traumatic injury while eating sugarcane twenty-four hours back. On examination, extraoral swelling was present in the left cheek region. A clinical diagnosis of herniation of the buccal fat pad was made. The necrotic mass was surgically excised under local anesthesia, and healthy tissue was repositioned, followed by primary closure using a 4-0 vicryl suture, as shown in the image. Which of the following is related to this suture material?

choices.text: Tensile strength is maintained for 8-10 days

questions.solution:
Option C: Delayed absorbable suture

  • Vicryl(polyglactin) is also known as the work-horse suture of a general surgeon. 
  • Vicryl is a synthetic absorbable sterile surgical suture composed of a co-polymer made from 90% glycolide and 10% L-lactide. 
  • It retains tensile strength of about 70% and is maintained for 28-30 days, it completely absorbs within 56-70 days (delayed absorbable suture) by a simple hydrolytic mechanism, and its absorption is predictable. 
  • It is violet in color and used in organs with an increased risk of stone formation, such as the common bile duct, ureter, and bladder.

Option A: Tensile strength is maintained for 8-10 days

  • The tensile strength of Vicryl is maintained for 56-70 days, not for 8-10 days.

Option B: Co-polymer of glycolide and caprolactone

  • Vicryl is a co-polymer of glycolide and L-lactide, not caprolactone.

Option D: Used in Whipple's procedures

  • Vicryl is not used in Whipple's procedures.

questions.text: 26 years old Ramesh, who is a painter visits the infertility clinic with his wife as they couldn’t conceive even after trying for the last 2 years. His semen analysis showed oligospermia. Which of the following metal can be obtained from his blood sample?
questions.solution:
Option B: Lead

  • In the given case scenario, as the person is working in the fuel industry, he would have occupational exposure to lead, which damages testes, resulting in oligospermia.
  • Thus, Lead can be obtained from his blood & urine samples.

Option A: Cadmium

  • It causes 'Itai - Itai' disease.
  • Teeth: Golden yellow staining.
  • Proximal tubular necrosis, emphysema, and anemia.
  • Osteomalacia, bone pain, and pathological fractures.

Option C: Mercury

  • In mercury poisoning, we can see black blue lines of gums, intentional tremors (hatters shaking palsy); erethism; acrodynia or pinks disease, mercuria lentis, minimata disease; membranous glomerulopathy.
  • TEST: If a piece of copper wire is introduced into the solution and a few drops of hydrochloric acid are added, a silver coating of mercury will be formed on the wire.

Option D: Nickle

  • The symptoms of nickel poisoning: Headache, Nausea, Vomiting, Dizziness, Irritability, and Difficulty Sleeping.
  • The second group of symptoms will become more severe after a few days: Chest Pains, Sweating, Rapid Heart Beat, and Dry Cough. These symptoms are similar to pneumonia but may be fatal in the case of nickel poisoning

questions.text: A patient from a rural village presented to the PHC with a sore throat, fever, stiffness in the neck, and pain in the lower limbs. The condition was diagnosed as poliomyelitis. Under AFP Surveillance, For residual paralysis when is a follow-up examination done?
questions.solution:
Option C: 60 days of onset of paralysis

  • Under AFP Surveillance, For residual paralysis: Follow-up after 60 days of onset of paralysis is done.
  • Transported in the reverse cold chain (+2 to + 8°C):
    • Follow up after 60 days of onset of paralysis.
    • Confirmation of polio should be done within 90 days.
  • Acute fluid paralysis is seen in Poliomyelitis:
    • AFP surveillance done at 0-15 yrs. Age group in India, done by surveillance medical officer.
    • 2 stool specimens are collected from suspected individuals 24-48 hr apart.
    • Each sample should be 8 gm (adult thumb size).

Other options are incorrect

questions.text: A 29-year-old drug addict presented to the hospital with fever, extreme weight loss, rashes, night sweats and swollen lymph nodes. Blood reports detected him to be HIV positive. Which of the following is the least efficient mode of HIV transmission?
questions.solution:
Sexual

  • Sexual transmission is the least efficient mode (0.01-1%) of HIV transmission.

Blood and blood products

  • Blood and blood products: >90% (most efficient mode).

Needles/ syringes

  • Efficiency of the route for Needles/ syringes in HIV transmission is 0.3%.

Mother to child transmission

  • Efficiency of the route in Mother to child transmission is 30%.

Learning Objective

HIV transmission in India:

Route of transmission Percentage of total cases Efficiency of route
Sexual 90 (most common mode) 0.01-1% (least efficient)
Blood and blood products 1 (least common mode) >90% (most efficient mode)
Sharing needles/syringes 2 0.3%
Mother to child transmission 4 30%

questions.text: A patient from rural India presented to the OPD with fever, severe joint pain, headache, joint swelling and rash. The clinical diagnosis of chikungunya was made by the physician. Which of the following is the reservoir of chikungunya fever in India?
questions.solution:
Primates

  • Aedes aegypti primarily, Aedes mosquitoes are easily distinguished by white stripes on a black body. Because of the striped or banded character of their legs they are sometimes referred to as 'tiger mosquitoes". Important members of this group of mosquitoes are: Aedes aegypti, Aedes uittatus, and Aedes albopictus. Aedes mosquitoes are most abundant during rainy season. Also, Culex and Mansonia transmit Chikungunya.
  • Reservoirs are Primates.

Rodents

  • Endemic typhus: Also known as Flea-borne typhus/murine typhus.
  • Causative agent: Rickettsia typhi
  • Vector: Rat flea
  • Weil felix reaction becomes +ve in: 2nd week

Aedes

  • Yellow fever is a zoonotic disease caused by an arbovirus. It affects principally monkeys and other vertebrates in tropical America and Africa and is transmitted lo man by certain culicine mosquitoes. It shares clinical features with other viral hemorrhagic fevers and albuminuria or anuria, shock, agitation, stupor and coma. In general, death occurs between the fifth and tenth day of illness. The case fatality rate may reach 80 per cent in severe cases.
  • Reservoir is Aedes mosquito.

Man

  • It is a type of rickettsial disease of typhus group:
    • Recrudescent form of Epidemic typhus: Brill Zinsser Disease
    • Was the ‘most formidable rickettsial disease in past.
  • Causative agent: R. prowazekii
  • Vector: Louse (P. capitis, P. corporis)
  • Clinical picture: Prolonged febrile illness, vasculitis
  • Drug of choice: Tetracycline
  • Reservoir is humans

Learning Objective

Reservoirs of important disease:

Disease Reservoir
Epidemic typhus Humans
Endemic typhus Rats
Scrub typhus Rats
Trench fever Humans
Q fever Humans
Ascariasis Humans
Ancylostomiasis Humans
Dengue Humans, aedes
Chikungunya Primates
Yellow fever Humans, Aedes, Monkeys

questions.text: A two-year-old unimmunized child presents to a primary health centre with fever for 5 days. Mother also gives a history of rash starting behind ear-pinna a day before coming to OPD. On examination, the child is having a runny nose and congested eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Measles

  • The symptoms mentioned above point toward the diagnosis of Measles.
  • The pathognomic clinical feature of measles is the Koplik spot [opposite to lower 2nd molar].
  • The clinical features include the retro-auricular origin of the rash, fever, diarrhea, conjunctivitis, coryza, and pneumonia.
  • Vaccine: Live attenuated (Edmonston Zagreb strain).

Option A: Rubella

  • The causative organism for rubella is RNA Togavirus.
  • The incubation period is 14-21 days. Cases are the source of infection in Rubella.
  • No carriers and no iceberg phenomenon are seen in Rubella.
  • The Mode of transmission is Respiratory/air droplets, vertical transmission from mother to child.

Option B: Mumps

  • The causative agent for mumps is Myxovirus parotitis.
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks. Cases are the source of infection in mumps.
  • The Mode of transmission is Respiratory/air droplets.
  • The most common complication of mumps is Aseptic meningitis.
  • Complications in children: Aseptic meningitis
  • Complications in Adolescents males: Orchitis, Adolescents Females: Oophoritis
  • Complications in Adults: Meningoencephalitis.

Option D: Chickenpox

  • Chickenpox is caused by HHV-3 [Varicella Zoster]
  • The incubation period of chickenpox is 14-16 days. Cases are the source of infection.
  • The mode of transmission of chickenpox is respiratory/ air droplets.
  • The period of communicability of Chickenpox is 1-2 days before the appearance of the rash till 5 days afterward.
  • The rash in chickenpox is superficial, unilocular, centripetal, and pleomorphic, showing a due drop in rose petal appearance affecting flexor aspects and axilla.
  • Late complication: Shingles by recrudescence.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male visited to the hospital for permanent sterilization operation. The physician explained him about vasectomy method. Which of the following is not true regarding ‘no scalpel’ vasectomy?

choices.text: Special instruments are used to deliver the vas instead of cutting the skin
Scrotal skin is cut with LASER to expose the vas
The failure rate is the same as that of conventional vasectomy
It is a very popular method in China

questions.solution:
Scrotal skin is cut with LASER to expose the vas- False statement

  • No scalpel vasectomy is a vasectomy procedure variant in which a sharp hemostat is used to puncture the scrotum to access the vas deferens instead of giving an incision as in conventional vasectomy.
  • All other options (Option A, C, and D) are true statements regarding no-scalpel vasectomy.

Learning Objective

  • No scalpel vasectomy (also called keyhole vasectomy or NSV) is a vasectomy procedure variant in which a sharp hemostat is used to puncture the scrotum to access the vas deferens instead of giving an incision as in conventional vasectomy.
  • No cuts are made in no-scalpel vasectomy, but the skin is punctured.
  • The failure rate is the same as that of conventional vasectomy.
  • It is a very popular method in China.
  • It is a daycare procedure.
  • No stitches are made.

  • The NSV approach offers several benefits, including a lower risk for infection, bleeding, bruising, and pain.
  • No scalpel vasectomy and conventional vasectomy are equally effective.
  • Steps of no-scalpel vasectomy: By using the three-finger method on both sides, the vas deferens are isolated. Midway between the top of the testicles and the base of the penis is the best location for needle insertion. The vas is isolated and encircled with the ringed clamp. The scrotal skin is punctured, the tissues are spread out, and the vas deferens are pierced to deliver it outside the scrotum using the dissecting forceps. The vas deferens is subsequently blocked.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presented to the hospital for consulting the female about IUCD insertion. Which of the following is the absolute contraindication of IUCD insertion?

choices.text: Genital herpes with severe non-purulent discharge

questions.solution:
Correct Answer Option B: Pelvic tuberculosis

  • Pelvic tuberculosis is an absolute contraindication for IUD insertion.
  • Because of ongoing inflammation.

Other Options-

Option A: Genital herpes with severe non-purulent discharge

  • The case discussed the absolute contraindication of IUD insertion. Genital discharge is a relative contraindication for IUD insertion.

Option C: AIDS on ARV therapy

  • AIDS on ARV therapy is not an absolute contraindication for IUD insertion. Medical practitioners must use appropriate caution.

Option D: Recto-vaginal fistula

  • A relative contraindication is a rectovaginal fistula. Due to their medical condition, the patient in this instance must undergo surgery before continuing with IUD insertion.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with persistent cough for 3 weeks, fever, night sweats and extreme weight loss is diagnosed with tuberculosis infection. ASHA worker visited him and gave him DOTS therapy. What is the role of ASHA in DOTS therapy?
questions.solution:
DOTS provider

  • ASHA is the central component of the national rural health mission (NRHM).

Responsibilities of ASHA worker:

  • Create awareness and mobilize a community for local health planning
  • Promote good health practices
  • Counsel women on RCH
  • Act as depot holder for essential medicines
  • Act as DOTS provider
  • Help develop a comprehensive village health plan
  • Accompany pregnant women and children to the nearest health facility
  • Be a part of JSY and help reduce MMR.

questions.text: The Alma Ata declaration created by WHO in 2000 aimed for health for all. All of the following provisions are included in Primary health care according to the Alma Ata declaration, except?

choices.text: Adequate supply of safe drinking water

questions.solution:
Option C: Financial aids

  • Provisions included under Primary Health Care according to the Alma Ata conference do not include the provision of Financial aids.

ALMA–ATA CONFERENCE

  • Called for WHO Goal of “Health for All” by 2000
  • India is a signatory

Other options

Option A: Adequate supply of safe drinking water

  • Adequate supply of safe drinking water is also a provision of primary health care.

Option B: Nutrition

  • Education about good health and nutrition is also a provision of primary health care.

Option D: Basic sanitation

  • It is also a function of primary health care.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male from rural village presented to the PHC complaining of blister formation and worms coming out of it, accompanied by fever. The condition was diagnosed as guinea worm disease. This condition is a common public health problem which is attributed to the use of?
questions.solution:
Step well

  • Guinea worm disease is quite a public health problem in areas where step wells are in use.

Step Wells:

  • STEP WELLS are a kind of pucca wells which are becoming obsolete, fortunately.
  • In these wells, there is considerable personal contact between the user and the water.
  • Steps are constructed into these wells to enable people to descend into the well to fetch water or quench their thirst.
  • Some people may even wash their faces, hands and feet which is a common Indian custom.
  • The open dug wells and step wells are a health hazard to the community.

Dug well

  • Most common well in India.
  • The unlined katcha well and the masonry or pucca well.
  • The katcha well is a hole dug into the water-bearing stratum.

Sanitary well

  • A sanitary well is one which is properly located, well constructed and protected against contamination with a view to yield a supply of safe water.

Artesian well

  • ARTESIAN WELLS are a kind of deep wells in which the water rises above the level of ground water, because it is held under
    pressure between two impervious strata.
  • Artesian wells are not common in India

questions.text: A 32-year-old vegetarian male presented to the OPD with pale skin, fatigue, and numbness. On examination, he was having vitamin deficiency for which only animal sources had to be consumed. Which of the following vitamins is deficient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Vitamin B12

  • A vegetarian male with pallor, fatigue, and numbness suggests the patient is having anemia with peripheral neuropathy, which is most likely due to B12 deficiency.
  • Vitamin B12/Cyanocobalamin is only obtainable through animal sources, therefore strict vegetarians develop B12 deficiency.

Option A: Vitamin B1

  • Since B12 only obtain through animal sources this patient is more likely to have B12 deficiency.
  • Thiamine deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy but anemia would be uncommon.
  • Given Strict vegetarian, B12 is the more likely answer.

Option B: Vitamin B2

  • Vitamin B2 deficiency can lead to angular stomatitis, cheilosis, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis.

Option D: Vitamin C

  • Vitamin C deficiency is also known as "scurvy" present with bleeding gums, petechiae, poor wound healing, and corkscrew hair.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presented to the hospital with a lump in her breast. On examination, there is the presence of a dimpling sign. Mammography was performed by the physician. Which of the following is a characteristic of a Diagnostic test as compared to a Screening test?

choices.text: Test results are arbitrary and final
Based on one criterion or cut-off point
Done on those with indications or sick

questions.solution:
Option D: Done on those with indications or sick

  • A diagnostic test is done on those with indications or who are sick. Whereas, a screening test is done on an apparently healthy individual.
  • Diagnostic test characteristics:
    • A diagnostic test's goal is to determine whether a disease is present (or absent) so that treatment choices can be made in cases when a person has symptoms or tests positive (confirmatory test).
    • When a patient has medical indications or is sick, this needs to be performed.

Other options

Option A: Test results are arbitrary and final

  • The results of a screening test are final and arbitrarily determined. 
  • Screening test characteristic:
    • The main goal of screening tests is to find early disease or risk factors for disease in a wide population of people who appear to be healthy.
    • The test's results are final and arbitrarily determined.
    • The outcomes are determined by a single criterion or cut-off point.

Option B: Based on one criterion or cut-off point

  • The screening test is based on one criterion or cut-off point.
  • The diagnostic test is based on the evaluation of a number of symptoms.

Option C: Less accurate

  • Compared to screening tests, diagnostic tests are more accurate.

questions.text: The ICD-11 catalogues known human diseases, medical conditions, and mental health disorders and is issued for insurance coding purposes, for statistical tracking of illnesses, and as a global health categorization tool that can be used across countries and in different languages. ICD -11 has 3 volumes plus 26 chapters. What does Volume 2 contain?
questions.solution:
Reference guide

  • Volume II contains a Reference Guide.

Tabulation list

  • Volume I - Tabulation List

Alphabetical index

  • Volume III- Alphabetical Index

Functional assessment

  • Chapter V - Functional Assessment

ICD-11 (International Classification of Diseases - 11th Edition, WHO)

  • Revised every 10 years, right now 11th edition.
  • Released in June 2018 and it contains 3 Volumes & 26 chapters along with chapters X and V.
    • Volume I - Tabulation List
    • Volume II - Reference Guide
    • Volume III- Alphabetical Index
  • Some important chapters to be remembered:
    • Chapter 6 - Mental behavior and Neurodevelopmental disorders.
    • Chapter 26 - Traditional Medicine
    • Chapter X - Extension codes
    • Chapter V - Functional Assessment

questions.text: A patient after 1 month of getting vaccinated presented to the hospital with muscle weakness, difficulty in swallowing, and a pricking needle sensation in the hands and feet. The diagnosis of Guillain Barre syndrome was made by the physician. Which of the following vaccine is most likely to cause this reaction?
questions.solution:
Option D: Killed Influenza Vaccine

  • The adverse effects of killed influenza vaccine include:
    •  Anaphylaxis
    • Guillain barre syndrome
    • Oculo-respiratory syndrome.

Option A: Pertussis

  • Hypotensive, hyporesponsive episode following immunization is seen mainly with DTP, rarely with other vaccines.
  • In the DPT vaccine, the pertussis component is mainly responsible for Hypotensive hypo responsive episodes (HHRE).
  • It can also result in persistent inconsolable crying.

Option B: Measles

  • The measles vaccine can cause reactions such as TSS, and febrile seizures.
  • The vaccination Schedule consists of 2 doses, 1st dose at 9 months and 2nd dose at 16-24 months.

Option C: Hepatitis B

  • Adverse effects of the Hep B vaccine include hypersensitivity, and shock.
  • Hepatitis B vaccine in newborns: 3 doses- (6, 10, 14 weeks) if the child is delivered at home or (0, 6, 14 weeks) if the child is delivered at an institute(Dose: 0.5 ml each).
  • Hepatitis B vaccine schedule for adults: 0,1,6 months. (dose: 1 ml each).

questions.text: A 25 years old female recently delivered a healthy baby in your hospital. You were the assistant doctor with your senior for the delivery. After successful delivery of the baby your senior asks you what is the ‘first immunization’ of the baby?

choices.text: Handing over the baby to mother

questions.solution:
Colostrum

  • Is the most suitable food immediately after birth of the baby; Regular milk comes 3-6 days after birth.
  • Aka ‘Beestings’, ‘First milk’ or ‘Immune Milk’.
  • High in carbohydrates, proteins, antibodies & low in fat.
  • Contain all five immunoglobulins found in all mammals, IgA (highest), IgD, IgE, IgG & IgM.
  • Known as ‘first immunization’ of newborn.

OPV

  • Oral Polio Vaccine / SABIN is a Bivalent vaccine (P1, P3 strain).
  • Dosage:
    • 1st dose given immediately at birth or as soon as possible, then at 6weeks followed by 10 and 14 weeks.
    • 1st booster: 16-24 m.
    • Another dose at 5 y along with DPT booster.

Handing over the baby to mother

  • Handing over the baby to mother is a wrong option.

DPT + BCG

  • 1st dose of DPT is give at 6 weeks after birth and 1st dose of BCG is given at the time of birth or as early as possible till one year of age.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a 3-month history of 10kg weight loss despite an increased appetite. She also complains of anxiety, diarrhoea and amenorrhea. Examination reveals a fine tremor, brisk reflexes and a systolic murmur heard throughout the precordium. A urine pregnancy screen was negative. What is the most likely finding in examining the pulse?
questions.solution:
Option C: Irregularly irregular pulse

  • Female, weight loss in spite of appetite, amenorrhea, tremors, brisk reflexes are features of Thyrotoxicosis
  • Thyrotoxicosis can be Associated with A. fibrillation.
  • So, irregularly irregular pulse can be presentation of Thyrotoxicosis.

Rhythm disorder characteristics

Rhythm

Causes

ECG Features

Atrial fibrillation

  • Mitral valve disorders
  • Myocardial infarction, hypertension, coronary artery disease, heart failure
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
  • Digoxin toxicity
  • Post cardiac surgery
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Electrolyte abnormalities
  • Venous thromboembolism
  • Obesity
  • Diabetes
  • Obstructive sleep apnoea
  • Pneumonia
  • Alcohol excess
  • Caffeine
  • QRS width: <120 milliseconds
  • Atrial rate is 350-400 beats per minute but ventricular rate is variable
  • Heart rate is irregular
  • Absent P-waves  

Atrial flutter

  • Underlying cardiac disorder, mitral or tricuspid  valve disease
  • Cor pulmonale
  • Post-myocardial infarction complication
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Excess alcohol
  • Post cardiac surgery
  • QRS width: <120 milliseconds
  • Atrial rate is 250-350 beats per minute, ventricular rate varies according to atrioventricular node conduction
  • Regular P-waves are typically absent with mainly flutter or saw tooth waves

Ventricular tachycardia

  • Acute myocardial infarction
  • Chronic ischaemia
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Electrolyte abnormalities
  • Congenital problems
  • Drugs (antiarrhythmic, digoxin)
  • Idiopathic/unknown
  • Regular rhythm
  • Wide QRS:>120 milliseconds
  • Monomorphic, with all QRS complexes being the same shape

Torsades de pointers

  • Amiodarone
  • Tricyclic antidepressants
  • Low magnesium or potassium
  • Congenital problems
  • Excess alcohol
  • Malnourishment
  • QT – Prolonging medications
  • Regular rhythm
  • Wide QRS: >120 milliseconds
  • Polymorphic, with varying shape and size QRS complexes

Option A: Pulsus paradoxus

  • Pulses Paradoxus is the feature of C. Tamponade.

Option B: Collapsing pulse

  • Rapidly rising pulse collapses suddenly as arterial pressure falls rapidly during late systole and diastole (Corrigan's pulse).
  • It Features aortic regurgitation & AR have a Diastolic murmur.

Option D: Pulsus alternans

  • Pulsus Alternans is feature of LVF

questions.text: A 45 years-old-male presents to the cardiac OPD with complaints of breathlessness, palpitations and disturbed sleep. He has a history of chronic alcohol intake and consumes about 450 ml of alcohol per day. Examination reveals a dicrotic pulse on palpation and pansystolic murmur on auscultation. This patient is prone to develop which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Option B: Dilated cardiomyopathy

  • Binge drinking in alcoholic leads to Holiday Heart Syndrome, which might cause sudden Cardiac Death (SCD)
  • Atrial fibrillation can be seen due to a change in the shape of the heart.
  • The most common cause of DCM is Alcohol.
  • Alcoholic cardiomyopathy, which is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy, is a condition in which the shape of your heart changes as a result of the muscles of your heart stretching too much. 
  • The muscles get weaker as they continue to stretch further and further. This type of stretching can be particularly problematic for the muscles that control the lower chambers of the heart, specifically the left and right ventricles. These chambers are responsible for the majority of the work that the heart does. 
  • The right ventricle is involved in pumping blood to the lungs, while the left ventricle is involved in pumping blood to the rest of your body. If the muscles that surround the ventricles get weaker, the ventricles will be unable to pump as forcefully, which will have a severe impact on the rest of the body.
  • Examination findings of Dilated cardiomyopathy include:
    • Dicrotic pulse
    • Pan systolic murmur along with features of biventricular failure
    • Third heart sound present
    • B/L fine crepitation present
    • Hypokinetic, diffuse, laterally displaced impulse

Option A: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

  • Familial HOCM is an Autosomal dominant Mendelian inherited disease in approximately 50% of cases.
  • MC gene involved is β-myosin heavy chain > Myosin-binding protein C > Troponin T.
  • Clinical features of HOCM
    • Dyspnea (earliest symptoms) due to Diastolic malfunction (due to small LV cavity), Pooling of blood in lungs, Pulmonary Oedema present
    • Chest pain on exertion: Sub. Endocardial Ischemia
    • Effort intolerance
    • Sudden collapse or death on exercise/ running due to Ischemic ventricular fibrillation, Twitching, Loss of Pulse / BP, Sustained arrhythmias (Atrial Fibrillation)

Option C: Pericarditis

  • Pericarditis is the inflammation of the pericardium due to an infectious or non-infectious cause.
  • Chest pain is the most common symptom.
  • Pain behind the breast bone on the left side, which spread to the left shoulder and neck.

Option D: Mitral valve prolapse

  • Mid systolic clicks (Due to extra tension generated in the chordae tendineae during exercise) and late systolic murmur (d/t leakage of blood into the Left atrium) are seen in mitral valve prolapse.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of dizziness and weakness early in the morning when getting up from bed. She has been a known case of diabetes mellitus for the past 14 years and has a 10-pack-year smoking history. She had 3 uncomplicated cesarean sections previously. General physical examination is unremarkable. Neurologic examination shows decreased sensation in the feet and hands bilaterally. Her blood pressure is 130/90mmHg in sitting position and 100/70mmHg after standing. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Midodrine

  • Diabetic neuropathy is a microvascular complication of diabetes mellitus.
    • In Peripheral neuropathy, there is a stocking and glove pattern of numbness and paresthesias.
    • Loss of sensation leads to ulcer formation with ischemia and Charcot's joints.
    • Cranial nerve complications can also occur, e.g. diabetic third nerve palsy.
    • Mononeuropathies such as median nerve and ulnar nerve neuropathies are also common.
    • Diabetic truncal neuropathy causes pain in the distribution of any intercostal nerve.
    • Diabetic foot is a combination of artery disease (ischemia) and neuropathy leading to infected ulcer formation, which may require amputation.
  • People who have long-standing diabetes mellitus can develop autonomic instability due to neuropathy.
  • It can affect any autonomic system function, such as blood pressure, heart rate, gastrointestinal motility, bladder function and erectile dysfunction. Each abnormality has its specific treatment.
  • When a patient develops orthostatic hypotension due to autonomic neuropathy of diabetes, it can be managed as:
    • Non-pharmacological measures include Jobst-fitted stockings, tilting the head of the bed and arising slowly from the lying position.
    • Pharmacotherapies that can be used to manage orthostatic hypotension are:
      • Fludrocortisone: When non-pharmacological measures are inadequate, treatment with oral fludrocortisone 0.1–0.2 mg/kg daily can be considered to help with orthostatic hypotension. This medication can result in supine hypertension and hypokalemia.
      • Phenylephrine is an alpha sympathomimetic drug with more alpha-1 activity than alpha-2. It causes vasoconstriction and raises blood pressure. So, it can be used to treat orthostatic hypotension. Phenylephrine is also used in eye procedures as a mydriatic, rhinitis as a decongestant and ischemic priapism.
      • Midodrine: Midodrine is a selective alpha-1 agonist, given 10mg/kg 3 times a day, which elevates blood pressure by vasoconstriction. It is an effective drug in autonomic insufficiency and postural hypotension.

Option A: Dopamine/Dobutamine

  • Dopamine increases renal blood flow at lower doses and acts as a beta-1 agonist at moderate doses to increase heart rate. At high doses, it raises blood pressure. It can be given in septic shock.
  • Dobutamine is a beta-1 and beta-2 agonist with mild alpha-agonist activity. It can be given in heart failure and cardiogenic shock.

Option B: Isoproterenol

  • It is a sympathomimetic with non-specific beta-agonist activity. It causes vasodilation and increases the heart rate. So it can not be given to treat orthostatic hypotension.

 

Option C: Clonidine

  • Clonidine is an alpha-2 agonist used in hypertensive urgency. It is not used for orthostatic hypotension as it lowers blood pressure.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought to the paediatrician by her mother with complaints of delayed growth. The mother also reports that the child complains of backache and leg pain. On examination, his legs appear bent, and he has a waddling gait. He is at the 10th percentile for length,15th percentile for weight, and 50th percentile for head circumference. Lab investigations show a standard metabolic profile, with normal calcium, phosphorus, 25-hydroxyvitamin D, and parathyroid hormone levels. However, the serum ALP level is low. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Hypophosphatasia

  • The disease is caused by a deficiency of tissue nonspecific (bone/liver/kidney) alkaline phosphatase (TNSALP)
  • Defective Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) permits the accumulation of its major naturally occurring substrates, including phosphoethanolamine (PEA), inorganic pyrophosphate (PPi), and pyridoxal 5′-phosphate (PLP).
  • The accumulation of PPi interferes with mineralisation through its action as a potent inhibitor of hydroxyapatite crystal growth.
  • Hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria are common.
  • Because of the large number of described mutations in the TNSALP gene and variable clinical expression, the disease severity varies widely. It has the following joint presentation depending upon the age of the patient:
  • During the perinatal period, it is lethal.
  • During infancy, the initial development appears normal; however, rachitic deformities develop by age six months, and approximately 50 % of affected patients die during infancy.
  • It presents premature loss of deciduous teeth, delayed walking, and shuffling gait during childhood. The Symptoms may improve spontaneously after puberty and recur later in life.
  •  During adulthood, it is most commonly characterised by poorly healing, recurrent metatarsal stress fractures, and bone pain (thighs and hips).

Management

  • The treatment is usually supportive.
  • A low-calcium diet, glucocorticoids, and calcitonin have been used in a small number of patients with variable responses. Because fracture healing is poor intramedullary rods may be used.
  • In 2015, asfotase alfa, a nonspecific tissue ALP was approved as enzyme replacement therapy for perinatal/infantile- and juvenile-onset forms

Option A: Hypoparathyroidism

  • The most common aetiology of hypoparathyroidism is the autoimmune or surgical destruction of parathyroid glands. The other causes include abnormal parathyroid gland development, altered regulation of parathyroid hormone (PTH), and impaired PTH action on end organs.
  • It results in hypocalcemia and triggers various symptoms, such as muscle cramps, seizures, and heart failure.
  • Laboratory findings include hypocalcemia with low or inappropriately normal PTH and hyperphosphatemia with normal renal function.

Option C: Hyperparathyroidism

  • Hyperparathyroidism (HPT) is characterised by abnormally high parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels in the blood due to overactivity of the parathyroid glands.
  • Its clinical presentation ranges from asymptomatic to bone pain, gastric ulcers, and kidney stones.
  • Hyperparathyroidism (HPT) is characterised by elevated parathyroid hormone and ALP levels.

Option D: Pseudopseudo-hypoparathyroidism

  • It is a rare condition due to defective Gs protein α subunit inherited from the father (GNAS gene imprinting).
  • However, because of the mother's normal allele, there is no end-organ resistance to PTH.
  • The clinical features include Albright hereditary osteodystrophy (round face, short stature, obesity, brachydactyly of the 4th and 5th fingers, intellectual disability, and subcutaneous ossifications).
  • The laboratory investigations show normal calcium, PTH, and phosphate.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents due to chronic fatigue & weight loss for the past 3 months. On physical examination, her face, palmar creases & gingivae appear hyperpigmented. Initial laboratory tests demonstrate elevated serum K+ levels and decreased serum Na+ levels of 5.5 mmol/L & 130 mmol/L, respectively. Her past medical record is uneventful. The physician suspects a case of primary adrenal insufficiency. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for diagnosing adrenal insufficiency?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cosyntropin test

  • Primary adrenal insufficiency, also known as Addison’s disease, is caused by insufficient secretion of adrenal hormones.
  • Patients usually present with fatigue, weight loss, decreased appetite, low blood pressure with salt cravings, hypoglycemia, abdominal or muscle pains, hyperpigmentation, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia.
  • The causes of Addison's disease include autoimmune disorders, malignancies, tuberculosis, acute meningococcal infection, and haemorrhage.
  • The diagnosis of primary adrenal insufficiency is established by the cosyntropin test (ACTH stimulation test).
  • During the test, a small amount of synthetic ACTH is injected, and the amount of cortisol (and sometimes aldosterone) that the adrenals produce in response is measured.
  • Cortisol values of <18µg/dl sampled 30-60 minutes after ACTH stimulation will diagnose the disease.
  • This is followed by plasma ACTH values to identify primary versus secondary Addison disease.
  • The cortisol level is low with normal to increased ACTH level in primary adrenal insufficiency.

Option A: CT abdomen

  • CT scan of the abdomen is done to diagnose adrenal adenoma or bilateral adrenal hyperplasia.
  • The patient has features of hypercortisolism in those cases (opposite to Addison’s disease).

Option B: Steroid autoantibodies

  • Steroid autoantibodies are markers for autoimmune adrenalitis.
  • It is a secondary test to find out the cause of Addison’s disease after the diagnosis of Addison’s disease is made.

Option D: Fludrocortisone challenge test

  • The fludrocortisone challenge test is done for Conn syndrome (increased aldosterone synthesis).
  • It has no role in detecting Addison’s disease.

questions.text: A 22-years-old female, G2P1L1, gave birth to a term baby girl of weight 3.2kgs in a hospital. The mother has no chronic medical condition and taking all her required supplements. Her vitals are within normal range. Routine neonatal screening tests are done. Neonatal screening for congenital hypothyroidism showed a TSH value of 38 mIU/ml & free T4 value of 0.5 ng/dl. What is the most common presentation in such a neonate?
questions.solution:
Option D: Asymptomatic at birth

  • Neonatal screening for congenital hypothyroidism showed a TSH value of 38mIU/ml & free T4 value of 0.5ng/dl.
  • It is caused by abnormal thyroid gland development or dyshormogenesis in iodine-sufficient regions.
  • Most commonly, infants with congenital hypothyroidism are asymptomatic at birth.
  • But some are presented by the following characters:
  • Puffy face
  • Paleness
  • Protuberant tongue
  • Protruding umbilicus
  • Potbelly
  • Poor brain development

 

  • Sluggish feeding 
  • constipation 
  • Lethargic 
  • sleep more, needs to be awakened to feed
  • Hoarse cry
  • Hypothermia 
  • Cardiomegaly 
  • Murmur
  • Asymptomatic pericardial effusion 
  • Macrocytic anemia 
  • hypotonic with slow reflexes 
  • prolonged physiological jaundice 

other options

Option A: Prolongation of physiological jaundice

  • It occurs in the case of congenital hypothyroidism, but most neonates are asymptomatic at birth.
  • It is defined as jaundice that lasts more than 14 to 21 days.

 

Option B: Wide open posterior fontanelle

  • It occurs in the case of congenital hypothyroidism, but most neonates are asymptomatic at birth.
  • Large-size fontanelle (both anterior and posterior) are early signs in symptomatic neonates.

Option C: Enlarged tongue and feeding problems

  • It occurs in congenital hypothyroidism, but most neonates are asymptomatic at birth.
  • It also occurs in many other cases like Down syndrome, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, acromegaly and primary amyloidosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with the complaint of recurrent diarrhoea episodes for the past 3 hours. On examination, his blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, and his pulse is 88 bpm. ABGs analysis shows a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following condition can have a similar acid-base imbalance?
questions.solution:
Option A: Small bowel fistula

  • A small bowel fistula causes metabolic acidosis by increasing the strong ion difference due to the loss of a large number of strong cations (sodium and potassium) with a relatively small loss of chloride

Option B: Metformin

  • Metformin causes lactic acidosis.
  • This results in high anion gap metabolic acidosis

Option C: Ethylene glycol poisoning

  • Ethylene glycol results in the formation of oxalic acid, glycolic acid, and other organic acids.
  • This raises the anion gap.

Option D: DKA

  • DKA results in the formation of ketoacids.
  • This raises the anion gap.
  • Hence increased anion gap metabolic acidosis is seen in DKA

questions.text: A 19-year-girl presents to opd with complaints of severe abdominal pain for 2 hours. She also had 3 episodes of vomiting at home. USG reveals 2 small renal stones on the lower pole of the left kidney. Urine analysis shows envelope-shaped crystals and few RBCs. Diagnosis of nephrolithiasis was made. Which of the following dietary modification will you advise her on?
questions.solution:
Option A: Low sodium diet

Treatment of renal stones:

  • An increase in fluid intake to at least 2.5–3 L/day is perhaps the single most effective intervention, regardless of the type of stone.
  • Conservative recommendations for patients with Calcium oxalate stones (i.e., low-salt, low-fat, moderate-protein diet) are thought to be helpful.
  • In contrast to prior assumptions, dietary calcium intake does not contribute to stone risk; dietary calcium may help reduce oxalate absorption and stone risk.
  • Calcium intake in patients with kidney stones should be normal with adequate water intake.

Option B: Low calcium diet

  • A low-calcium diet is not recommended.
  • Reduction in calcium may promote oxalate absorption, which predisposes to stone formation.

Option C: High sodium diet

  • High sodium intake may lead to sodium leaking in the urine.
  • This may take calcium with it, which depletes calcium stores in the body.
  • High levels of calcium in the urine lead to the development of kidney stones

Option D: Low citrate diet

  • Citrate is an inhibitor of stone formation.
  • Hypocitraturia is a risk factor for calcium oxalate stones.

questions.text: A 50-year-male presented to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhoea and reflux episodes. He also complains of weight loss and loss of appetite. A provisional diagnosis of Zollinger Ellison syndrome was made. The gastroenterologist suspected the underlying cause to be gastrinoma with metastasis. Which of the following is the best investigation for diagnosing metastatic gastrinoma?
questions.solution:
Option B: Octreoscan

  • Octreoscan is the brand name of somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS).
  • The most accurate non-invasive technique for locating primary tumours and metastases is SRS.
  • It is useful for figuring out whether liver or bone metastases are present. The results of this method can be utilised to distinguish between small liver hemangiomas and small liver metastases. False-positive SRS localisation findings can occasionally happen.
  • It is also helpful in identifying the primary lesions preoperatively
  • The diagnostic sensitivity of SRS is between 80%-100% in cases of metastasised gastrinomas.

Option A: Selective arterial secretin injection

  • This test is rarely advised since it has been demonstrated to be most useful for locating gastrinomas in the head of the pancreas and the proximal duodenum.

Option C: BAO/MAO ratio

  • The BAO/MAO ratio criterion> 0.6 is highly specific for gastrinoma but has a low sensitivity.

Option D: Ultrasound

  • With a sensitivity of 90% for intrapancreatic gastrinomas, endoscopic ultrasonography has also been proven to help detect the primary tumour.
  • Endoscopic ultrasonography is considerably less sensitive for metastatic gastrinomas.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with features of malabsorption and iron deficiency anaemia for three weeks. She has no history of chronic medical conditions and is currently not on any medications. Blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg, and pulse is 64 beats/min. After the examination of the patient, the physician recommends an endoscopy. Duodenal biopsy shows complete villous atrophy. Which antibody is likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Anti-endomysial antibodies

  • This patient, with features of malabsorption, iron-deficiency anaemia and villous atrophy, likely has celiac disease.
  • The best screening test for diagnosis of celiac sprue is the presence of anti-Tissue transglutaminase antibody and Anti-endomysial antibody.
  • Malabsorption and anaemia are seen due to disease affecting the distal part of the small intestine.
  • Biopsy from the Distal duodenum or proximal jejunum shows the loss or blunting of the intestinal mucosa.

Option B: Anti–goblet cell antibodies

  • Anti-goblet cell antibodies are not present in celiac disease.
  • They are found in autoimmune enteropathy.

Option C: Anti – Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies

  • Anti – Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies are associated with Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). They are usually not seen in celiac disease.

Option D: Anti-neutrophilic antibodies

  • Anti-neutrophilic antibodies can be seen in patients with autoimmune vasculitis and IBD. They are not seen in celiac disease.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male was diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukaemia after an incidental finding of leukocytosis last year. He was treated with imatinib, and the treatment was changed to nilotinib because of progressive leukocytosis. On follow-up, investigations revealed worsening of leukocytosis & thrombocytopenia. His peripheral blood showed >30% blasts with promyelocytes. What is the most effective treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Allogeneic bone marrow transplantation

  • The above features are suggestive of the Accelerated phase of CML.
  • Among patients who present with or evolve to the blastic phase, combinations of chemotherapy and Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors (TKI) should be used to induce remission, followed by allogeneic stem cell transplantation as soon as possible.
  • The same applies to patients who evolve from chronic to accelerated phase. Patients with de novo accelerated-phase CML may do well with long-term TKI therapy; the timing of allogeneic stem cell transplantation depends on their optimal response to TKI (achievement of complete cytogenetic response). The most effective is stem cell transplantation.
  • Among patients who relapse in the chronic phase, the treatment sequence depends on several factors, such as the patient's age and risk factors for stem cell transplantation.

Option B: Autologous bone marrow transplantation

  • Autologous bone marrow transplantation is not the treatment of choice; because the patient's bone marrow is already infiltrated with cancer.

Option C: Chemotherapy

  • The patient's peripheral blood shows >30% blasts with promyelocytes after treatment with imatinib and nilotinib. It shows chemotherapy is ineffective in this case.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Hydroxyurea & interferon

  • Hydroxyurea, a ribonucleotide reductase inhibitor, is used for controlling cell counts.
  • Interferons are given when allogeneic stem cell transplantation is not feasible.

questions.text: A 22 years male comes to OPD complaining of persistent painful erection of the penis for the last 6 hours. His past medical history includes severe anaemia in early childhood, for which he required a blood transfusion several times. He also has a history of multiple episodes of non-healing leg ulcers and abdominal and chest pain. His lab findings include decreased Hb, high reticulocyte count and an abnormal shaped RBC on PBF. What may be the probable diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Sickle cell anaemia

This patient's early childhood history of severe anaemia with the current presentation of acute, persistent painful erection (vaso-occlusive crisis), non-healing leg ulcers and lab findings mostly suggest sickle cell anaemia.

Sickle cell anaemia:

  • It is an inherited blood disorder caused by a point mutation in the β-globin gene.
  • Mutant HbA is termed HbS (sickle haemoglobin).
  • Deoxygenated HbS polymerizes and causes sickling.
  • Pathogenesis: Low O2, high altitudes, dehydration, or acidosis triggers sickling.
  • Sickled RBCs precipitate in the blood vessel and cause vaso-occlusion.
  • Signs/Symptoms of a vaso-occlusive crisis include:
    • Acute chest syndrome (most severe form).
    • Priapism (persistent painful erection of the penis for >4 hours).
    • Dactylitis (painful swelling of hands and feet).
    • Abdominal pain.
  • Priapism occurs due to the following:
    • An excessive release of neurotransmitters
    • Blockage of draining venules (e.g., mechanical interference in sickle cell crisis, leukaemia, or excessive use of intravenous parenteral lipids)
    • Prolonged relaxation of the intracavernous smooth muscles (most often caused by using exogenous smooth-muscle relaxants such as injectable intra-cavernosal prostaglandin E1)
  • Lab findings include:
    • Decreased Hb.
    • High reticulocyte count (>1.5%).
    • Peripheral blood smear: Target cells and Howell-Jolly bodies.
    • Haemoglobin electrophoresis: Abnormal Hb (HbS) with sickling of RBC.

Option B: Hairy cell leukaemia

  • It is a rare type of blood and bone marrow cancer where the bone marrow makes excessive lymphocytes.
  • It can cause anaemia, but vaso-occlusive symptoms and abnormal sickled RBCs won't be found here.

Option C: ALL

  • Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia is the most common childhood cancer.
  • Signs include- Fever, anaemia, easy bruising, petechiae, bone or joint pain, and shortness of breath.
  • But sickled RBC and priapism are highly unlikely in this condition.

Option D: Beta thalassemia

  • It is also an inherited blood disorder caused by a point mutation in the β-globin gene.
  • PBF will reveal target cells but no sickled RBC.
  • Also, the reticulocyte count will be lower than normal.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old female is brought to the emergency department by the paramedics due to left-sided weakness and aphasia since last night (approximately for 10 hours). Physical examination reveals a weakness in the left arm and leg, left homonymous hemianopia and aphasia. The ECG shows atrial fibrillation. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain shows:



Which of the following is the next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Urgent administration of a thrombolytic agent (e.g., alteplase)

questions.solution:
Option D: Administration of dual antiplatelet therapy

  • The patient presents with left-sided weakness, left homonymous hemianopia and aphasia, indicating a brain lesion on the right side.
  • The CT scan shows the ischemic involvement of the areas supplied by the middle cerebral artery.
  • Hence, the diagnosis for this patient is ischemic stroke.
  • Risk factors for ischemic stroke include a family history of stroke, smoking, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and diabetes mellitus.
  • Investigations include non-contrast CT scans (investigation of choice), CT perfusion and CT angiography.
  • Treatment includes: 
    • The usage of a thrombolytic agent (e.g., alteplase) is up to 4-4.5 hours after the vascular accident.
    • After 4-4.5 hours, the treatment of choice is dual antiplatelet therapy. Administration of 300mg aspirin and 300mg clopidogrel should also be started in suspected stroke cases.
    • Anticoagulants such as warfarin, apixaban, dabigatran and rivaroxaban for long-term use in patients with atrial fibrillation.
    • Thrombectomy
    • Treatment of underlying conditions should be done simultaneously.
    • Dual antiplatelet therapy reduces the risk of recurrent stroke.
    • As this patient had symptoms for almost 10 hours, thrombolytic therapy could not be used.
    • Therefore, dual antiplatelet therapy is the next step in managing this patient.

Option A: Heparin

  • Heparin increases the risk of intracranial and extracranial haemorrhage.
  • Therefore, its antithrombotic benefits are limited due to the increased risk of haemorrhage.

Option B: Lumbar puncture 

  • Lumbar puncture is done to carry out cerebrospinal fluid analysis for the diagnosis of meningitis.
  • It is contraindicated in stroke.

Option C: Urgent administration of a thrombolytic agent (e.g., alteplase)

  • As the patient had symptoms for almost 10 hours, thrombolytic therapy cannot be used.
  • The window period for stroke is 4-4.5 hours.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department by her home health aide secondary to her behaving in a disorganized manner. Moreover, she has a 20-year-old history of focal impaired awareness with cognitive changes and behavioural arrest, progressing to poorly controlled bilateral tonic-clonic seizures. Subsequently, her Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) displays asymmetry of the hippocampus, with a prominent right temporal horn of the lateral ventricle. Based on the history and findings, which of the following is the most efficacious treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Amygdalohippocampectomy

The above clinical history & features are suggestive of Mesial temporal lobe epilepsy.

  • It is associated with focal seizures with impairment of consciousness.
  • MRI can detect the characteristic hippocampal sclerosis that appears to be essential in the pathophysiology of MTLE for many patients.
  • It tends to be refractory to treatment with anticonvulsants but responds well to surgical intervention.
  • EEG shows Temporal (Unilateral or Bilateral) spikes.
  • MRI Brain (coronal views below) showing asymmetry of the lateral ventricles, with a prominent right temporal horn of the lateral ventricle, indicative of decreased volume in the right hippocampal region.

  • These patients have epilepsy refractory to medical therapy and need devices like vagal nerve stimulation.

Definitive treatment

  • Amygdalohippocampectomy
    • It is a surgical procedure that removes the amygdala and hippocampus.
    • Resection of Antero-medial temporal lobe or limited removal of hippocampus and amygdala.

  • Lesionectomy
    • It is a common surgical procedure to remove a lesion or abnormality in the brain.
    • Focal seizures are abolished by focal neocortical resection with the removal of the identified lesion.

Option B: Levetiracetam

  • Levetiracetam is increasingly considered the initial Drug of choice for women of childbearing age with epilepsies having mixed seizure types. 
  • Levetiracetam is used for focal seizures in elderly patients. (Less interaction with other drugs)

Option C: Primidone

  • Primidone is a derivative of barbiturate and is used as an anticonvulsant for the following:
  • Grand Mal seizures
  • Focal or Jacksonian seizures
  • Myoclonic jerks
  • Akinetic attacks

Option D: Vagus Nerve Stimulation

  • Vagus Nerve Stimulation (VNS) is a surgical treatment involving the implantation of a device that electrically stimulates the vagus nerve.
  • Indications are as follows:
    • Adjunctive treatment of epilepsy
    • Depression resistant to medications

questions.text: What is the false regarding difference in between Upper motor neuron lesion and Lower motor neuron lesion?
questions.solution:
Option D: Paralysis is Flaccid in UMNL

  • This statement is incorrect
  • Paralysis is spastic in UMNL

Other options

​​​​​​​Option A: Tone is increased in UMNL

  • Tone is increased in UMNL is true

Option B: Babinski sign positive in UMNL

  • Babinski sign positive in UMNL is true

Option C: Clonus present in UMNL

  • Clonus present in UMNL is true

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to rheumatology OPD complaining of painful swelling in his right big toe since yesterday. He is diabetic, hypertensive and has a history of tuberculosis six months ago, for which he took medication regularly. On examination, the right 1st metatarsophalangeal joint is tender, swollen and erythematous. There are no other findings on systemic examination. The doctor advises synovial fluid aspiration, which shows strongly negative birefringent needle-shaped crystals under polarized light. What are these crystals composed of?
questions.solution:
Option A: Monosodium urate

  • This is a case of gouty arthritis.
  • Gout is an inflammatory disease resulting from monosodium urate crystals deposited in and around synovial joints.
  • Risk Factors include five times more likely in males, risk increases with old age, metabolic syndrome may increase the risk of gout, alcoholism, generalized osteoarthritis, Diet high in red meat, low in vitamin C or coffee, and lead poisoning.
  • Causes include reduced excretion (increased renal tubular reabsorption, renal failure, lead toxicity, lactic acidosis, drugs such as diuretics, alcohol etc.), increased intake of uric acid (Red meat, seafood) and Increased production (Lymphoproliferative disease, Psoriasis, Glycogen storage diseases and inherited disorders such as Lesch-Nyhan syndrome and Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate synthetase 1 mutation).
  • Pathophysiology is the basic mechanism that underlies all of the above-listed causes: an imbalance between the production of uric acid and its excretion by kidneys (two-thirds) and gut (one-third).
  • Clinical features include:
    • Acute monoarthritis: Classic presentations, most commonly involving 1st metatarsophalangeal joint, although ankle, midfoot, knee, wrist, elbow, or MCP joints can also be involved.
    • Rapid onset
    • Severe pain
    • Self-limiting, often completely resolving in one or two weeks.
  • Examination findings include Tophi (irregular, firm nodules on extensor surfaces of fingers, hands, forearm, elbow, Achilles tendon, and helix of the ear, often seen in chronic cases of gout).
  • They are white in color, unlike rheumatoid nodules.
  • They can become ulcerated or infected or induce an inflammatory response in the surrounding tissue.
  • Investigations include
    • Confirmatory test: Joint fluid aspiration.
    • Crystals of monosodium urate are needle-shaped, 5–25 μm in length, and strongly negatively birefringent under polarized light.

  • Treatment in cases of an acute attack is by oral NSAIDs for pain relief (oral colchicine 0.5mg twice or thrice daily); if the diagnosis is clear and infection is absent, joint aspiration and intra-articular steroid injection can provide immediate pain relief, oral or intra-muscular corticosteroids can also be added.
  • In refractory or complicated cases, patients with two or more attacks in one year should be started on allopurinol 100 mg daily or 50mg in old patients or those with renal failure.
  • The long-term treatment plan must include correcting risk factors, lifestyle modifications to lose weight, reduction of alcohol intake, and dietary modification.

Option B: Calcium pyrophosphate

  • These crystals are formed in pseudogout.
  • They are differentiated from MSU crystals by joint aspiration, as they are positively birefringent and rod-shaped. In contrast, MSU crystals are negatively birefringent and needle-shaped.
  • Pseudogout occurs most commonly in patients aged more than 85 years old.
  • The most common joint involved is the knee joint.
  • It has no relation to metabolic syndrome, use of drugs such as anti-tuberculous drugs or hyperuricemia.

Option C: Sodium pyrophosphate

  • Sodium pyrophosphate is a compound used in the making of cleaning compounds.
  • It has no role in gout or pseudogout formation.
  •  It isn’t involved in joint disease. .

Option D: Homogentistic Acid

  • This metabolite is used to diagnose alkaptonuria, a metabolic disease resulting from enzyme homogentisic acid oxidase deficiency.
  • It accumulates in urine and serum.
  • It is not involved in joint disease

questions.text: A mother brings her 4-year-old boy to the medicine outpatient department with a complaint of fever for 5 days. On examination, the child has red eyes. The patient also had dry as well as cracked lips. The child was also having rashes on his hands and feet. The doctor also noticed edema on his soles and palms and had unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. The patient also had a red tongue. The doctor suggested radiological imaging of coronary arteries to confirm the suspected vasculitis. Closely observe the image and analyze the symptoms mentioned above. Choose the correct statement regarding the disease

choices.text: IV immunoglobulin is used in treatment

questions.solution:
Option C: IV immunoglobulin is used in the treatment

  • The image show child having a strawberry tongue

Kawasaki disease:

  • Also known as "mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome."
  • Most common vasculitis in children aged less than 4 years.
  • It is a Necrotizing Vasculitis involving Medium-sized vessels, most commonly the Coronary arteries.
  • Diagnostic Criteria for Kawasaki Disease:
  • Fever lasting for at least 5 days + at least 4 out of 5 characteristic symptoms should be present:
    • Conjunctivitis (bilateral)
    • Rash, primary truncal
    • Asymmetric cervical lymphadenitis
    • Crusting of lips, fissuring of mouth and oropharyngeal erythema
    • Oedema & erythema of palms & soles
    • Adenopathy
    • Mucosal involvement: Strawberry tongue
  • Management:
    • High dose Aspirin and IV immunoglobin.
    • Steroids are contraindicated (danger of vessel rupture).
    • Add Warfarin if there is a high risk of thrombosis (very high platelet count).

Option A:  Aspirin is contraindicated in this disease

  • Aspirin is an NSAID. Also known as acetylsalicylic acid.
  • It is used to treat inflammation, minor aches/pain and fever.
  • Aspirin is given with IV Immunoglobin in Kawasaki to prevent abnormalities in the coronary artery.
  • It prevents the development of Myocardial infarction in a patient with Kawasaki disease.
  • Aspirin is contraindicated in bleeding disorders and patients under 16 years except in Kawasaki disease.

Option B:  Bilateral purulent conjunctivitis is present

  • Purulent conjunctivitis is a violently severe conjunctival infection.
  • The patient is presented with profuse pus (white or coloured), eye pain/itch/puffiness and a clear propensity for corneal involvement.
  • Purulent conjunctivitis is most commonly caused by N. gonorrhoea and Neisseria meningitidis
  • The patients have bulbar congestion in Kawasaki Disease.
  • There is an Absence of any discharge.

Option D: Lymphadenopathy is rare

  • Lymphadenopathy means swelling of lymph nodes.
  • Swelling of lymph nodes occurs due to
    • Infections,
    • Autoimmune diseases,
    • Malignancies
    • Drug reactions.
  • The patients develop  Unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy with fever in the initial part of Kawasaki Disease.
  • Kawasaki illness also causes swelling in the glands (lymph nodes) and mucous membranes within the mouth, nose, eyes, and throat.
  • Formerly referred to as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman presented to your hospital for a routine first-trimester checkup. A laboratory workup was done. She is found to have a Hepatitis B infection. Which of the following antigen does not appear in the blood in such patients?
questions.solution:
ANSWER

Option A: HbcAg

  • HBcAg is an antigen that can be found on the surface of the nucleocapsid core (the innermost layer of the hepatitis B virus). While both HBcAg and HBeAg are made from the same open reading frame, HBcAg is not secreted.
  • HBcAg is considered "particulate" and does not circulate in the blood, but a recent study shows it can be detected in serum by Radioimmunoassay.
  • However, it is readily detected in hepatocytes after biopsy. The presence of both HBcAg and HBeAg proteins together acts as a marker of viral replication, and antibodies to these antigens are a marker of declining replication.

Other Options

Option B: HbeAg

  • HBeAg is an antigen that can be found between the icosahedral nucleocapsid core and the lipid envelope (the outermost layer of the hepatitis b virus). However, HBeAg is considered "nonparticulate" or "secretory".
  • While both HBeAg and HBcAg are made from the same reading frame (multiple protein products can be produced from the same DNA sequence, and when the genes "ORF Core" and "Pre C" are translated together, the result is HBeAg), HBeAg is secreted and accumulates in serum as an immunologically distinct soluble antigen.
  • Hence the reason why the presence of both proteins together acts as a marker of viral replication and why antibodies to these antigens are a marker of declining replication.
  • The presence of HBeAg in the serum of patients can serve as a marker of active replication in chronic hepatitis.

Option C: HbsAg

  • HBsAg is the most common hepatitis B test. The presence of HBsAg in serum indicates that the patient has contracted HBV infection.
  • The test is used to identify those at risk of spreading the disease, e.g., blood donors, pregnant women, intravenous drug abusers, healthcare workers, institutionalized people, transplant donors and recipients, and donors of semen for artificial insemination.
  • A quantitative HBsAg test can be used to monitor the treatment of chronically infected patients. HBsAg screening assays are normally supported by confirmatory tests, which are used to confirm repeatable reactive (positive) results.
  • Typically the confirmatory test involves neutralization of the HBsAg in the sample by >50% using a human anti-HBs antibody.​​​​​​​

Option D: None of the above

  • HbcAg antigens do not appear in the blood of such patients.

questions.text: A forty-two years old woman presented to your clinic with a history of recurrent jaundice. She also complains of losing her appetite despite not feeling nauseous. On examination, she is icteric. Routine liver function tests reveal elevated levels of serum bilirubin. Her liver enzymes are within the normal range. Prothrombin time is also normal. Serum bilirubin is predominantly unconjugated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Gilbert's Syndrome

  • Gilbert Syndrome is caused by decreased bilirubin uridine diphosphate glucuronosyltransferase enzyme activity.
  • This causes decreased conjugation of bilirubin, leading to increased levels of unconjugated bilirubin.
  • Gilbert syndrome is usually asymptomatic; jaundice occurs in situations of stress.
  • There is mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia but normal values for standard hepatic biochemical tests and normal hepatic histology other than a modest increase of lipofuscin pigment in some patients.
  • Serum bilirubin concentrations are most often < 3 mg/dL.

Option B:  Dubin Johnson syndrome

  • Dubin Johnson syndrome is persistent non-hemolytic hyperbilirubinemia associated with lipochrome-like pigment in the liver cells
  • Both Dubin Johnson syndrome and Rotor syndrome cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Option C: Rotor syndrome

  • Rotor syndrome is an autosomal recessive disease and a rare cause of mixed direct (conjugated) and indirect (unconjugated) hyperbilirubinemia
  • Both Dubin Johnson syndrome and Rotor syndrome cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Option D: Hepatocellular necrosis

  • Acute, toxic injury to the liver with sudden and precipitous onset, marked elevations in serum aminotransferase levels, and early signs of hepatic (or other organ) dysfunction or failure despite minimal or no jaundice
  • This would cause an increase in liver enzymes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with fever, Headache, and unilateral parotid gland swelling. A few weeks back, he had a history of throat infections. On examination, there are blisters on the tympanic membrane and lymphadenopathy. He also complains of multiple joint pain and cough with very low sputum expectoration. A chest x-ray is done, showing patchy consolidation at the hilum and fanning to the periphery. What is the drug of choice for the given clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Option D:  Azithromycin

  • The given clinical features and physical examination findings suggest Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
  • It is the classic cause of atypical pneumonia, also called silent pneumonia.
  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a pleomorphic organism and lacks a cell wall.
  • It has a selective affinity for respiratory epithelial cells.
  • Outbreaks are more common in military recruits, prisons, and colleges.
  • The patient's symptoms may include:
    • Fever
    • Malaise
    • Persistent worsening cough
    • Indolent dull Headache
    • Chills
    • Macular/vesicular rash
    • Pharyngitis 
  • Interstitial infiltrate will be present on chest x-ray.
  • The x-ray of this disease is worse than the presentation of the patient.
  • Treatment options for Acute mycoplasma pneumoniae infection include
    • Macrolides (e.g.oral, azithromycin, 500 mg on day 1, then 250 mg on days 2–5). It is the drug of choice.
    • Tetracyclines (e.g., oral doxycycline, 100 mg twice daily for 10–14 days), and
    • Respiratory fluoroquinolones: However, ciprofloxacin and ofloxacin are not recommended because of their high minimal inhibitory concentrations against M. pneumoniae isolates and their poor performance in experimental studies.

Option A: Penicillin

  • It is used to treat streptococcus pneumonia.
  • Penicillin is ineffective as it has no cell wall.

Option B: Tetracycline

  • Tetracyclines are used to treat mycoplasma pneumoniae, but the first line of treatment is macrolides.

Option C: Cefuroxime

  • Cefuroxime is a second-generation cephalosporin and can be used to treat Klebsiella pnemoniae.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male who is a suspected case of leprosy with Type 1 reaction has come to the clinic. On examination, the patient was afebrile. Peripheral nerves, including the greater auricular, radial cutaneous, ulnar and common peroneal nerves, were all thickened with the tenderness of the radial cutaneous and ulnar nerves bilaterally. Examination of the skin revealed multiple asymmetric and well-demarcated raised, erythematous plaques across the chest, abdomen, arms, back, legs and face with reduced sensation to pinprick in all lesions. What will be the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Systemic steroids

The given clinical case is a case of Type 1 lepra reaction with severe neuritis.

Therapy for Reactions

  • Type 1 lepra reactions are best treated with glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone, initially at 40-60 mg/d). As the inflammation subsides, the glucocorticoid dose can be tapered, but steroid therapy must be continued for at least 6 months.

Raised erythematous plaques of multi-bacillary leprosy in Type 1 reaction.

Option B: Clofazimine

  • Clofazimine is used to treat leprosy paired with dapsone and rifampicin. It is only used for erythema nodosum leprosum (Type 2 lepra) and multibacillary (MB) leprosy.
  • It is considered an orphan drug and is unavailable in pharmacies.

Option C:  Paracetamol

  • Type 2 Lepra reaction: If erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) is mild (i.e., without fever or other organ involvement), it may be treated with antipyretics alone. In cases with many skin lesions, fever, malaise, and other tissue involvement, brief glucocorticoid courses (1-2 weeks) are effective.

Option D:  Thalidomide

  • If despite two courses of glucocorticoid therapy, Type 2 lepra (ENL) appears to be recurring and persisting, treatment with thalidomide should be initiated

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency ward with abdominal pain and headache complaints. A general physical examination revealed 6 scars on the abdomen from previous surgeries. He seeks attention from the nurses. He demands multiple tests, including a liver biopsy. The medical team failed to diagnose any major physical illness in this patient. His mental status examination doesn't reveal any major psychopathology. One treating staff recognized him to have appeared in several other hospitals with abdominal pain and some other vague complaints. He is most likely suffering from which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option D: Factitious disorder

  • This is a case of factitious disorder.
  • Characteristics of factitious disorder:
  • The history of multiple scars from previous surgeries.
  • Seeking attention from nurses.
  • Maintenance of sick role.
  • Demands for multiple diagnostic tests and identification by staff all suggest a factitious disorder.
  • In the absence of a confirmed physical or mental disorder, disease, or disability, the individual feigns symptoms repeatedly and consistently.
  • Individuals with this pattern of behavior usually show signs of several other marked abnormalities of personality and relationships.
  • Willful production of symptoms to get medical attention and take 'sick role.'
  • A sick role means that the patient wants others to accept him as “sick” and treat him accordingly by giving attention and care.
  • Patients with factitious disorders frequently fake symptoms to get the “sick role."
  • Professional patients
  • Hospital addiction

Option A: Schizophrenia

  • Psychotic disorder
  • Positive symptoms: Hallucinations, delusions, confused thoughts, disorganized speech, movement disorders
  • Negative symptoms: Avolition, apathy, anhedonia, affective flattening, alogia.

Option B: Malingering

  • Not a psychiatric disorder.
  • Wilful production of symptoms for conscious external incentives like financial incentives, avoiding legal cases, or a tough job.
  • Should be suspected.
  • Referral by a court of law.
  • The discrepancy in complaints and objective findings
  • Lack of cooperation by patients during evaluation and treatment.

Option C: Somatization disorder

  • One or more somatic symptoms (pain, GI symptoms, sexual dysfunction symptoms, pseudo-neurologic symptoms)
  • Excessive thoughts, excessive behaviors, excessive feelings.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother with the complaint of slow speech and low academic performance. She says that her delivery had no complications. She further states that except for the slow development of motor milestones, the child remained healthy until now. On the examination, the intelligence quotient of the child is 60. Which of the following intervention can be used to manage maladaptive behavior in a mentally retarded patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Contingency management

  • Patients with mental retardation may exhibit maladaptive behaviors such as hostility, self-injurious behavior, and hyperactivity.

  • These behaviors can usually be modified using behavioral therapy techniques like contingency management.

  • In contingency management, the desired behaviors are rewarded, and undesired behaviors are punished.

Option A: Cognitive behavior therapy

  • CBT is indicated in various psychiatric disorders, which include anxiety disorders (panic disorder, agoraphobia, social phobia, specific phobia, and generalized anxiety disorder), obsessive-compulsive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, depression, and eating disorders (bulimia nervosa)

  • Mentally retarded child behavior should be modified by contingency management.

Option C: Cognitive reconstruction

  • Cognitive reconstruction is used to manage psychotic disorders, personality disorders, and depression.

  • Mentally retarded child behavior should be modified by contingency management.

Option D: Self-instruction

  • Self-instruction is not used to correct the behavior of mentally retarded children.

  • Mentally retarded child behavior should be modified by contingency management.

questions.text: An 80-year-old female presents with complaints of a gradual cognitive decline, apraxia, disorientation, and sleep disturbances. 18F-Florbetaben amyloid imaging of the patient showed diffuse amyloid retention with prominent striatal uptake, as this is a characteristic feature supporting the clinical utility of amyloid imaging in the diagnostic process of Alzheimer’s disease. MMSE is done. She is unable to spell the word world backward. Which of the following cognitive domains is being tested?
questions.solution:
Option B: Attention

  • It is a true statement.
  • Alzheimer's is one of the progressive neurologic disorders that cause the brain to shrink and brain cells to die. Alzheimer's is one of the most common causes of dementia — a continuous decline in behavioral, thinking, and social skills that affect a person's ability to function independently.
  • The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) has poor sensitivity when screening for incapacity in groups with dementia, acquired brain injury, or psychiatric disorders.
  • In contrast, the MMSE has high specificity when evaluating capacity in these diagnostic groups.
  • MMSE would have a specificity of 91% if the score cutoff was 22 or lower.
  • Even higher specificity was found when the cutoff was below 20.
  • The MMSE is a 30-point test for the assessment of cognitive function, including orientation, registration, attention, memory, language, and visuomotor integrity.
  • The MMSE tests attention by having the patient spell the word world backward or performs serial 7s (i.e., have the patient count backward from 100 by 7s).
  • The risk factors of the disease are
Risk factors for Alzheimer's disease
  • Age
  • Head injury
  • HTN
  • Insulin resistance
  • Depression
  • Down syndrome
  • Smoking
  • There is the presence of loss of memory and prosopagnosia (difficulty in identifying face).
  • Following tests can help in the diagnosis of the disease
  1. cognitive and memory tests to assess the person's ability to think and remember
  2. neurological function tests test their balance, senses, and reflexes
  3. blood or urine tests
  4. MRI or CT scan

Mini – Mental State Examination (MMSE)

Patient’s Name: ________________________          Date:______________________

Instructions: Score one point for each correct response within each question or activity

Maximum Score

Patient’s Score

Questions

5

  

“What is the year? Season? Date? Day? Month”

5

  

“Where are we now? State? County? Town/City? Hospital? Floor”

3

  

The examiner names three unrelated objects clearly and slowly, then the instructor asks the patient to name all three of them. The patient’s response is used for scoring. The examiner repeats them until patient learns all of them, if possible

5

  

“I would like you to count backward from 100 by sevens.” (93, 86, 79, 72, 65, …)

Alternative: “Spell WORLD backwards.” (D-L-R-O-W)

3

  

“Earlier I told you the names of three things. Can you tell me what those were?”

2

  

Show the patient two simple objects, such as a wristwatch and a pencil, and ask the patient to name them.

1

  

“Repeat the phrase; No its, ands, or buts”

3

  

“Take the paper in you right hand, fold it in half, and put it on the floor.” (The examiner gives the patient a piece of blank paper.)

1

  

“Please read this and do what it says.” (Written instructions is ‘Close your eyes.’)

1

  

“Make up and write a sentence about anything.” (This sentence must contain a noun and a verb.)

1

  

“Please copy this picture.” (The examiner gives the patient a blank piece of paper and asks him/her to draw the symbol below). All 10 angles must be present and two must intersect.)

30

  

Total

 

Option A: Registration

  • It is a false statement.
