  • The MMSE tests attention by having the patient spell the word world backward or perform serial 7s (i.e., have the patient count backward from 100 by 7s).

Option C: Executive functioning

  • It is a false statement.
  • The MMSE tests attention by asking the patient to spell backward.

Option D: Orientation

  • It is a false statement.
  • The MMSE tests attention in this case.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old female patient with a history of schizophrenia has been taking a second-generation antipsychotic medication for the past month. She presents to the clinic with complaints of an intense inner restlessness and an inability to sit still. The restlessness is distressing and is affecting her daily activities. On examination, the patient is observed constantly shifting in her chair, crossing and uncrossing her legs, and frequently changing her position. She describes a strong urge to keep moving and feels unable to find relief.

What is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is  D: Akathisia

The clinical presentation of the patient, including the subjective feeling of restlessness, objective signs of motor restlessness such as rocking motions, pacing around, and rapid alteration of sitting and standing, is consistent with akathisia. Akathisia is a common side effect of antipsychotic medications and is characterized by an intense inner restlessness and an inability to sit still.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome presents with severe muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, autonomic instability, and altered mental status.

Option B: Acute Dystonia presents with sudden muscle contractions, such as oculogyric crisis, torticollis, and trismus.

Option C: Tardive Dyskinesia is characterized by abnormal involuntary movements, typically involving the face, lips, tongue, and extremities, and it usually occurs after prolonged use of antipsychotic medications.

questions.text: A previously healthy 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency room with a 3-day history of nausea, anorexia, weakness, abdominal pain, and six episodes of vomiting associated with loose stools. He has no history of fever or respiratory or urinary symptoms. On examination, his blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, and his heart rate is 120 beats per minute. The physical examination reveals a thin-built boy with sunken eyes and slightly dry mucous membranes. Fluid resuscitation has been started for the patient. Which of the following is the best guide for managing fluid resuscitation?
questions.solution:
The best measure of organ perfusion and the best monitor of the adequacy of shock therapy remains the urine output”.

  • Minimum urine output in ADULTS – 1ml/min
  • Minimum urine output in CHILDRENS – (0.5 – 1) ml/min

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the primary rural health centre when he slipped from the roof of the house and fell onto a trishula fixed on the top of a small temple next to the house. The trishula entered the back near the renal fossa, traversed the abdomen, and exited through the anterior abdominal wall. The people around there dismantled the trishula from the top of the temple while it remained in situ. Due to the rural setup and poor communication, the ambulance took about 2 hours to reach there. The boy is conscious and in extreme pain. His blood pressure is 150/60mmHg, and his heart rate is 130 beats per minute. Which of the following is a correct statement regarding the patient's shifting?

choices.text: Placed on a hard board with head/spine stabilized
Ask the patient to keep quiet while he is on board

questions.solution:
Option A: Placed on a hard board with head/spine stabilised

  • Based on the history of falls and piercing of the renal fossa and anterior abdomen wall, extreme pain and a heart rate of 130 beats per minute show severe abdominal trauma and suspected hypovolemic shock due to internal bleeding. Therefore, the patient should be shifted urgently to a tertiary care hospital for multidisciplinary care.
  • The patient should be placed straight on a hard board with head and spine stabilisation, as shown in the image below.

  • Immobilisation of cervical spine injury requires continuous immobilisation of the entire patient with a semi-rigid cervical collar, head immobilisation, backboard, tape, and straps before and after transfer to a definitive-care facility.
  • Modes of transportation:
    • Do no further harm is the most important principle when choosing the mode of patient transportation.
    • Ground, water, and air transportation can be safe and effective in fulfilling this principle, and no one form is intrinsically superior to the others.
    • Local factors such as availability, geography, cost, and weather are the main determining factors to use in a given circumstance.

Four-Person Logroll. Logrolling a patient to remove a spine board and/or examine the back
(A) One person stands at the patient's head to control the head and c-spine, and two are along the patient's sides to control the body and extremities.
(B) As the patient is rolled, three people maintain alignment of the spine, while
(C) the fourth person removes the board and examines the back. (D) Once the board is removed, the patient is returned to the supine position, while maintaining alignment of the spine

Option B: In a lateral lying position

  • Based on the history of falls and piercing of the renal fossa and anterior abdomen wall, extreme pain and a heart rate of 130 beats per minute show severe abdominal trauma and suspected hypovolemic shock due to internal bleeding. Therefore, the patient should be shifted urgently to a tertiary care hospital for multidisciplinary care.
  • The patient should be placed straight on a hard board with head and spine stabilisation, not in a lateral lying position.

Option C: Ask the patient to keep quiet while he is on board

  • Based on the history of falls and piercing of the renal fossa and anterior abdomen wall, extreme pain and a heart rate of 130 beats per minute show severe abdominal trauma and suspected hypovolemic shock due to internal bleeding. Therefore, the patient should be shifted urgently to a tertiary care hospital for multidisciplinary care.
  • The patient should be asked to speak and talk while he is on the board and not to be quiet at any time if he is conscious.

Option D: Rolling by moving the spine

  • Based on the history of falls and piercing of the renal fossa and anterior abdomen wall, extreme pain and a heart rate of 130 beats per minute show severe abdominal trauma and suspected hypovolemic shock due to internal bleeding. Therefore, the patient should be shifted urgently to a tertiary care hospital for multidisciplinary care.
  • The patient should be rolled without moving the spine.
  • The log roll or logrolling transfers a patient without flexing the spinal column.
  • The patient's legs are stretched, and the head is held to immobilise the neck.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman was hospitalized because of microcytic anemia, weight loss, anorexia, and vomiting. Upper gastro-endoscopy with biopsy revealed an ulcer 4 cm x 3 cm at the gastric antrum. Histopathological examination found a poorly differentiated ulcerative adenocarcinoma (ADC). The patient was scheduled for an open D2 total gastrectomy with an end-to-side esophagojejunal anastomosis with a 21 mm EEA stapler and Roux-en-Y reconstruction. In this intestinal anastomosis, strength is mainly provided by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: Submucosa

  • In intestinal anastomosis, strength is mainly provided by submucosa
  • It has a high collagen content and is the most stable suture layer in all sections of the gastrointestinal tract

Option A: Mucosa

  • The mucosa consists of epithelium, lamina propria and muscularis mucosae.
  • Mucosa has not enough collagen content.
  • Therefore, it does not have enough strength for anastomosis.

Option C: Serosa

  • Serosa is formed by a serous membrane; it does not have enough collagen content.
  • Therefore, it does not have enough strength for anastomosis.

Option D: Muscularis mucosa

  • Muscularis mucosa is a muscular layer of mucosa; it does not have enough collagen content.
  • Therefore, it does not have enough strength for anastomosis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease. Medications include insulin, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. Physical examination shows pitting oedema of both ankles. Serum creatinine concentration is 4.5 mg/dL. Donor kidney transplantation is planned by the physician. The kidney to be transplanted has to be stored at a temperature between 0-5° C and flushed with University of Wisconsin solution. What is the rationale behind storing kidneys at low temperatures?

choices.text: Oxygen is more soluble in cold solutions and provides a continuous supply for energy metabolism
There is no way to suppress microbial growth except by cooling and slowing the growth rate
Hypothermia diminishes energy requirements and allows the limited energy reserve to keep the organ alive
It slows down metabolism and the enzymatic processes that would destroy the cell

questions.solution:
ANSWER

\Option D: It slows metabolism and the enzymatic processes that would destroy the cell

  • Organ preservation is the supply line for organ transplantation. Currently, solid organs like the liver, pancreas, and kidney can be successfully preserved for up to two days by flushing the organs with the University of Wisconsin (UW) organ preservation solution and storing them at hypothermia (0–5° C).
  • At the cellular level, the basis of hypothermic protection is the effect of temperature on reaction rates which are generally slowed by a reduction in temperature (typically a 50% reduction for each 10-degree drop in temperature for most reactions). The processes of deterioration associated with ischemia and anoxia are mediated by chemical reactions, and these reactions are slowed down by hypothermia. These deleterious changes begin with the depletion of high energy reserves (adenosine triphosphate and creatine phosphate) and membrane depolarization.
  • Hypothermia is known to influence
  • Reaction rates
  • Energy metabolism
  • Active ion transport and ion homeostasis
  • Membrane fluidity
  • Function and secretion of hormones and neurotoxins
  • Cooling has proven to be the first line of defense against hypoxic injury and is necessary to reduce cellular metabolism and the requirements for oxygen to prevent tissue injury. Most organs are stored by static cold storage in an icebox at 4 degree Celsius.
  • Cold storage solutions like UW solution mitigate the adverse effects of hypothermia. UW solution is effective because it uses a number of impermeant cell agents (lactobionic acid, raffinose, hydroxyethyl starch) that prevent the cells from swelling during cold ischemic storage.
  • UW solution also contains glutathione and adenosine, agents that may stimulate recovery of normal metabolism upon reperfusion by augmenting the antioxidant capacity and membrane integrity of the organs (glutathione) or by stimulating high-energy phosphate generation ATP (adenosine) upon reperfusion.
Organ Optimum(hours) Safe maximum (hours)
Kidney <18 36
Liver <12 18
Pancreas <10 18
Small intestine <4 6
Heart <3 6
Lung <3 6

Other Options

Option A: Oxygen is more soluble in cold solutions and provides a continual supply of energy metabolism

As a fact, oxygen solubility increases with a decrease in temperature. But oxygen is not the sole contributor to keeping the organ alive. Enzymatic functions and metabolic processes are more important to be in a proper and balanced state to keep the organ alive.

Option B: There is no way to suppress microbial growth except by cooling and slowing the growth rate

Pharmacological inhibition methods are used to inhibit the growth of microorganisms on preserved organs rather than hypothermia.

Option C: Hypothermia diminishes energy requirements and allows the limited energy reserve to keep the organ alive

Slowing down of energy requirement of the organ is not much helpful in preserving an organ. Enzymatic processes damaging to a cell are more important to deal with than those achieved with hypothermia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a history of abdominal gunshot injury. The pulse is 130/min, blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 35/min. On abdominal examination, generalized abdominal tenderness with guarding is present. Which of the following compensatory mechanisms is currently acting in this patient?

choices.text: The juxtaglomerular apparatus in the kidney produces renin
There is afferent arteriolar constriction and efferent arteriolar dilatation
Increased excretion of sodium by the kidneys
Increased potassium reabsorption by the kidneys

questions.solution:
Option A: The juxtaglomerular apparatus in the kidney produces renin

  • This patient with generalized abdominal tenderness with guarding, a pulse rate of 130/min and blood pressure of 80/60 mmHg following a gunshot wound is in a state of hemorrhagic shock.
  • In response to vasoconstriction and a decrease in blood flow, the juxtaglomerular apparatus in the kidney produces the enzyme renin, which generates angiotensin I.
  • In the lungs, the angiotensin-converting enzyme converts angiotensin I to angiotensin II, which stimulates an increased sympathetic drive and causes the adrenal medulla to release catecholamines. The catecholamines are responsible for the elevated glucose levels seen in hemorrhagic shock.
  • In the adrenal cortex, the zona glomerulosa produces aldosterone in response to angiotensin II, which causes increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion. Angiotensin II also has a direct effect on renal tubules, reabsorbing sodium.
  • Antidiuretic hormone is released from the pituitary, causing free water retention at the kidney's level.

Option B: There is afferent arteriolar constriction and efferent arteriolar constriction

  • GFR is maintained by prostaglandin-mediated dilatation of afferent arterioles and angiotensin II-mediated constriction of efferent arterioles.
  • Once the mean arterial pressure falls below 80mmHg, renal autoregulation fails, and GFR declines steeply.

Option C: Increased excretion of sodium by the kidneys

  • As a compensatory mechanism in hypovolemic shock, increased aldosterone concentration occurs secondary to angiotensin II, resulting in increased potassium excretion.

Option D: Increased potassium reabsorption by the kidneys

  • Increased angiotensin II concentration in hypovolemic or hemorrhagic shock results in an increased aldosterone concentration. Aldosterone causes increased absorption of sodium in the kidneys.

questions.text: You are the 2nd year PG in the surgery department assisting the chief surgeon in Exploratory laparotomy for a patient with severe abdominal trauma. The patient was successfully managed, and while closing the abdomen after a midline laparotomy, you were asked by your chief to suture the incision. What length of suture will you choose to close the incision?

choices.text: Twice the length of the incision
4 times the length of the incision
6 times the length of the incision
8 times the length of the incision

questions.solution:
Option B: 4 times the length of the incision

  • The length of the suture depends upon the type of incision.
  • For a laparotomy incision, the suture length should be 4 times the length of the incision.

Option A: Twice the length of the incision

  • For a skin suture, the length of the suture is twice the length of the wound

Option C: 6 times the length of the incision

  • This is usually done in the incision of abdominal surgeries other than laparotomy.

Option D: 8 times the length of the incision

  • This is not recommended for a laparotomy incision.

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient presents with complaints of dyspnea. He is a lifetime smoker. His pulse is 99/min, and his blood pressure is 95/66 mmHg. Examination shows swelling and redness of the face and neck. There is distention of the superficial veins of his neck and upper thorax. SVC obstruction is suspected. Chest x-ray shows mediastinal enlargement. What is the next step in establishing a diagnosis for this patient?

choices.text: Total blood count with peripheral smear

questions.solution:
Option B: CT thorax

  • SUPERIOR VENA CAVA (SVC) SYNDROME:
    • A condition caused by obstruction of blood flow in the superior vena cava (e.g., by a thrombus or external compression). This impairs venous backflow to the right atrium and results in upper venous congestion.
    • Features include a feeling of fullness in the head, dyspnea, oedema of the upper extremities, and distention of the superficial veins of the chest, face, and upper extremities.
    • The Most common cause is Lung cancer (small cell & squamous cell carcinoma), along with lymphoma and metastatic tumours responsible for more than 90% of all SVC syndrome.
    • In young adults, malignant lymphoma is the leading cause of SVC syndrome.
    • CLINICAL FEATURES:
      • Hemodynamic symptoms: Oedema of the upper extremities and face (facial plethora), the prominent venous pattern on the chest, face, and upper extremities, Jugular venous distension, Orthostatic hypotension, Syncope, and Renal failure.
      • Symptoms and signs of congestion of the neck: Dyspnea, Cough and hoarseness, Stridor, and Dysphagia
      • Neurological symptoms: Headache, Dizziness, Confusion and mental obtundation, and Visual impairmen
    • ​​​​​​​DIAGNOSIS:
      • Unstable or severely symptomatic patients: invasive venography with or without stent placement (gold standard)
      • Stable patients: 
        • ​​​​​​​CT chest with CT venography: modality of choice for most patients
        • Doppler ultrasound: initial investigation for suspected catheter-associated thrombosis

 

 

 

Option A: Total blood count with peripheral smear

  • The complete blood count is a laboratory test that measures the following:
    • Red blood cell (RBC) count
    • Haemoglobin (Hb)
    • Hematocrit (Hct)
    • Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)
    • Mean corpuscular haemoglobin (MCH)
    • Mean corpuscular haemoglobin concentration (MCHC)
    • White blood cell (WBC) count
    • Platelet count
      • A peripheral blood smear is a diagnostic test examining peripheral blood under a microscope. It can diagnose conditions that cause abnormal counts or morphology of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.
      • These tests do not have a diagnostic value for SVC syndrome.

 

Option C: Start cyclophosphamide

  • Cyclophosphamide is used in the treatment of the following malignancies:
    • Solid tumours (e.g., breast cancer, ovarian cancer, small cell lung cancer)
    • Leukemias
    • Lymphomas
    • Multiple myeloma
  • However, in the case of SVC syndrome chest CT scan is necessary to rule out the cause of obstruction causing SVC syndrome.

Option D: Urgent referral to treatment​​​​​​​

  • In stable patients of SVC syndrome, the investigation of choice is a chest CT scan used to diagnose the cause of obstruction, and after the cause of SVC obstruction is known, treatment begins.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female from a rural background presented with a history of chronic tobacco chewing since age 14. Now she has difficulty opening her mouth. On oral examination, no ulcers are seen. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Oral submucous fibrosis

  • The most probable diagnosis in the Asian female with a history of chronic tobacco chewing and difficulty in opening her mouth with no ulcers on oral examination is oral submucous fibrosis.
  • ORAL SUBMUCOUS FIBROSIS:
    • Progressive disease in which fibrous bands form beneath the oral mucosa
    • Almost confined to the Asian population
    • Risk factors:
      • Pan masala areca nut, with or without concurrent alcohol use.
      • Tobacco smoking alone is not associated with oral submucous fibrosis.
    • Pathology:
      • Characterized by epithelial fibrosis with associated atrophy & hyperplasia of the overlying epithelium.
      • Epithelium shows changes in epithelial dysplasia.
    • Clinical features: Scarring produces contracture resulting in limited mouth opening and restricted tongue movement
    • Treatment: Restricted mouth opening can be treated with either Intralesional steroids or Surgical excision and Skin grafts.

Option B: Oral hairy leukoplakia

  • Oral hairy Leukoplakia is a benign condition characterized by painless, white plaques with a feathery or hairy appearance on the lateral tongue (or, less commonly, the floor of the mouth, palate, or buccal mucosa) that cannot be scraped off.
  • It is caused by Epstein-Barr virus infection but typically only occurs in patients who are also immunocompromised.
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia (OHL), which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, manifests as white patches on the oral mucosa that cannot be wiped off with gauze, and biopsy can show marked hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis.
  • However, the lesions of OHL are typically found on the lateral surfaces of the tongue, not the gingiva, and have a hairy or feathery rather than granular texture.
  • Moreover, OHL lesions typically only manifest in immunocompromised patients, and there is no evidence of immunocompromised in this patient.

Option C: Erythroleukoplakia

  • Erythroleukoplakia is a type of nonhomogeneous oral Leukoplakia characterized by white plaques with red speckles.
  • It has a higher risk of malignant transformation than homogeneous Leukoplakia.

Option D: Trigeminal neuralgia 

  • Trigeminal neuralgia, or Tic douloureux, is a condition characterized by attacks of facial pain in the area of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve. 
  • The pain is typically very intense, sharp, and stabbing and lasts for several seconds.
  • Attacks can occur without provocation but are sometimes triggered by innocuous stimuli like chewing.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant has undergone surgical treatment for meningomyelo encephalocele. At birth, an operation was carried out in the posterior cranial fossa to partially replace cerebellar brain contents to an intracranial position, leading to the development of hydrocephalus. On investigating progressive hydrocephalus, it is noted that the cerebellar tonsils are herniated through the foramen magnum. The neurosurgeon has diagnosed the baby with a syndrome that may include which of the following?

choices.text: Fusion of the temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes
Abnormal elongation of the medulla and lower cranial nerves
Partial or complete absence of the pituitary gland

questions.solution:
Option C: Abnormal elongation of the medulla and lower cranial nerves

  • Based on the surgical history for meningo myelo encephalocele, development of progressive hydrocephalus, and herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, the most likely diagnosis is Arnold-Chiari syndrome.
  • In Arnold-Chiari syndrome, there is an abnormal elongation of the medulla and lower cranial nerves.
  • There is the displacement of the cerebellar tonsils, medulla, and the fourth ventricle into the spinal canal, sometimes with accompanying meningomyelocele. In such circumstances, the cord cavity connects with and may merely represent a dilated central canal.
  • Additional features include the fusion of the corpora quadrigemina, leading to a "beaked tectum''; the partial or complete absence of the corpus callosum; and microgyria.
  • MRI is the most useful imaging study for diagnosing Chiari malformation.
  • Patients with Chiari malformations with minimal or equivocal symptoms without syringomyelia can be treated conservatively. Mild neck pain and headaches can be treated with analgesics, muscle relaxants, and the occasional use of a soft collar. The symptomatic patients should be offered surgical treatment.
  • The goals of surgical treatment are decompression of the cervicomedullary junction and restoration of normal CSF flow in the region of the foramen magnum.

Severity

Chiari Spectrum

Dandy-Walker Spectrum

Type I - Tonsillar herniation

Mega Cisterna Magna

Type II - Brainstem and vermis herniation, lumbar myelomeningocele

Dandy-Walker variant-Mild enlargement of 4th ventricle

Type III - cerebellar herniation into cervical myelomeningocele

Dandy-walker Malformation - Massive enlargement of 4th ventricle with large posterior fossa

Type IV - Cerebellar agenesis with small posterior fossa

 

Option A: Fusion of the frontal lobes

  • Based on the diagnosis of Arnold-Chiari syndrome, a fusion of frontal lobes is unlikely.
  • Fusion of the frontal lobes is seen in the Holoprosencephaly group of structural disorders.

Option B: Fusion of the temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes

  • Based on the diagnosis of Arnold-Chiari syndrome, no fusion of the temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes will be seen.
  • In Arnold-Chiari syndrome, there is neither fusion of the frontal lobes nor the fusion of the temporal, parietal and occipital lobes.

Option D: Partial or complete absence of the pituitary gland

  • Based on the diagnosis of Arnold-Chiari syndrome, the partial or complete absence of the pituitary gland is unlikely.
  • Empty-Sella syndrome is when the pituitary gland shrinks or becomes flattened.
  • The pituitary sits inside a bony compartment in the skull's base called the sella.
  • When the pituitary gland becomes smaller or flattened, it cannot be seen on an MRI scan. This makes the area of the pituitary gland look like an "empty sella." 
  • It is often filled with cerebrospinal fluid. With empty sella syndrome, CSF drips into the sella turcica, pressurizing the pituitary gland. This causes the gland to shrink or flatten.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male was hit by an auto and got dragged on the road for a distance of 50 meters. She was brought to ER in an ambulance and got admitted. On examination, multiple abrasions were noted all over the body, and a laceration of size 6x0.5cm on her left hand. There was no fatal injury noted and hence discharged on the 3rd day. The tensile strength of all these wounds would become normal after:-
questions.solution:
The tensile strength of wound never equals that of unwounded skin

Normal wound healing involves

  • inflammatory phase
  • proliferative phase
  • remodelling phase

Inflammatory phase

  • Begins immediately and lasts 2-3 days
  • Bleeding — vasoconstriction — thrombus formation to limit blood loss
  • Rubor, Tumor, calor and dolor occurs in this phase
  • Chemotaxis and proliferation of inflammatory cells

Proliferative phase (3rd day to 3rd week )

  • Fibroblast activity with the production of collagen (type III) and ground substance
  • Angioneogenesis
  • Reepithelialisation of wound surface

Remodelling phase

  • Maturation of collagen (type I replacing type III until a ratio of 4:1 is achieved)
  • This leads to increased tensile strength in the wound which is maximal at the 12th week post injury and represents approximately 80% of the uninjured skin strength

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the medicine outpatient department with his wife with a 4-week history of progressively worsening right shoulder pain radiating down his right arm and into his upper back. He has also reported blurred vision in his right eye and felt his right eyelid was 'drooping'. His only other history, of note, is being an ex-smoker with a 25-pack-year history. He also reported that he had recently been to the gym and noticed only the left side of his face was sweating. Examination reveals partial ptosis of the right eye, a constricted right pupil, and reduced sensation in the right T1 dermatome. A chest radiograph is performed and shows the following finding (image). What will be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pancoast tumour

  • The given Chest X-ray shows a tumour in the lung apices
  • Clinical signs-- progressively worsening right shoulder pain radiating down the right arm and into the upper back, sweating on the face, and ptosis; all these indicate the Pancoast tumour of the lung.
  • A Pancoast tumour is an apical tumour typically found in conjunction with a history of smoking tobacco.
  • The clinical signs and symptoms may be mistaken for neurovascular compromise at the level of the superior thoracic aperture.
  • The patient's smoking history, rapid onset of clinical signs and symptoms, and pleuritic pain suggest an apical tumour.
  • A Pancoast tumour can give rise to both Pancoast syndrome and Horner's syndrome.
  • When the brachial plexus roots are involved, it will produce Pancoast syndrome; involvement of sympathetic fibres as they exit the cord at the T1 level and ascend to the superior cervical ganglion will produce Horner's syndrome

Option A: Horner's syndrome

  • A constricting pupil (miosis), drooping of the upper eyelid (ptosis), an absence of facial sweat (anhidrosis), and sinking of the eyeball into the bone chamber that covers the eye are all signs of Horner syndrome (enophthalmos).

Option C: Larynx CA

  • Laryngopharyngeal cancer symptoms:
    • A modification in voice, such as a raspy tone
    • Swallowing discomfort or a challenge
    • A growth or lump in the neck
    • A persistent cough or shortness of breath
    • A prolonged headache or sore throat
    • A loud wheezing sound was made during breathing
    • In extreme circumstances, respiratory problems

Option D: Superior vena cava syndrome

  • When blood flow via the superior vena cava (SVC) is impeded, several issues are known as superior vena cava syndrome (SVCs).
  • A sizable vein called the SVC carries blood from the head, neck, arms, and upper chest to the heart. The majority of patients with SVCs have cancer.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male patient presented with complaints of pain, fatigue, and paresthesia in his left arm for the last nine months. The patient also had dizziness for the past six months, which worsen with upper-extremity activity or exercise. The patient had a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus. On physical examination, there is a systolic bruit in the left supraclavicular fossa. Vital signs are include blood pressure of 160/90 mm Hg, pulse pressure of 65/min and respiration rate of 18/min. Coronal magnetic resonance is ordered, which reveals the following finding as shown in the image:



 What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Subclavian steal syndrome

  • This is a case of subclavian steal syndrome with pain, fatigue, paresthesia in the left arm, dizziness, disequilibrium, and supraclavicular bruit.
  • It occurs due to atherosclerosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery, leading to a reversal of blood flow in the ipsilateral vertebral artery.
  • Diagnosis
    • Doppler ultrasound
    • Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA)
  • Treatment
    • Lipid-lowering intervention
    • Smoking cessation
    • Stent placement in some cases

Option A: Angina

  •  Angina is chest pain due to ischemic myocardium secondary to coronary artery narrowing or spasm.
  •  Atherosclerosis is the most common risk factor and doesn't lead to cardiac myocyte necrosis.
  • ECG findings are ST depression (stable angina), transient ST elevation (vasospastic angina) and ST depression and T wave inversion (unstable angina)

Option C: Aortic dissection

  • Aortic dissection is an intima tear that occurs in the proximal 10 cm of the aorta with pre-existing weakness of tunica media.
  • It is associated with risk factors like a bicuspid aortic valve, hypertension, Marfan syndrome, and cocaine use.

Option D: Heart failure

  • Heart failure is a failure of the cardiac pump that presents with shortness of breath, orthopnea, fatigue, crackles, S3 heart sound, jugular venous distention, and pitting edema.
  • Left heart failure is caused by hypertension, myocardial infarction, ischemia, and dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • A right heart is caused by left heart failure, chronic lung disease (leads to cor pulmonale)

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presents with large bulging veins in her bilateral extremities along with tiredness, heaviness, and throbbing pain in the lower legs. A duplex Ultrasound examination shows an underlying feeding vein that was directly feeding the surface varicose veins in the thigh. Which of the following drugs can be used for sclerotherapy of varicose veins?
questions.solution:
Option B: Polidocanol

  • Sclerosing agents (Polidocanol) are irritants that cause inflammation, coagulation, and, ultimately, fibrosis when injected into haemorrhoids or varicose veins.
  • These can be used only for local injection.

Option A: Metandienone

  • Metandienone is an androgen and anabolic steroid which is used for bulky cycles.
  • It is contraindicated in varicose veins because it can cause a recurrence of the varicose veins.

Option C: Ethanol

  • Ethanol is an alcohol.
  • As Ethanol worsen the symptoms of varicose veins, so it is contraindicated.

Option D: Oxandrolone

  • Oxandrolone is an anabolic steroid which is used to gain weight.
  • Varicose veins can also be caused by steroids, so Oxandrolone is contraindicated in varicose veins.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child is referred to the pediatric department in the with complaints of an distended abdomen, dribbling of urine with overflow incontinence. On physical examination, there is only a palpable and distended bladder up to the umbilicus with no other abnormalities. A urinary catheterization was performed, which drained 350 mL of clear urine, with immediate relief of the symptoms. This condition in a male child may be due to the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : Option D: Meatal ulcer with scabbing

  • In the above-given case, the presence of an enlarged bladder, dribbling urine, and distended bladder up to the umbilicus is suggestive of the diagnosis of acute urinary retention.
  • Acute urinary retention in a male child may be due to local inflammatory causes like a meatal ulcer with scabbing.

 

Aetiology of urinary retention in children
  • Neurological processes (17%)
  • Severe voiding dysfunction (15%)
  • UTI (13%)
  • Constipation (13%)
  • Adverse drug effect (13%)
  • Local inflammatory causes (7%)
  • Locally invading neoplasms (6%)
  • Benign obstructing lesions (6%)
  • Idiopathic (6%)
  • Combined UTI and constipation (2%)
  • Incarcerated inguinal hernia (2%)

 

Option A: Prostatic radiotherapy

  • Prostatic brachytherapy can lead to swelling of the urethra.
  • The swelling may cause blockage of the urethra, which can lead to urinary retention.
  • Prostatic radiotherapy may not lead to urinary retention in children.

Option B: Urethral stricture

  • Urinary strictures are rare in children.
  • Urinary strictures are associated with sudden urinary retention in adults.

Option C: Hysteria

  • Hysteria is not the common cause of urinary retention in children.
  • Urinary retention can be caused by mechanical obstruction in children.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the Gynecology emergency department with complaints of right-sided abdominal pain associated with vomiting for the last 2 hours. She is G2P1+0 and has gestational amenorrhea of 8 weeks. She has no previous significant gynecology history. Her examination reveals a tender iliac fossa associated with guarding and rebound tenderness. Her urine analysis shows leukocytosis, and an ultrasound abdomen suggests acute appendicitis. Which of the following is true regarding appendicitis in pregnancy?

choices.text: The most common cause is acute abdomen in the first trimester
Conservative management by antibiotics should be tried
After rupture, fetal mortality is around 1%

questions.solution:
Option A: The most common cause is acute abdomen in the first trimester

  • The patient is most likely suffering from acute appendicitis. It is the most common cause of acute abdomen in the first trimester.
  • Appendicitis in a pregnant patient remains the most common non-obstetric emergency.
  • It occurs in 1 in 800 to 1 in 1000 pregnancies, mostly in the first and second trimesters.
  • Pregnancy may alter the disease's presentation and laboratory values like WBC count (leukocytosis as high as 16000 cells/L is common in pregnancy), making diagnosis difficult.
  • Its symptoms typically consist of right lateral abdominal pain, nausea, and anorexia, yet typical presentation accounts for only 50% to 60% of cases.
  • The point of maximum tenderness is usually displaced on physical examination.
  • Ultrasonography is the preferred imaging modality, although non-visualization can occur.
  • In pregnant patients, plain MRI can be used alternatively for diagnosis.
  • For suspects at any stage of pregnancy, an early appendectomy is the best option.

Option B: Pregnancy increases the risk

  • Pregnancy does not increase the risk of getting acute appendicitis.
  • Risk during pregnancy is the same as in non-pregnant women of the same age. However, pregnancy may alter the disease's presentation and laboratory values.

Option C: Conservative management by antibiotics should be tried

  • In the case of non-operative management, treatment failure rates have been reported to be as high as 25%.
  • Hence, early appendectomy is the appropriate therapy for suspected during all stages of pregnancy.

Option D: After rupture, fetal mortality is around 1%

  • The risk of fetal loss is up to 36% if appendiceal perforation occurs.

questions.text: What would be the management of a middle-aged female with three finger test revealing positive cough impulse in the femoral region?
questions.solution:
Option D: McVay repair

  • Given the clinical scenario and examination findings, the patient most likely suffers from an inguinal hernia and femoral ring defects.
  • In such cases, McVay repair is indicated.
  • McVay repair addresses both inguinal and femoral ring defects.
  • The McVay repair uses autologous tissue to close the inguinal canal floor.
  • McVay repair is shown in the picture below:

  • It is indicated for femoral hernia and where prosthetic material is contraindicated.
  • After reaching the preperitoneal space, the superior transversalis flap is fastened to the cooper's ligament to occlude the femoral ring.

Option A: Bassini repair

  • This procedure is done for inguinal hernia only. It is a triple-layer repair.
  • Internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and transversalis fascia are fixed to the inguinal ligament and pubic periosteum with interrupted suture.

Option B: Hunters repair

  • Hunter's repair does flexor tender reconstruction.
  • It is not indicated in treating inguinal and femoral ring defects.

Option C: Shouldice repair

  • This is indicated for inguinal hernia repair.
  • It is a four-layer repair for an inguinal hernia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the surgical emergency department with acute abdominal pain for the past 2 hours. He is immediately taken up for emergency laparotomy. Resection of the bowel with ileostomy is done. Examination of the specimen reveals a segmental disease with aphthous ulcers and non-caseating granulomas with Langerhans giant cells. What diagnostic modality is most commonly used to diagnose the above clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Option A:

CT enteroclysis

  • It is the primary diagnostic tool but not most commonly used for diagnosing Crohn's disease.

 

​​​​​Option B:

Colonoscopy

  • The given clinical condition is Crohn’s disease.
  • Colonoscopy reveals focal ulceration adjacent to areas of normal mucosa, giving a cobblestone appearance.

Option C: Capsule endoscopy

  • Capsule endoscopy is not used for diagnosing Crohn's disease.

Option D: CECT

  • CECT is not used for diagnosing Crohn's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is most likely related to postoperative ileus?

choices.text: The use of intravenous patient-controlled analgesia does not affect the return of small bowel motor activity
The presence of peritonitis at the time of the original operation delays the return of normal bowel function
The routine use of metoclopramide will hasten the return of small intestinal motor activity
Contrast radiographic studies have no role in distinguishing early postoperative bowel obstruction from normal ileus

questions.solution:
Option B: The presence of peritonitis at the time of the original operation delays the return of normal bowel function

  • When there is peritonitis along with ileus, the recovery is delayed.
  • An ileus is defined as intestinal distension and the slowing or absence of passage of luminal contents without a demonstrable mechanical obstruction
  • Causes of ileus
    • After laparotomy
    • Metabolic and electrolyte derangements (Hypokalemia, Hyponatremia, Hypomagnesemia, Uremia, Diabetic coma)
    • Drugs (Opiates, Psychotropic drugs, Anticholinergics, Calcium channel blockers, Tricyclic antidepressants)
    • Infection (Intra abdominal inflammation, Systemic sepsis, Peritonitis, Pneumonia)
    • Retroperitoneal inflammation or hemorrhage
    • Mesenteric ischemia
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Ureteral colic
    • Spinal cord injury
    • Myocardial infarction
  • Among the proposed mechanisms responsible for postoperative ileus are Surgical stress-induced sympathetic reflexes, Inflammatory response mediator release, and Anesthetic/analgesic side effects, each of which can inhibit intestinal motility. The use of intravenous patient-controlled analgesia may delay the recovery of postoperative ileus compared to the IM route of narcotic administration.
  • Normal motility returns generally follow a characteristic temporal sequence, with small intestinal motility returning to normal within the first 24 hours after laparotomy and gastric and colonic motility returning to normal by 48 hours and 3 to 5 days, respectively. Because small bowel motility returns before colonic and gastric motility, listening for bowel sounds is not a reliable indicator that the ileus has fully resolved
  • The typical and most notable clinical feature is abdominal distension without the usual colicky abdominal pain. Nausea and vomiting may or may not occur. Patients with ileus continue to pass flatus and diarrhea, which may help distinguish these patients from those with a mechanical small bowel obstruction
  • Plain radiographs may reveal distended small bowel as well as large bowel loops. In the postoperative setting, CT scanning is the test of choice because it can demonstrate the presence of an intraabdominal abscess or other evidence of peritoneal sepsis that may be causing ileus and can exclude the presence of complete mechanical obstruction
  • The treatment of ileus is entirely supportive, with nasogastric decompression and IV fluids. There has been little success in using prokinetic agents to shorten recovery times after lower abdominal procedures.
  • Measures to reduce postoperative ileus
    • Intraoperative measures
      • Minimize handling of the bowel
      • Laparoscopic approach, if possible
      • Avoid excessive intraoperative fluid administration
    • Postoperative measures
      • Correct electrolyte abnormalities
      • Early enteral feeding
      • Epidural anesthesia, if indicated
      • Avoid excessive intravenous fluid administration
      • Consider mu-opioid antagonists

Option A: The use of intravenous patient-controlled analgesia does not affect the return of small bowel motor activity

  • Intravenous analgesia increases the chances of a drug overdose.
  • But adequate pain control is an effective method to restore bowel activity.

Option C: The routine use of metoclopramide will hasten the return of small intestinal motor activity

  • Routine use of metoclopramide is not recommended.
  • Although it is a promotility drug.
  • There are several adverse effects, such as movement disorders which are associated with the regular use of metoclopramide

Option D: Contrast radiographic studies have no role in distinguishing early postoperative bowel obstruction from normal ileus

  • Contrast CT is the best test for differentiating early postoperative bowel obstruction from normal ileus.

questions.text: A  chronic pancreatitis patient who is a chronic alcoholic presents with abdominal pain radiating to the back that does not respond to analgesics. On evaluation, the pancreatic duct was dilated, and multiple stones were noted in the pancreatic duct. ERCP was performed, but the patient remained symptomatic. Which is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pancreaticojejunostomy

  • In the case history above, the patient has intractable pain with pancreatic dilatation. The ERCP was performed, but still, the patient was symptomatic with pain. The best treatment option for this case is Pancreaticojejunostomy through Puestow's procedure
  • The surgery involves creating a longitudinal incision along the pancreas while the main pancreatic duct is filleted open longitudinally from the head of the organ to its tail. The duct and pancreas are then attached to the jejunum (Pancreaticojejunostomy), which is overseen to the exposed pancreatic duct to allow drainage. When used in the appropriate setting, pain from chronic pancreatitis can improve


Option A: Pancreatic tail resection

  • Pancreatic tail resection, which is the distal pancreatectomy, is done in patients with a nondilated pancreatic duct, but it is done when drainage with Pancreaticojejunostomy with frey's procedure is not possible as it is a complicated surgery and can have many complications

Option C: Percutaneous removal of stone

  • Percutaneous removal of stone through endoscopy is a new procedure done to give relief to symptomatic patients, but in this patient, ERCP is already done, and it failed to give results, so permanent drainage through Pancreaticojejunostomy is the better option in this case

Option D: Medical management

  • Medical management through pain relief medications and enzyme replacement therapy is the first line of treatment for patients with chronic pancreatitis, but this patient is not responsive to analgesics and needs further treatment

questions.text: You are a third-year resident in the surgery department. During a sphincterotomy procedure for sphincter of Oddi dysfunction, the chief surgeon passes on the surgical blade to you and tells you to continue the procedure. To minimize the chance of pancreatic duct injury during surgery, you should make the incision at which of the following positions in the ampulla?
questions.solution:
Option D: 11 o’clock position

  • Sphincterotomy is performed from 10 to 11 o’clock position. 
  • Placing the incision at this location in the ampulla minimizes the chance of pancreatic duct injury, which is generally located opposite the planned sphincterotomy site.

Option A: 3 o’clock position

  • Incision at the 3 o’clock position increases the risk of pancreatic duct injury.

Option B: 6 o’clock position

  • Incision at the 6 o’clock position increases the risk of pancreatic duct injury.

Option C: 9 o’clock position

  • Incision at the 9 o’clock position increases the risk of pancreatic duct injury.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man with a history of end-stage renal disease from focal segmental glomerulosclerosis was managed solely with steroid therapy until he underwent a living-unrelated donor kidney transplant after a progressive deterioration in renal function. The most probable malignancy that can occur in this individual post-transplant is :
questions.solution:
COMPLICATIONS OF IMMUNOSUPPRESSION
INFECTION MALIGNANCY NON-IMMUNE SIDE EFFECTS
  • High risk of infection by virusesQ (CMV InfectionQ)during first 6 months
  • Recipient derived infectionsQare more common than donor derived infections
  • Bacterial infection- during first monthQ
  • Polyoma BK virus is associated with a progressive nephropathy and Ureteral obstruction
  • JC virus has been found to be associated with progressive multimodal leukoencephalopathy
  • Chemoprophylaxis is important in high risk patients
  • Pre-transplant vaccination against community acquired infection should be considered
  • MC malignancy in transplant recipient: Skin cancerQ (SCC)
  • Increased risk of PTLD & Kaposi sarcoma and other virally mediated tumours
  • Hypertension & chronic allograft nephropathy-Calcineurin inhibitorsQ
  • New onset diabetes - Tacrolimus or steroidsQ
  • Hyperlipidemia, anemia & accelerated cardiovascular diseaseQ
  • Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death in transplant survivorsQ

questions.text: A 21-year-old male is brought to the emergency ward after slipping while catching the ball in a cricket match. He is in severe pain. Upon further investigation, there is tibial torsion secondary to the fall. Which of the following will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Lateral patellar subluxation

  • In the given case scenario, there will be increased Q-angle
  • An increase in Q angle predisposes the patella to lateral overload and makes it prone to subluxate or dislocate laterally.
  • Q angle provides a lateral vector to the patella and is a line between Quadriceps and the Patellar tendon.

Q-angle:

  • Measured by an angle between two lines
  • From ASIS to the middle of the patella
  • Middle of the patella to the tibial tuberosity
  • It is best measured at 30° of knee flexion to the center patella in the trochlea.
  • Its value is higher in females (about 15°) than in males (8-10°).
  • Vastus medialis balances this lateral vector, especially vastus medialis obliquus.

Option A: Medial patellar subluxation

  • Medial patellar subluxation is not related to the given scenario.
  • Q angle is not increased in medial patellar subluxation

Option C: Superior patellar subluxation

  • Q angle is not increased in superior patellar subluxation

Option D: Inferior patellar subluxation

  • Inferior patellar subluxation is not related to tibial torsion.
  • Q angle is not increased in inferior patellar subluxation

questions.text: A 23-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with a complaint of severe upper neck pain for the last 1 hour. He was practicing for the national level swimming competition and dived perpendicularly to the surface of the swimming pool resulting in an injury to the head. Vital signs are within normal limits. CT scan of the head is ordered, which reveals an un-displaced C1 ring fracture. Which of the following is the next best step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Rigid cervical collar

  • The application of a rigid cervical collar is the first management step for burst fractures.
  • Jefferson fracture is a burst fracture of the ring of the atlas (C1) vertebrae.
  • It occurs due to vertical compression force.
  • It is a combined fracture of anterior and posterior arches.
  • It can present with:
    • Pain
    • Restriction in neck movement
    • Hematoma
    • Neurological deficits
  • Two types depending on stability:
  • Stable fractures: Anterior column fracture without any compromise in the stability of the spine
  • Unstable fractures: Posterior column fracture and spinal cord injury are common, and neurological deficits are usually present.

Management of burst fractures:

  • If it is undisplaced, the injury is stable, and the patient wears a semi-rigid collar or halo-vest until the fracture unites.
  • Management is conservative or surgical, depending upon the stability of the fracture.

Option A: Atlanto axial fusion

  • The application of a rigid cervical collar is the first management step for burst fractures.
  • If there is persisting instability on the x-ray, a posterior C1/2 fixation and fusion are needed.

Option C: Reduction by halo traction

  • Unstable burst fractures need to be treated with halo traction.

Option D: None of the above

  • The application of a rigid cervical collar is the first management step for burst fractures.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male came to the hospital with complaints of throbbing, painful swelling in his forearm. On physical examination, the patient is febrile. The patient has a past medical history of appendicitis and is not allergic to any medication. Blood examination reveals raised ESR & total leukocyte count. Biopsy of the swelling revealed that it arises from the endothelial cells in the bone marrow and was found positive for the mic-2 gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ewing's sarcoma

  • This is a case of Ewing’s sarcoma in which the patient presents with complaints of throbbing and painful swelling of the forearm.
  • Ewing sarcoma is a round-cell tumor with positive glycogen cells
  • Associated with trisomy 8 and trisomy 12
  • It is usually difficult to differentiate it from osteomyelitis since it typically presents as a systemic illness with fever, elevated TLC, and ESR.
  • The classic cytogenetic abnormality associated with Ewing's sarcoma is a reciprocal translocation of the long arms of chromosomes 11 and 22, t(11;22).
  • The features that differentiate Ewing's sarcoma from osteomyelitis were:
    • Sequestrum
    • Well-defined cloacae and a rather smooth periosteal reaction.
    • Located at the metaphysis.
  • Other features suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma in this question are:
    • Mid-thigh describing a diaphyseal tumor
    • Throbbing painful swelling
    • Swelling arises from endothelial cells.

Option A: Osteomyelitis

  • Metaphysis of the long bone is the earliest and most common site involved in osteomyelitis.
  • The most common cause is a bacterial infection, such as staphylococcus.
  • It causes swelling, pain, and tenderness at the infected site.

Option B: Osteosarcoma

  • Osteosarcoma is usually a metaphyseal lesion.
  • It is a malignant tumor that mostly occurs in long bones.
  • It is radiation-induced sarcoma (after 10-15 years of radiotherapy).
  • It is a radio-resistant bone tumor.

Option D: Chondrosarcoma

  • Chondrosarcomas can arise as a transformation of malignant enchondroma or of the cartilaginous osteochondroma.
  • Chondrosarcomas presents with severe pain, a large lump on infected bone, feelings of pressure around the lump, and stiffness of the joint.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male comes to the clinic with severe pain in the right foot for the past 1 day. He has recently been recruited into the paramilitary force and has been undergoing intense physical training. Temperature is 37°C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 62 per minute. Examination reveals tenderness over the second metatarsal of the right foot. Passive movement of the second metatarsal produces pain. When asked to stand up, the patient is able to bear weight on the right foot. An X-ray is taken and is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Fatigue fracture

  • The patient described in the above scenario most likely has a fatigue fracture of the second metatarsal bone of the right foot.
  • Fatigue fractures result from prolonged or repetitive stress and are common in athletes, long-distance runners, or military personnel (also known as march fractures) who are subjected to intense physical activity and prolonged standing. Fatigue fractures most commonly occur in the weight-bearing bones of the lower extremities, such as the tibia, fibula, metatarsal, or navicular bones.
  • Patients usually present with pain that increases with activity and relieves with rest.
  • The examination may reveal crepitus or point tenderness over the point of fracture.
  • Most of the patients are able to bear weight on the affected foot.
  • X-rays should be obtained as an initial diagnostic test, although MRI is the investigative modality of choice.
  • Most stress fractures heal spontaneously, so treatment revolves around rest, symptomatic treatment, and rehabilitation.
  • Runner fracture is a type of stress fracture which is happens in the lower tibia or fibula not in the foot. If it happens in the foot it is called March fracture.

Option A: Metastatic bone disease

  • Metastatic bone disease is a common complication of certain cancers such as multiple myeloma, prostate cancer, and breast cancer, etc. bone fractures often occur as a result.
  • This patient does not have any history of cancer, and X-ray findings are consistent with a fatigue fracture.

Option B: Pathological fracture

  • A pathological fracture refers to the fracture of the bone without significant trauma.
  • Vertebral bodies (thoracic and lumbar) are the most often affected bones, followed by the neck of the femur and the lower end of the radius (collie's fracture).
  • Common causes of pathological fractures are osteoporosis, metastasis, and nutritional deficiency.

Option C: Osteoporosis

  • Osteoporosis most commonly results due to increased bone resorption related to decreased estrogen levels and old age.
  • Other causes include the use of certain drugs (such as steroids, alcohol, and anti-epileptic agents) or medical conditions such as hyperparathyroidism, hyperthyroidism, or malabsorption syndromes.
  • Osteoporosis can lead to compression fractures of the vertebrae.
  • This patient does not have any risk factors related to the development of osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese female with symptomatic cholelithiasis is planned for laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anaesthesia. She had a previous history of lumpectomy in the right breast under general anaesthesia and severe nausea and vomiting in the post-operative ward. The patient was induced with Inj. Propofol 200 mg and endotracheal intubation facilitated with Inj. Succinylcholine. Anaesthesia was maintained with oxygen/nitrous oxide, sevoflurane, and vecuronium. Intraoperative analgesia with 150 micrograms of fentanyl was given. The intraoperative and postoperative course was uneventful. Inj. Tramadol was used for analgesia in the post-operative ward. The patient complained of nausea and vomiting in the postoperative ward, which was treated with Inj. Ondansetron 4mg IV. Which risk factor predicts postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) in this patient?

choices.text: Inj. propofol as the induction agent

questions.solution:
Option A: Female gender

  • The patient has a previous history of having postoperative nausea and vomiting after her lumpectomy under general anaesthesia.
  • She is likely to develop the same complaint this time.
  • Female gender is one of the most important risk factors for postoperative nausea and vomiting.
  • The term postoperative nausea and vomiting is typically used to describe nausea and vomiting or retching in the post-anaesthesia care unit or the immediate 24 postoperative hours. 
  • Other risk factors include non-smokers and post-operative use of opioids.
  • The cause of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) is the complex mechanical and chemical interactions between the brain (vomiting centre, chemoreceptor trigger centre and middle ear) and gastrointestinal tract.
  • Treatment of postoperative nausea and vomiting includes anticholinergics, NK 1 receptor antagonists, corticosteroids, antihistamines, phenothiazines, butyrophenones, prokinetics, serotonin receptor antagonists and vasopressors.

Option B: Inj. Propofol as the induction agent

  • Propofol is an induction agent that reduces the chance of postoperative nausea and vomiting.
  • It has strong antiemetic properties.

Option C: Smoking

  • Smokers are at less risk of developing post-operative nausea and vomiting.

Option D: Obesity

  • Postoperative nausea and vomiting are unrelated to the patient's body mass index.

questions.text: A 35-year-old obese male who is a case of gynaecomastia planned for webster's procedure under general anaesthesia. After the induction of anaesthesia with Inj.Thiopentone sodium, the reservoir bag collapsed. Guedel's airway was inserted, the oxygen flush valve was activated, and the patient was ventilated and intubated. No other leaks were found in the anaesthesia machine. Which of the following is correct about oxygen flush?

choices.text: Delivery of a flow between 25 and 50 L/minute
Barotrauma and awareness during Anaesthesia, if accidentally activated
Activation if the master switch is on
Delivery of oxygen at 30 psi pressure

questions.solution:
Option B: Barotrauma and awareness during Anaesthesia, if accidentally activated

  • If the oxygen flush valve is accidentally activated, then high pressure of oxygen is delivered to the lung tissues causing a rapid expansion of the lungs, which can cause lung trauma (barotrauma).
  • The oxygen flush valve can deliver flow between 35 to 75 L /minute, depending on the machine and operating pressure (minimum flow is 35 L/minute), directly to the patient's breathing circuit to overcome the circuit leaks or to rapidly increase inhaled oxygen concentration and it bypasses the anaesthetic vaporizers.
  • It can be activated regardless of whether the master switch is turned on or off.
  • A direct tubing connecting the pressure regulator to the O2 flush directs high unmetered flow directly to the common gas outlet.
  • It comes under the components of an intermediate pressure system.
  • Its main use is during mask ventilation, with many leaks between the mask and the patient's face, especially in elderly patients and patients with difficult airways. It is also an acceptable power source for jet ventilation for providing partial, if not total, ventilatory support in most clinical situations.

Option A: Delivery of a flow between 25 and 50 L/minute

  • Delivery of an oxygen flow occurs between 35 and 75 L/minute.

Option C: Activation if the master switch is on

  • The oxygen flush valve is activated regardless of whether the master switch is off or on.

Option D: Delivery of oxygen at 30 psi pressure

  • Delivery of oxygen pressure occurs at 55 to 60 psi pressure.

questions.text: A 47-year-old chronic smoker and alcoholic is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident and sustained an injury to the right upper limb. This patient was planned for open reduction and internal fixation with plating for bone fracture under the brachial plexus block. Injection of 2% lignocaine and bupivacaine 0.5% were used for brachial plexus block, and the intraoperative course was uneventful. The patient could not move his right upper limb for more than 12 hours. The reason behind this could be:
questions.solution:
Option A: Liver Cirrhosis

  • This is a case of a road traffic accident in which the patient presents with complaints of an injury to the right upper limb.
  • Severe liver disease may slow the clearance of amino amide local anaesthetics, and significant drug levels may therefore accumulate, and their effects persist.
  • Dose reduction is necessary for hepatic dysfunction.
  • Bupivacaine and lidocaine are both amino amide local anaesthetics.
  • Amide local anaesthetics undergo varying metabolism rates by microsomal enzymes located primarily in the liver.
  • The initial step is the conversion of amide based to amino carboxylic acid under cyclic aniline derivative.
  • Complete metabolism involves hydroxylation of the aniline moiety and N-dealkylation of the amino carboxylic acid.
  • Ester local anaesthetics undergo hydrolysis by cholinesterase enzyme principally in the plasma and, to a lesser extent, in the liver.
  • The exception to hydrolysis of ester local anaesthetics in the plasma is cocaine which undergoes significant metabolism in the liver.

Option B: Acute renal failure

  • Because of the high morbidity and mortality in acute renal failure, only lifesaving surgery should be undertaken in these patients.
  • The renal disease may slow the clearance of vecuronium and rocuronium, so dose adjustment is necessary.

Option C: Pseudocholinesterase deficiency

  • Psedocholinestrase is also known as plasma cholinesterase. It catalyses the hydrolysis of esters of choline.
  • In patients with pseudocholinesterase deficiency, the following drugs should be avoided: succinylcholine, mivacurium, procaine, and benzocaine.

Option D: Chronic renal failure

  • Lignocaine and bupivacaine can safely be given in patients with chronic renal disease as they are metabolised through the liver.
  • A drug that should be avoided in chronic kidney failure is methoxyflurane.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male undergoes Whipple's procedure under general anaesthesia to manage periampullary carcinoma of the pancreas. At the end of the procedure, neuromuscular monitoring shows profound neuromuscular blockade. Which of the following agents can be used to reverse the neuromuscular side effects experienced by this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Sugammadex

  • Sugammadex acts as a selective reversal binding agent for rocuronium, vecuronium, and pancuronium, which were most probably used in this patient to provide neuromuscular blockade during the procedure.
  • Residual paralysis can occur after general anaesthesia, and the patient may be unconscious, unable to breathe adequate tidal volume, and show signs of motor weakness and desaturation.
  • Several crude tests have been suggested to evaluate neuromuscular block, including:
    • Head lift for 5 secs
    • Tongue protrusion
    • Hand grip
    • Ability to lift legs off the bed

Option A: Naloxone

  • It is a nonselective antagonist at all three opioid receptors and is used in managing opioid overdose.

Option B: Flumazenil

  • It is a selective competitive benzodiazepine antagonist used to manage benzodiazepine overdose.

Option C: Phentolamine

  • It is a reversible alpha-1 receptor antagonist and can be used to manage a hypertensive crisis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man reported mild swelling and pain in the left zygomatic region. The patient was a known diabetic who was under medication. He had a habit of smoking cigarettes for the past 15 years. The clinical examination revealed a firm swelling in the left zygomatic region measuring approximately 3 cm to 5 cm. It was mildly painful on palpation. A palpable left submandibular lymph node was also tender and fixed. He is referred to the radiological department for an X-ray of the maxillary sinus. Which of the following is the most appropriate view to visualise the maxillary sinus?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Water’s view

Figure 1 Water's view

  • An angled posteroanterior radiograph of the skull with the patient looking slightly upwards is known as the occipitomental (OM) or Waters view.
  • In addition to facial fractures, it can be used to check for blowout fractures of the orbit.
  • It is the view of choice for visualizing the maxillary sinus.

Option B: Caldwell’s view

Figure 2 Caldwell’s view

  • Caldwell's view is a caudally angled radiograph, and its posteroanterior projection exposes the orbits to the least amount of radiation possible.
  • The paranasal sinuses, particularly the frontal sinus, are easier to visualize at this angle.
  • Assessing four inflammatory disorders, including sinusitis, secondary osteomyelitis, and sinus polyps or cysts might be helpful.
  • This view is the best for visualizing the frontal sinus.

Option C: Lateral skull view

  • A non-angled lateral radiograph of the skull is called the lateral skull view.
  • This view does not try to highlight any one area of the skull; rather, it gives a general overview of the complete skull.
  • In addition to evaluating for neoplastic alterations and Paget disease, this projection is also utilized to check for skull fractures.
  • A horizontal beam lateral projection in a trauma situation may show air-fluid levels in the first sphenoid sinus, a sign of a basal skull fracture.
  • This view is also helpful in visualizing the sella turcica, sphenoid sinus, and nose fractures.

Option D: Rhese view

  • The optic canal can be visualized by using the Rhese view of the X-ray.
  • In this view, the patient is positioned with the orbit to be studied such that the cassette should be touched by the zygoma, nose, and chin.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presented with a six-month history of global headaches, loss of balance, and a change in facial sensation. Central nervous system examination revealed reduced sensation on the left side, a GCS of 15/15, and all other cranial nerves were otherwise normal. Contrast-enhanced CT scans revealed an intracranial lesion at the CPA angle. On further evaluation, MR Spectroscopy showed an alanine peak . What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Alanine Peak on MRS is seen at 1.4 ppm in Meningioma
  • Meningiomas also show choline peak at 3.2 ppm.
  • Glutamate-glutamine (Glx, peak at 2.1-2.6 ppm) and Glutathione (GSH, peak at 2.95 ppm) may be more specific potential markers in meningioma.

Figure: Alanine peak in Meningioma

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for the last 3 days. He has had a history of similar episodes for the preceding two months. He has abdominal distention and tenderness. An upright abdominal radiograph demonstrates multiple air-fluid levels in the small bowel. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography demonstrates a dilated small bowel loop and a mass at the ileocecal valve. His histopathological examination revealed an ulcer with caseating granulomas and giant cells. On Barium enema, gooseneck deformity is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ileocecal TB:

  • The most likely diagnosis here is ileocecal TB.
  • Gooseneck deformity occurs due to contracted, cicatrised, pulled-up cecum and straightening of the terminal ileum.
  • The Ileocecal region is the most common site affected by gastrointestinal TB.
  • It may present with obstruction, perforation, and ileocecal mass. The Fleischner sign, also called the inverted umbrella sign, is seen in ileocecal tuberculosis. It describes a widely gaped and thickened ileocecal valve and a narrowed, ulcerated terminal ileum. It can be seen in ileocecal TB.
  • The treatment includes:
    • Anti-tuberculous therapy with a four-drug regimen for 6 to 9 months.
    • Illegal resection with end-to-end anastomosis in case of perforation.

 

Incorrect Options:  

Option A - Carcinoma Colon:

  • Colon cancer may present as blood in stools, weight loss, and tenesmus.
  • Colonoscopy with biopsy is done to rule out colon cancer.
  • The radiological hallmark of classic colon cancer is the apple core lesion.

 

Option B - Ischemic colitis:

  • Ischemic colitis is where the blood flow to the colon is temporarily reduced.
  • It may be caused due to constriction of the blood vessels supplying the colon.
  • Thumb printing is characteristic.

 

Option D - Crohn's disease:

  • Differentiating features between Ileocecal TB and Crohn's disease:
Computed tomographic features of intestinal tuberculosis and Crohn's disease 
Tuberculosis Crohn's disease 

 

  • Mural thickening without stratification 
  • Strictures concentric 
  • Fibrofatty proliferation of mesentery very rare 
  • Mesenteric inflammation but no vascular engorgement 
  • Hypodense lymph nodes with peripheral enhancement 
  • High density ascites 

 

  • Mural thickening with stratification in active inflammation 
  • Strictures eccentric
  • Fibrofatty proliferation of mesentery 
  • Hypervascular mesentery (comb sign) 
  • Mild lymphadenopathy 
  • Abscesses

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to his primary care physician due to increased urinary frequency for 3 months. He also reports nocturia but denies dysuria. He has limited fluid and caffeine consumption in the evening without much benefit. Physical examination reveals prostate enlargement with a nodular surface. The prostate is firm, non-tender, and with rubber-like consistency. The physician suspects benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH). Which of the following is not a characteristic radiologic feature of BPH?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - J-shaped or fish-hook-shaped proximal ureters:

  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia. White = bladder.
  • Dark = benign enlargement of prostate, pushing down on inferior bladder

  • BPH is the nodular enlargement of transitional and periurethral zones of the prostate gland.
  • Cystourethrograpghy shows elongated and compressed urethra.
  • Retrograde cystogram shows bladder outlet obstruction, which presents as increased trabeculations, diverticula or calculi formation.
  • J-shaped or fish-hook distal ureters are seen as the prostate enlarges and the bladder floor is elevated with trigone pushed upwards is seen on fluoroscopy.
  • Bilateral hydronephrosis with hydroureter can be seen
  • Transrectal ultrasound shows enlarged prostate (volume greater than 30mL) with well-defined mixed echogenicity nodules. Central gland is enlarged. Calcification is the enlarged gland and pseudocapsule may be seen. Post-micturition residual volume is also increased.
  • CT scan shows enlarged prostate above the symphysis pubis as an incidental finding
  • J-shaped or fish-hook-shaped proximal ureters are radiologic features of inferior vena cava compression.
  • MRI shows enlarged transition zone, heterogenous signal with low signal pseudocapsule in the periphery.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increased bladder trabeculations:

  • Increased trabeculations, diverticula or calculi formation are present in the bladder with BPH.

 

Option C - J-shaped or fish-hook-shaped distal ureters:

  • J-shaped or fish-hook-shaped distal ureters are radiologic features of BPH.

 

Option D - Bilateral hydronephrosis:

  • Back pressure due to urethral and bladder outlet obstruction causes bilateral hydronephrosis and hydroureters.

questions.text: A woman, 30 years of age P1L1 calls up her gynecologist to inform that she had intercourse the previous night and is doubtful whether the ejaculation was inside or outside the vagina. The couple has been practicing coitus interruptus for purpose of contraception. She does not want pregnancy. She has a strip of MALA d tablets with her and wants to know if she can use it now. The doctor should tell her that she should :

choices.text: Take 4 tablets stat and repeat after 12 hours
Start the strip now and take one tablet each day for 21 days
Wait for periods and follow up only if she is pregnant

questions.solution:
Option A: Take 4 tablets stat and repeat after 12 hours

  • In this case, the patient presents with unprotected intercourse and wants advice regarding emergency contraception.
  • The Mala-D tablets consist of levonorgestrel and ethinyloestradiol, an emergency contraceptive that can be used in this case.
  • The patient wants contraception within 72 hours of intercourse. Any drug regime for emergency contraception can be used.

Emergency contraceptives

  • IUCD: Can prevent implantation up till the 5th day of unprotected intercourse  
  • Progesterone-only pill: LNG 1.5 mg: can reduce tubal motility and make endometrium 'Out of Phase" for embryo implantation.
  • Combined pill: The Yuzpe regimen can prevent embryo implantation since the estrogen component makes the endometrium unreceptive.
  • Mifepristone, antiprogestin and RU 486 prevent implantation.
  • Ulipristal acetate: SPRM: Selective progesterone receptor modulator
  • OCP containing 50 mcg of EE, used as an emergency contraceptive; the dose is 2 tablets stat (as soon as possible within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse) and repeats after 12 hours.
  • However, the content of Mala-D is 30 mcg of EE. Therefore a double dose is recommended, that is, 4 tablets stat and 4 after 12 hours. The total dose of EE required here is 200 mcg.

 

Option B: Start the strip now and take one tablet each day for 21 days

  • OCPs must be started from day 1 to day 5 of each cycle and taken without a break regularly to prevent pregnancy.
  • Here the day of cycle is not mentioned hence routine way of taking OCPs cannot surely prevent a pregnancy and emergency contraception is indicated as intercourse has already happened.

 

Option C: Take mifepristone + misoprostol

  • It is an incorrect option because these drugs are used to cause an early abortion and not contraception.

 

Option D: Wait for periods and follow up only if she is pregnant

  • The patient should not be advised to wait for periods as pregnancy can occur as the method of coitus interruptus appears to have failed here.
  • The patient should have emergency contraceptives within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with complaints of frequency, urgency and a sense of incomplete evacuation for 1 year. She is non-diabetic. Her past ultrasounds, urine examination, and high vaginal swab cultures have no pathology. On pelvic examination, there is no significant vaginal discharge. Cystoscopy is normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Urethral syndrome

  • Urethral syndrome is a complex symptom including dysuria, frequency, urgency, suprapubic discomfort, post-void fullness and dyspareunia in the absence of any abnormality of the urethra or bladder.
  • The cause is uncertain and is attributed to subclinical infection, urethral obstruction, and psychogenic and allergic factors.
  • It is a diagnosis of exclusion after ruling out UTI, malignancy, and vulvovaginitis. Cystoscopy to rule out urethral diverticulum, stones and malignancy.
  • Management: a multidisciplinary approach, antibiotics for sterile pyuria. Postmenopausal women may benefit from local estrogen, physical therapy, cognitive-behavioural therapy and psychological support.
  • Asymptomatic bacteriuria is ruled out with everyday urine culture, cystitis with normal urine r/m, c/s, and USG.

 

Option B: Asymptomatic bacteriuria

  • Patients with asymptomatic bacteriuria do not present with urine symptoms of infection, but investigations may reveal leukocytosis, and culture may reveal the growth of the infectious organism.

Option C: Vulvovaginitis

  • It is an inflammation or irritation of the vulva or vagina. It occurs less commonly after puberty.
  • Vulvovaginitis is ruled out by the given symptoms and regular local examination.

Option D: Cystitis

  • Cystitis is an acute or chronic infection of the bladder.
  • It is ruled out in this case as there is no history suggestive of urinary infections and USG does not show thickened bladder wall.

questions.text: What confers a woman with squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva, being evaluated for staging, the least chance of survival after surgery?
questions.solution:
Option C: Positive pelvic lymph nodes

  • The single most important prognostic factor for vulvar carcinoma is lymph node status. So, in this case, a patient will have a poorer prognosis with the involvement of pelvic lymph nodes.
  • In the case of advanced cancer, 5-year survival without groin node metastases is greater than 90%.
  • However, with groin node metastases, 5-year survival is around 50%.
  • Inguino-femoral lymph nodes are involved in stage 3 vulvar cancer.
