  • Pelvic and other lymph nodes are involved in stage 4 A, and hence the involvement of pelvic lymph nodes signifies a further metastasis in the pelvic area where many important viscera are present, and seeding to organs can occur.
  • The survival rates of different stages are mentioned below:

 

Option A: Large tumour size

  • Large tumour size is important in the management of vulvar cancer.
  • However, without the relevant information about metastasis, it is not important for the prognosis.

Option B: Positive inguinofemoral lymph nodes

  • Positive inguinofemoral lymph nodes are present in the case of stage 3 cancer.
  • In the above-mentioned scenario, pelvic lymph nodes present in stage 4 cancer will show a worse prognosis.

Option D: Involvement of the lower 1/3rd of the vagina

  • The lower third of the vagina is involved in stage 3 of vulvar cancer.
  • Pelvic node spread supersedes the involvement of the vagina as a marker of bad prognosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady came to OPD with h/o post menopausal bleeding for 2 months, on vaginal examination a growth of 1 x 2 cm is found on the anterior lip of the cervix, normal uterine size, on rectal examination, rectal mucosa, and parametrium are free. A punch biopsy of the lesion established a diagnosis of Ca cervix. What would be the Management?
questions.solution:
Option C: Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

  • This is a case of cervical cancer stage 2.
  • The patient has a clinically visible lesion measuring 2 cm without parametrial involvement. This is clinical-stage IB2 of cervical cancer.
  • Treatment of stage 1B2 is radical hysterectomy (Type 3) with pelvic lymphadenectomy.
  • In radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy, the uterus, cervix, upper 1/3-1/2 vagina, entire parametria, uterine artery ligated at its origin from internal iliac artery and uterosacral ligament at most distal attachment (rectum).

Option A: Conization

  • Conization is done as an excisional procedure for diagnosis in cases where colposcopy is unsatisfactory and not for management of cervical cancer except for stage 1A1 without LVSI in women who wish to preserve their uterus

Option B: Type 1 hysterectomy

  • Simple extra fascial hysterectomy (type I) is done only for stage 1A1 tumours without lymphovascular space invasion.

Option D: Concurrent chemo-radiation

  • When chemotherapy and radiation therapy are given simultaneously to treat cancer, this procedure is called concurrent chemo-radiation therapy.
  • It is done for stages IIB and beyond

questions.text: A 25-year-old female undergoing hysteroscopic myomectomy for submucosal fibroid is noted to have a 500ml fluid deficit while using 1.5 % glycine as irrigating fluid for the cavity. What is the next step?

choices.text: Change the fluid to normal saline
Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status
Give furosemide to the patient and continue surgery

questions.solution:
Option C: Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status

  • Alert at a deficit of more than
    • 750 ml in non-electrolyte distention media like glycine
    • 1000 ml in electrolyte media like NaCl
  • Should stop if more than
    • 1500 ml deficit for non-electrolyte media
    • 2500 ml deficit for electrolyte media
  • Excess of non-electrolyte media like glycine can cause hyperammonemia.
  • Excess electrolyte media like saline of more than 2500ml can cause:
    • fluid overload
    • pulmonary oedema
    • cardiac failure.
  • In the abovementioned cases, furosemide must be given to remove the excess fluid.

Option A: Stop the surgery

  • Should stop if more than
    • 1500 ml deficit for non-electrolyte media
    • 2500 ml deficit for electrolyte media

Option B: Change the fluid to normal saline

  • Confers no extra benefit

Option D: Give furosemide to the patient and continue surgery

  • Furosemide needs to be given to remove the excess fluid in case of excess of electrolyte media.

questions.text: What factor is accountable for transforming the gonad into testes, leading to the development of a male?
questions.solution:
Option A: Presence of SRY gene

  • The human gonad is a bipotential gonad till 5 weeks of intrauterine development, which implies it has the potential to develop into either ovary or testes
  • Gonads acquire male or female characteristics only after 6 weeks of development, i.e., in the 7th week of development.
  • Gonadal differentiation is an active process directed by the presence or absence of the SRY gene.
  • The presence of the SRY gene will differentiate gonads into the testis.
  • Absence will lead to the differentiation of gonads into ovaries.

 

 

Option B: Lack of SRY gene

  • Lack of SRY gene or absence of SRY gene will lead to failure of the testicle formation.

 

Option C: Presence of AMH

  • The presence of the anti-mullerian hormone (AMH) is responsible for suppressing structures that would otherwise form from the paramesonephric duct.

 

Option D: Presence of Testosterones

  • The presence of testosterone during development leads to the formation of male external characteristics.

questions.text: Review the following hysterosalpingogram and provide the appropriate diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Option B: Unicornuate uterus

  • A unicornuate uterus is a rare disorder which causes a female to have only half a uterus accounting for only 10% of all Mullerian anomalies.
  • Unicornuate uterus (Class II).
    • It appears banana-shaped without the rounded fundus and triangular-shaped uterine cavity. If present, the rudimentary horn presents as a soft tissue mass with similar myometrial echogenicity. Obstruction in the rudimentary horn is presented as hematometra on one side.
    • A unicornuate uterus with a non-communicating rudimentary horn is linked with several complications like infertility, endometriosis, hematometra, urinary tract anomalies, abortions, and preterm deliveries. Treatment involves surgical removal of the unicornuate uterus.
  • The picture below shows a unicornuate uterus:

 

Option A: Normal uterus

  • The HSG shown above reveals a unicornuate uterus, not a normal one.
  • A normal uterus shows a triangular cavity with tubes on both sides.

Option C: Bicornuate uterus

  • The HSG shown above reveals a unicornuate uterus, as a bicornuate uterus appears heart-shaped, having two sides instead of a single hollow cavity.

Option D: Arcuate Uterus

  • As shown above, it is a unicornuate uterus because an arcuate uterus appears as an upside-down pear with the top of the uterus indented

questions.text: A 35 year old woman with recurrent episodes of rectal bleeding underwent a sigmoidoscopy. Blackish hemorrhagic lesions were seen and biopsy was taken. Biopsy revealed endometrial glands and stroma. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A : Most common site of endometriosis is the Ovary, followed closely by the POD deposits, surfaces of the peritoneum (including broad ligament, uterosacral ligaments, surface of the uterus). These lesions are black, dark brown, or bluish nodules or small cysts containing old hemorrhage surrounded by a variable degree of fibrosis Histologic confirmation of the laparoscopic impression is essential for the diagnosis of endometriosis. Biopsy reveals endometrial glands or stroma or both.

The most common site of extrapelvic endometriotic implants is intestinal tract. This may present with abdominal pain, distension, rectal bleeding, obstruction.

Other sites include: lungs, pleural cavity, skin, surgical scars

Option B : Utero-intestinal fistula is a rare entity which can occur due to iatrogenic injury during gynaecological surgery, can present with rectal bleeding but the presence of hemorrhagic lesions and endometrial glands and stroma in biopsy rules out this condition

Option C : GIST are uncommon cancers of GI tract occurring in stomach or small intestine, can present with abdominal pain, GI bleeding, on endoscopy show well circumscribed fleshy pink tumor growth with hemorrhagic or degenerative changes, on HPE show spindle cells with pale eosinophilic cytoplasm ovoid nuclei and syncitial cell borders. Here the presence of endometrial glands and stroma on biospy rules out GIST.

Option D : Accidental uterine injury can occur due to iatrogenic injury during gynaecological surgery, can present with rectal bleeding but the presence of hemorrhagic lesions and endometrial glands and stroma in biopsy rules out this condition

questions.text: A 38-year woman presents to the gynaecology clinic with lower abdominal pain for the last 2 months. She underwent gynaecological surgery after radiological investigations. She developed right-sided flank pain on the third postoperative day, and her urine output decreased. An abdominal scan done reveals right-sided hydroureteronephrosis. Which of the following surgeries has the highest risk of this complication?
questions.solution:
Option C: Wertheim hysterectomy.

  • This patient has presented with a right-sided ureteric injury post-surgery. This is evidenced by oliguria, flank pain, and hydroureteronephrosis.
  • Ureteric injury is 0.1–1.5% of all pelvic surgery.
  • The most common cause is an abdominal hysterectomy, a commonly performed surgery.
  • However, surgery-wise, the highest risk is for Wertheim Radical hysterectomy since this surgery involves stripping the ureteric fascia, which can compromise the ureteric blood supply and hence a devascularisation injury.
  • The most common site of ureteric injury is the pelvic brim, clamping the infundibulopelvic ligaments.

Option A: Anterior colporrhaphy

  • Anterior colporhaphy involves separating vagina from bladder, buttressing the bladder, cutting the redundant vagina and then repairing it over the bladder for treating anterior compartment prolapse or cystocele.
  • Associated complications are
    • Damage to the urethra, bladder, or vagina.
    • Irritable bladder.
    • Prolapsed vagina.
    • Fistula causing urine leakage.
    • Complications associated with anaesthesia.
    • Infection.
    • Bleeding.
    • Ureteric injury is not a complication of anterior colporrhaphy.

Option B: Vaginal hysterectomy.

  • It may cause ureteric injury, however risk is more in Wertheims

Option D: Abdominal hysterectomy.

  • Abdominal hysterectomy is the most common cause of ureteric injury as it is the most frequently performed pelvic surgery.
  • Please note that if the question asks which is the most common cause of iatrogenic ureteric injury, it is abdominal hysterectomy
  • However the highest risk of injuring the ureter during a surgery, out of the given options, is Wertheims, due to its radical nature

questions.text: A 54-yrs-old woman undergoes a laparotomy because of a pelvic mass. At exploratory laparotomy, a unilateral ovarian neoplasm is discovered that is accompanied by a large omental metastasis. Frozen section diagnosis confirms metastatic serous cystadenocarcinoma. The most appropriate intraoperative course of action is:-

choices.text: Excision of the omental metastasis and ovarian cystectomy.
Excision of the omental metastasis and unilateral oophorectomy
Omentectomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

questions.solution:
Option D: Omentectomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

  • The patient in question has advanced stage ovarian malignancy (stage-IIIC). This is managed by comprehensive surgical staging, maximal cytoreduction, and adjuvant chemotherapy.

Management of ovarian epithelial cancer:

  • Early:
    • Low risk : Stage 1A and 1B, low-grade : surgical staging
    • If High risk : Stage 1C, high-grade : surgical staging + adjuvant chemotherapy
  • Advanced:
    • Stage II, III, IV = Maximal cytoreduction + Adjuvant chemotherapy
  • Steps of comprehensive surgical staging
    • Vertical midline incision
    • Ascitic fluid for cytology
    • If no ascites: Take peritoneal washings
    • Biopsy of suspicious lesions and diaphragm
    • Omentectomy
    • Retroperitoneal lymph node evaluation
  • Important points:
    • Maximal cytoreduction: Means removal of entire pelvic tumor + resection of metastasis
    • Optimal debulking: Less than 1 cm of residual lesion
    • Fertility sparing surgery (unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy): Stage 1A with low grade, borderline tumors
    • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy: Stage III and IV with massive ascites, massive pleural effusion, unresectable tumor. It increases the chances of optimal debulking.

Option A: Excision of the omental metastasis and ovarian cystectomy

  • The patient in question has advanced stage ovarian malignancy (stage IIIC). Excision of the omental metastasis and ovarian cystectomy is insufficient.

Option B: Omentectomy and ovarian cystectomy

  • The patient in question has advanced stage ovarian malignancy (stage IIIC). Omentectomy and ovarian cystectomy is insufficient

Option C: Excision of the omental metastasis and unilateral oophorectomy

  • The patient in question has advanced stage ovarian malignancy (stage IIIC). Excision of the omental metastasis and unilateral oophorectomy is insufficient.

questions.text: A woman using combined oral contraceptive pill for 8 years is concerned about long-term side effects of the pill. Which of the following benign tumors can be caused by prolonged use of oral contraceptive pills?
questions.solution:
Option A :

Adenomas have been reported with prolonged use of OC pills and though they are benign, rupture of a hepatoma can be fatal. Because the hormones are metabolized in the liver, chronic liver diseases and recent jaundice contraindi­cate the use of pills.

Also, Gall bladder function may be adversely affected. Gall stones are reported with OCP use, but not Gall bladder carcinoma

Option B : OCPs do not cause thyroid adenoma

Option C : OCPs are protective against benign breast diseases like fibroadenoma

Option D : OCPs do not cause myoma

questions.text: A primigravida at 8 weeks pregnancy presents with complains of pain abdomen and vaginal bleeding. Her transvaginal USG shows a gestational sac in the region of endocervical canal. On pressing the transvaginal ultrasound transducer, there is sliding of the sac against the endocervical canal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C : A gestational sac in the cervical canal could be an incomplete abortion or a cervical ectopic. A positive sliding sign is suggestive of an incomplete abortion, as there is sliding of the products of conception against the endocervical canal, which is absent in case of a cervical ectopic.

Incomplete abortion presents with pain, bleeding and passage of some mass, the cervical os is open and USG suggests some products retained in the uterus which need to be evacuated.

Various differentials of early pregnancy pain and bleeding are as follows :

  presentation P/V examination USG
Threatened pain, bleeding os closed normal intrauterine pregnancy
Inevitable pain, bleeding os open intrauterine pregnancy with dilated cervix
Incomplete pain, bleeding, passage of mass os open retained products of conception
Complete passage of mass os closed empty uterus
Missed no complaints os closed absent cardiac activity
Ectopic Pain, bleeding Cervical motion tenderness, adnexal fullness/ tenderness No intrauterine sac, adnexal mass/ sac +/- hemoperitoneum

Option A : A gestational sac in the cervical canal could be a cervical ectopic however the main differentiating point here is a positive sliding sign (sliding of the products of conception against the endocervical canal) which is absent in case of a cervical ectopic.

Option B : Abdominal pregnancy is characterized by an ectopic pregnancy which either is implanted in the peritoneal cavity (primary) or was implanted in the uterus and perforated its way out into the peritoneal cavity (secondary). Either way there is no abnormality seen in the cervix as in the question.

Option D : A missed abortion is one in which the fetus is found non-viable on USG without any symptoms of pain or bleeding.

questions.text: A multigravida delivers a live baby after labor of 8 hours at a gestational age of 32 weeks. The cord is clamped and cut after delivery and the obstetrician waits for the placenta to deliver. The placenta however fails to deliver even after 40 mins with significant continuous bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in patient management?
questions.solution:
Option C : A placenta that fails to deliver even after 30 mins of delivery of baby is known as a retained placenta. Causes of retained placenta include

  1. Uterine contractions are insufficient to detach the placenta
  2. Lower uterine segment constriction : the placenta is detached but trapped inside
  3. Morbidly adherent placenta

Risks for retained placenta

  • Still birth
  • Previous LSCS
  • Past history of retained placenta
  • Preterm delivery

Management :

  • Manual removal of placenta is indicated in a case of retained placenta as is can cause PPH. During manual removal, one hand grasps the fundus and the other hand is inserted into the cavity and the fingers are swept from side to side as they are advanced. When the placenta detaches, it is grasped and removed.
  • A single dose of antibiotic is also recommended.

Option A : If placenta fails to deliver within 30 minutes, manual removal must be done.

Option B : Controlled cord traction is done to separate the placenta, but here the obstetrician has already waited for 40 minutes and the placenta has not separated, hence a manual removal is required.

Option D : Hysterectomy is the last resort, only when there is a morbidly adherent placenta requiring obstetric hysterectomy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a fever at 19 weeks of pregnancy. She tests positive for COVID-19 on PCR. She desires to know the effects of the disease on her baby. The risk of which of the following complications is increased in a case of pregnancy with COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Option A: Preterm birth

  • COVID-19 is a disease of the respiratory system that affects the lungs. The patient often complains of having a cough, fever, and shortness of breath when they come in. The consolidations in the patient's lungs result in a decrease in the patient's oxygen saturation.
  • Even though there is currently no proper treatment for the sickness, most people recover from it after the virus has had a chance to incubate in their bodies for a period of 14 days.
  • COVID-19 in pregnancy is associated with an increased risk of preterm birth. It is mostly iatrogenic and done in view of maternal or fetal compromise. Also, there are increased chances of cesarean delivery.
  • The appearance of the Delta variant was linked to an even higher risk of severe outcomes for pregnant people. These outcomes included an increase in the number of deaths, an increase in the number of ICU admissions, an increase in the number of required medical interventions such as invasive ventilation and ECMO, and an increase in the number of medical interventions overall.
  • There is no increased risk of congenital malformation, neonatal death, and pre-eclampsia.

 

Option B: Pre-eclampsia

  • Pre-eclampsia is not a complication of COVID-19 during pregnancy.

Option C: Fetal malformations

  • COVID-19 in pregnancy does not result in fetal malformations.

Option D: Neonatal death

  • Neonatal death is not a complication associated with COVID-19 in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient has come to the hospital complaining of a history of multiple abortions. She had 3 spontaneous miscarriages in the second trimester, and the episode occurred 1 month back. She tests positive for LAC (lupus anticoagulant) and ACL (anticardiolipin antibody). Which of the following pharmacotherapy is most appropriate for this patient in her subsequent pregnancies?

choices.text: Aspirin + Low molecular weight heparin + Prednisolone

questions.solution:
Option B : A positive test for LAC (lupus anticoagulant) and ACL (anticardiolipin antibody) is suggestive of APLA

DOC for APLA - Warfarin (Teratogenic)

DOC for APLA in Pregnancy - Heparin + Aspirin

  • Heparin to be added only when there is H/O Recurrent abortions or Thrombosis
  • Otherwise we give only low dose Aspirin

Anti phospholipid syndrome -

  • Recurrent fetal loss
  • IUGR
  • PIH
  • Placental abruption (2nd trimester)
  • Recurrent thrombotic events (Arterial venous thrombosis)
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Auto immune or connective tissue diseases

 

Clinical criteria

  • Vascular thrombosis
  • Recurrent pregnancy loss >=3 spontaneous abortions <10 weeks
  • Death of normal fetus > 10 weeks
  • Premature birth at <34 weeks due to pre-eclampsia or placental insufficiency

Laboratory Features:
1. Elevated anticardiolipin antibodies (IgG or IgM)
2. Elevated Anti beta-2 glycoprotein -1 Antibody
3. Presence of Lupus Anticoagulant (LA) in plasma

DOC for APLA in Pregnancy - Heparin + Aspirin

Option A : Aspirin is insufficient as there is history of recurrent miscarriages.

Option C : Prednisolone is not used for treatment of APLA

Option D : Prednisolone is not used for treatment of APLA. Progesterones can be given for pregnancy support and to maintain uterine quiescence. However aspirin and LMWH has to be given

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, delivers an appropriate-for-gestational age infant by spontaneous vaginal delivery in the vertex position. The infant is noted to have edematous swelling of the soft tissue of the scalp that crosses the midline. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D : An edematous swelling of the soft tissue of the scalp that crosses the midline, in a newborn in most likely suggestive of a caput succadaneum

Option A : Caput succadaneum vs cephalhematoma

  • Caput succedaneum is a diffuse swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp. It extends across suture lines, and the edema starts to resolve over the first few days.
  • Underlying skull fractures not seen in caput succedaneum. These are occasionally associated with cephalohematomas.
  • The hemorrhages caused by cephalohematomas are subperiosteal; therefore, they are limited to one bone and do not cross suture lines.
  • Cephalohematomas tend to increase in size over the first few days and resorb in approximately 3 months.

Option B : Subcutaneous fat necrosis of the newborn is an uncommon panniculitis of the neonate. Classically red, red-brown or violaceous subcutaneous nodules and indurated plaques develop on the back, buttocks, proximal extremities or cheeks within the first few weeks of life.

Option C : A newborn skull fracture is rare but is usually associated with serious intracranial hemorrhage. Mostly occur with instrumental delivery, rarely from spontaneous or cesarean delivery. They can be linear or depressed types. These are recognized with skull x rays, CT or MRI. These can be treated with surgical decompression or may resolve spontaneously.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida at 5 weeks of pregnancy presents with abdominal pain and vaginal spotting. Examination suggests a normal-sized uterus with right adnexal fullness and tenderness. Cervical motion tenderness is also present. Which of the following investigations would provide the most definitive diagnosis in this case?

choices.text: Serial β-hCG levels and correlate with doubling titers

questions.solution:
Option A : History and examination findings are suggestive of right tubal ectopic.The usual and regular way to diagnose an ectopic is the Transvaginal USG. Serial bHCG levels are helpful adjuncts and not superior to TVS.MRI is the best imaging technique to diagnose an ectopic and is considered a 'Trouble Shooter' when there is a doubt.Best method to diagnose an ectopic pregnancy irrevocably is Laparoscopy

Ectopic pregnancy

  • Is one in which the fertilized ovum is implanted & develops outside the normal endometrial cavity

Site

  • Tubal (most common)
  • Ovarian
  • Abdominal
  • Cervical

Common cause

  • Salpingitis
  • PID
  • Contraception failure (IUCD )
  • Tubal ligation

Presentation

  • Abdominal pain
  • Amenorrhea
  • Vaginal bleeding

Diagnosis

  • hCG ( either in urine or serum ): to check doubling titres
  • Transvaginal sonography; usual test to diagnose an ectopic pregnancy in the OPD
  • Laparoscopy (confirmation) best test: This of course is not the first test to be done for the diagnosis. This is mostly done when the clinical and USG suspicion is almost sure and a laparoscopy hence is diagnostic as well as therapeutic intervention.

Treatment

  • Surgical or medical : Surgery could be done either by laparoscopy or laparotomy, either salpingotomy or salpingectomy.

Option B : Culdocentesis is a method in which fluid from POD is aspirated, presence of non clotting blood is suggestive of ruptured ectopic pregnancy when other signs are suggestive, however this is not diagnostic of ectopic pregnancy.

Option C : Serial b HCG every 48 hours can be done in cases where no gestational sac is seen on USG, to differentiate between ectopic and intrauterine pregnancy. In case of an intrauterine pregnancy, b HCG doubles every 48 hours, while in ectopic pregnancy doubling is not seen in 48 hours.

Option D : The usual and regular way to diagnose an ectopic is the Transvaginal USG. It is an easy convenient way to diagnose ectopic, wherein an ectopic gestational sac with or without hemoperitoneum may be seen. However in all cases of ectopic pregnancy diagnosis may not be cleared with USG and definitive diagnosis would be provided by laparoscopy.

questions.text: A woman at 30 weeks presents with complaints of excessive distension of her abdomen relative to her gestation. On ultrasound, the AFI is 27 cm. Which of the following statements concerning the patient's condition is true?

choices.text: The incidence of associated malformations is approximately 3%
Maternal oedema of the vulva & lower limbs are rarely associated
Complications include placental abruption, uterine dysfunction, and postpartum haemorrhage

questions.solution:
Option D : Polyhydramnios is an excessive quantity of amniotic fluid.

Definitions :

  • Liquor → >25 AFI or > 2 liters of Amniotic fluid
  • Acute Polyhydramnios → Polyhydramnios seen < 24 weeks of gestation
  • > 25-30 AFI → Mild Polyhydramnios (MC)
  • > 30-35 AFI → Moderate Polyhydramnios
  • > 35 AFI → Severe Polyhydramnios (mostly a/w anomalies)

Associations:

  • The incidence of associated malformation with it may range upto 15% of all cases.
  • Edema of the lower extremities, vulva, and abdominal wall can occur, resulting from compression of major venous systems.
  • Polyhydramnios is associated with preterm labor due to overdistension of uterus. Acute polyhydramnios tends to occur early in pregnancy and by definition is accumulation of fluid more than 25 AFI prior to 24 weeks. This as a rule, leads to labor before the 28th week.
  • The most frequent maternal complications are placental abruption, uterine dysfunction, and postpartum hemorrhage.

Option A : Polyhydramnios leads to preterm labor and not prolonged pregnancy.

Option B : The incidence of associated malformation with it may range upto 15% of all cases. It is more in more severe and acute cases.

Option C : Edema of the lower extremities, vulva, and abdominal wall can occur, resulting from compression of major venous systems.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents to the obstetric outpatient department for her antenatal check-up at 18 weeks of gestation. She has no active complaints. She has no history of any medical disorder. She has been a known cocaine addict for 4 years and continues to use cocaine during pregnancy despite being advised against it. A detailed anomaly scan is advised. Which fetal anomalies are most likely to be seen due to cocaine abuse in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cleft palate

  • Cocaine is a drug of abuse.
  • It is a sympathomimetic drug. It inhibits neuronal uptake of norepinephrine.
  • Drugs of abuse are an absolute contraindication during pregnancy because of their teratogenic effects.
  • Most of the adverse outcomes associated with cocaine occur due to its vasoconstrictive properties and hypertensive effects.
  • It has both maternal and fetal complications.
  • Maternal complications include:
  • Cerebrovascular haemorrhage
  • Myocardial damage
  • Placental abruption
  • Preterm labour
  • Preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM)
  • Precipitous labour
  • Fetal complications include:
  • Cleft palate
  • Cardiovascular abnormalities
  • Urinary tract abnormalities
  • Skull defects
  • Visceral infarcts
  • Fetal-growth restriction

Children exposed to cocaine during intrauterine life are at an increased risk of behavioural abnormalities and cognitive impairments.

 

Option A: Sacral agenesis

  • Sacral agenesis is a part of caudal regression syndrome.
  • The cause of sacral agenesis is unknown.
  • Some cases have been linked with uncontrolled maternal diabetes.

 

Option B: Hydrops fetalis

  • Hydrops fetalis may occur due to Rh incompatibility between the mother and fetus.
  • Other non immune causes include parvovirus B19, cytomegalovirus and herpes simplex virus infections.
  • It is not associated with cocaine abuse.

 

Option D: Hypertrichosis

  • Hypertrichosis is excessive hair growth.
  • It has an unknown aetiology.
  • It is a genetic disorder which is inherited or results from spontaneous mutation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old primigravida, at 33 weeks of gestation, is brought to the emergency department complaining of an absence of fetal movement for the last two days. She didn't receive any antenatal care or pregnancy check-up except a USG at 32 weeks, suggesting a growth retarded fetus corresponding to 30 weeks of fetal age. Her vitals are normal on examination, and the physician advises an antenatal doppler scan to assess fetal status. Which of the following umbilical artery Doppler findings is the most significant indication for termination of the pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Option C: Reversal of flow

  • Reversal of blood flow during diastole is suggestive of imminent fetal death.
  • The earliest sign of fetal compromise is a raised S/D ratio in the Umblical artery flow.
  • An absence of diastolic flow indicates severe fetal compromise, and it requires intensive fetal monitoring with NST and frequent doppler up to 34 weeks or occurrence of reversal of flow (whichever is earlier), after which pregnancy should be terminated.
  • A reversal of diastolic flow is indicative of imminent fetal death (fetus is expected to die within 24-48 hours), requiring urgent termination, and therefore reversal occurring before lung maturity carries poor chances of fetal survival.

Option A: Increased S/D ratio

  • It is the earliest sign of fetal compromise
  • Management involves frequent fetal monitoring with doppler and NSTs

Option B: Absent diastolic flow

  • It signifies severely worsening fetal condition, but pregnancy can be continued with intensive fetal monitoring with NST until 34 weeks or reversal of flow occurs.

Option D: Normal S/D ratio

  • A normal S/D ratio assures good fetal condition; therefore, pregnancy must not be terminated.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents in the emergency department with complaints of blood in urine, lower abdominal pain, and diarrhoea for 2 days. There is no history of decreased urine output. On examination, the patient's vitals are normal except for having tachycardia (102 beats/minute). He is mildly dehydrated and has evidence of dermatitis herpetiformis. Urine analysis shows evidence of gross haematuria. C3 levels are normal, and peripheral smear examination also shows no remarkable findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Berger’s disease

  • Gross haematuria within 1-2 days of onset of an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection in young children suggests Berger's disease. (Skin infection causes post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) and not Berger’s disease).
  • It is also called IgA nephropathy.
  • IgA Nephropathy is strongly associated with celiac disease, which has the cutaneous manifestation of dermatitis herpetiformis.
  • Mild to moderate hypertension can be seen in this disease, which may present with loin pain.
  • Normal serum levels of C3 in IgA nephropathy help to differentiate this disorder from PSGN, where serum C3 levels are low.
  • Serum IgA levels are elevated in only 15% of paediatric patients.

Option B: Post Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis

  • PSGN can present with gross haematuria after an upper respiratory tract infection or a skin infection. 
  • The time interval between the preceding illness and the development of haematuria is usually longer in PSGN (more than 10 days)

Option C: Microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia

  • Microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia results from damage to red blood cells while passing through the damaged/thrombotic capillary.
  • Microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia is diagnosed by morphologically abnormal RBCs, with schistocytes, spherocytes, helmet cells, and an elevated reticulocyte count. So normal peripheral smear examination in the above question rules out microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia.

Option D: Alport syndrome

  • The diagnosis of Alport syndrome can only be made by kidney biopsy.
  • There is a family history of kidney failure, and the patient may present with deafness.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented to the emergency department with jerky repetitive movements of limbs for 10 minutes. He is stabilized and admitted from detention. On further evaluation, it is revealed that he has a developmental delay. His mother gives a history of tonic-clonic seizures a few times before. An EEG shows polyspike bursts while sleeping and slow waves while awakened. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lennox-Gastaut syndrome

  • In this case, the boy is 7 years old and presents with a myoclonic seizure. He has a history of developmental delay and tonic-clonic fits. His EEG shows polyspike bursts in sleep and a slow background in wakefulness.
  • The age of onset is usually 2 to 10 years.
  • Classic features are a triad of developmental delay, multiple seizure types, and characteristic EEG changes.
  • Long-term cognitive impairment and intractable fits often develop despite multiple therapies.
  • EEG findings are 1-2 Hz spike–and–slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness.
  • Patients suffering from Ohtahara syndrome can develop West syndrome and then progress to LGS.

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome with paroxysms of fast activity and ..." src="https://images.prepladder.com/blog-images-prepladder/medical/gLkDTnmmQyc75Qia93826mZViyYR3h4k3pYWMljD1591625564.jpg" />

 

Option B: West syndrome

  • West syndrome, also known as infantile spasms, is characterized by a triad of spasms, developmental regression, and an EEG pattern called hypsarrhythmia.
  • It is a severe epilepsy syndrome with a survival rate of 5% at 5 years of age.

Option C: Ohtahara syndrome

  • Ohtahara syndrome is characterized by tonic-clonic fits and burst suppression in EEG.
  • It typically presents during the first two months of life.

Option D: Early infantile epileptic encephalopathy

  • It is another name for Ohtahara syndrome, which affects infants in the first 2 months of life.
  • EEG shows burst suppression, and the patient has tonic-clonic fits.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents in a paediatric clinic with inspiratory noises since 1 month; the noises are inspiratory and are increased when the baby is lying down, sleeping, and before or after feeding. According to his mother, he has no difficulty feeding. On examination, the child is of normal height and weight with a normal cry and mild tachypnea; the noise is inspiratory and increases when the baby is placed supine; the nasal pathway is clear; and there are no nasal secretions present. His laryngoscopy showed the following picture: What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Laryngomalacia

  • The infant presented with the complaint of inspiratory noises that increase when the infant is lying supine, sleeping and before/after sleeping; these noises are the characteristic of laryngomalacia, there are no nasal secretions, thus ruling out the possibility of any nasal pathology, and finally, on laryngoscopy, lateral tips of the epiglottis are collapsing inwards (Omega shaped epiglottis) thus confirming the diagnosis of laryngomalacia.
  • It is the most common cause of stridor during infancy.
  • The symptoms usually begin by 4-6 weeks, and they usually abate by 2 years of age.
  • The infant is usually thriving because of no disturbance in feeding pattern; vital signs are normal with sometimes mild tachypnea and no nasal pathology, thus ruling out the possibility of any nasal cause.
  • Diagnosis is made by flexible laryngoscopy.

Option A: Acute epiglottitis

  • It is an acute inflammation in the supraglottic region of the oropharynx that includes inflammation of the epiglottis, vallecula, aryepiglottic folds and arytenoids.
  • The signs and symptoms include a tripod position (Sitting up on hands, with the tongue out and head bent forwards), drooling of saliva, muffled voice, fever, hypoxia, mild respiratory distress, cough and tachycardia.
  • The diagnosis is made by laryngoscopy.

Option B: Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

  • It is also known as croup, and it is a paediatric viral respiratory tract illness generally caused by para influenza viruses which generally affects the trachea and larynx but might extend to the bronchi in severe cases.
  • The child presents with hoarseness, seal-like barking cough, stridor (which can be inspiratory, expiratory or biphasic) and respiratory distress. Diagnosis is usually made clinically, but laryngoscopy can be employed in complicated cases. Radiographs usually show the "Steeple sign" in the tracheal region.

Option D: Tracheoesophageal fistula

  • It is a communication between the trachea and oesophagus which can be acquired or congenital and often leads to severe and fatal pulmonary complications. Most of the patients are diagnosed in the neonatal period due to life-threatening complications.
  • Patients usually present with cough, aspiration, and fever, which is exacerbated on feeding.
  • Congenital tracheoesophageal fistula is usually associated with developmental anomalies of other systems like cardiac, genitourinary, gastric and musculoskeletal.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl always had to wear warm socks, even in the summer season. On physical examination, it was noticed that she had high blood pressure and that her femoral pulse was weak as compared to radial and carotid pulse; chest radiography showed a 'figure of 3' appearance and notching of the inferior margin of her ribs. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Option B: Coarctation of Aorta

  • This patient with hypertension, weak femoral pulses and the characteristic radiological findings is most likely suffering from coarctation of the aorta.
  • Coarctation of the aorta is caused by the medial thickening and intimal hyperplasia forming a ridge around the aortic lumen and impeding blood flow.
    • In the preductal (infantile) type (most common type), the narrowing is proximal to the ligamentum arteriosum or ductus arteriosus.
    • In the postductal (adult) type, the narrowing is distal to the ligamentum arteriosum or ductus arteriosus.
  • The patient presents with weak femoral pulses and hypertension.
  • Treatment involves infusion of PGE1 followed by surgical correction or balloon angioplasty.

Option A: Femoral artery Thrombosis:

  • Usually seen after an intervention like cardiac catheterisation
  • Clinical features include pulselessness, cold temperature, pallor, pain and impaired movement of the lower extremity.
  • In addition, femoral artery thrombosis usually affects one limb causing unilateral symptoms. The presence of bilateral femoral artery thrombosis is very rare.
  • Our patient has pulselessness and no pallor or cold extremities making femoral artery thrombosis a less likely diagnosis.

Option D: Takayasu arteritis:

  • It is also known as "pulseless disease"
  • It is a chronic large vessel vasculitis of unknown aetiology
  • Predominantly involves the aorta and its major branches
  • Age of onset: Between 10 and 40 years
  • Preferentially affects females
  • Clinical features include hypertension, headache, diminished pulses, asymmetric blood pressures, claudication, Raynaud phenomenon, renal failure, and symptoms of pulmonary or cardiac ischemia.
  • However, it does not cause decreased femoral pulses or a classic “figure of 3” appearance with rib notching on chest X-ray, making this diagnosis less likely.

Option C: Raynaud disease:

  • When the Raynaud Phenomenon is independent of an underlying rheumatic disease, it is termed Raynaud disease.
  • Raynaud Phenomenon refers to the classic triphasic sequence of blanching, cyanosis, and erythema of the digits induced by cold exposure and/or emotional stress.
  • Raynaud disease affects the vessels of the digits and does not involve the deeper vessels, such as the femoral vessel, which would decrease femoral pulses. Therefore, it is less likely to be present here.

questions.text: Establish a diagnosis for a child with petechiae, splenomegaly, hemoglobin level of 8 g/dL, platelet count of 50,000/µL, WBC count of 30,000/µL with 60% blasts, and a bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellular marrow with a high percentage of myeloblasts that are positive for myeloperoxidase on cytochemical staining.
questions.solution:
Option A: Acute myeloid leukaemia

  • The patient presents with the symptoms of tiredness and weakness, and pallor due to anaemia, and Auer rods are suggestive of acute myeloid leukaemia.
  • Acute myeloid leukaemia is cancer which starts in the bone marrow.
  • He had a history of recurrent infections, which is due to decreased white blood cell count.
  • It begins with flu-like symptoms like fatigue, fever, weight loss, loss of appetite, headache, swollen gums and more infections than usual.
  • Auer rods are Needle-like azurophilic fusiform inclusions in the cytoplasm of myeloblasts.
  • Auer rods are the most reliable morphological feature of AML [M2, M3, M4 subtypes]
  • The diagnosis of AML depends on blood tests, bone marrow examination, spinal tap and genetic testing.
  • Its treatment is done in two phases remission induction therapy and consolidation therapy.

Option B: Acute lymphocytic leukaemia

  • In acute lymphocytic leukaemia, there is no presence of Auer rods.
  • In this, there is an immature blood cell.

Option C: Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia

  • In this, there is an abnormally high level of unusual white blood cells.
  • While platelet count and red blood cells are decreased.

Option D: Hodgkin's lymphoma

  • In this case, the lymphatic system is affected.
  • Lymphadenopathy is observed.

questions.text: A 20-day-old baby presents to the emergency department with symptoms of hypotonia, weak arms, uncontrolled clumsy movements, muscle spasms, and tremors. Further examination reveals the diagnosis of bilirubin encephalopathy in the neonate. Which type of palsy is seen as a sequel to bilirubin encephalopathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Dyskinetic cerebral palsy

  • Dyskinetic or extrapyramidal cerebral palsy is seen due to basal ganglia involvement in kernicterus or bilirubin encephalopathy in the neonatal period

EXTRA EDGE:

CEREBRAL PALSY AREA OF THE BRAIN INVOLVED
Spastic diplegia periventricular area (PVL – periventricular leukomalacia/ PVHI- Periventricular hemorrhagic infarct)
Spastic quadriplegia Multicystic encephalopathy ; Parasagittal brain injury
Spastic hemiplegia MCA territory infarct
Dyskinetic/Extrapyramidal cerebral palsy Basal ganglia (neonatal jaundice/kernicterus)
Hypotonic Cerebellar lesion

 

Option A: Spastic Quadriplegia

  • Spastic quadriplegia, also known as quadriparesis, is the most severe type of spastic cerebral palsy and affects the face, trunk, and all four limbs.

Option B: Spastic Hemiplegia

  • Spastic hemiplegia/hemiparesis—Only one side of the body is afflicted by this type of CP, usually the arm more so than the leg.

Option D: Hypotonic cerebral palsy

  • A form of cerebral palsy called hypotonic is brought on by harm to the brain's cerebellum during birthing.
  • This brain injury can bring on floppy muscles, excessive flexibility, stability problems, and developmental delays

questions.text: During the 1950s, thalidomide, a medication utilized in Germany for hyperemesis gravidarum, led to the birth defect known as phocomelia in the offspring of mothers who used it. Presently, phocomelia is a seldom-occurring bone disorder due to the ban on the drug in certain countries. Which bones are typically impacted by phocomelia?
questions.solution:
Option A: Long bones

  • In the 1950s, the Thalidomide tragedy happened when the drug was used as a "Wonder drug" in Canada, West Germany, and most parts of the world.
  • It was used as a drug for anxiety, insomnia, and morning sickness.
  • Thalidomide is associated with phocomelia.
  • Phocomelia is a congenital disability affecting long bones.
  • Phoco (meaning 'seal') & Melia (meaning 'limb') indicate that a limb is like a seal's flipper.
  • Genetic inheritance is another cause of Phocomelia.
  • Management of Phocomelia involves the usage of prosthetic limbs.

Option B: Skull bones

  • Skull bones are not affected by thalidomide.
  • Folate deficiency can, however, cause brain development defects.

Option C: Carpals

  • Carpal bones are not commonly affected by teratogens.=

Option D: Metacarpals

  • Metacarpals are not commonly involved in thalidomide effects.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the paediatric outpatient department by his mother due to excessive sleepiness for 1 week. It is associated with constipation for 2 weeks. He was delivered at term via normal vaginal delivery and had no medical check-ups afterwards. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a lethargic infant with periorbital puffiness, a large tongue, and an umbilical hernia. Which of the following tests will help diagnose the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: T4 and TSH assay

  • The patient presents with the clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism.

  • Hypothyroidism presents with constipation, pallor, edematous facies, open posterior fontanel, umbilical hernia, hypothermia, large tongue, rough, dry skin, hypotonia, and large abdomen.

  • Initial investigation of hypothyroidism includes TSH and T4 levels.

  • TSH level is increased, and T4 is decreased in primary hypothyroidism.

  • TSH level is reduced along with T4 levels in secondary hypothyroidism.

  • Other investigations include thyroid ultrasound and evaluation of radionuclide uptake.

  • Oral levothyroxine is the treatment for hypothyroidism.

Option A: Karyotyping

  • Karyotyping identifies chromosomal disorders such as trisomies and translocations.

  • Hypothyroidism is not a chromosomal disorder.

Option C: Rectal mucosal biopsy

  • A rectal mucosal biopsy is used to diagnose Hirschsprung disease, which presents with constipation in the early neonatal period.

  • Rectal mucosal biopsy has no role in the diagnosis of hypothyroidism.

Option D: ACTH level

  • ACTH level is used to identify adrenal diseases such as Cushing’s syndrome and Addison’s disease.

  • It has no role in the diagnosis of hypothyroidism

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a known history of uncontrolled diabetes presents to the physician with complaints of severe persistent earache, greenish discharge from the ear, and headache for 3 months. He is otherwise vitally stable and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Otoscopy reveals granulation tissue at the cartilage bone of the external auditory canal. Which of the following dehiscence in the external auditory canal leads to the spread of infection in this case?
questions.solution:
Option A: Fissures of Santorini

  • This is a case of malignant otitis externa. Malignant external otitis (MEO) is an infection that affects the external auditory canal and temporal bone.
    • The causative organism is usually pseudomonas aeruginosa, and the disease commonly manifests in immune deficiency patients.
    • The infection begins as external otitis that progresses into osteomyelitis of the temporal bone (Lateral skull base osteomyelitis).
    • The spread of the disease outside the external auditory canal occurs through the fissures of Santorini (two vertical fissures in the anterior portion of the cartilage of the external auditory meatus, filled with fibrous tissue) and the osseocartilaginous junction.

Option B: Notch of Rivinus

  • It is a defect in the upper tympanic part of the temporal bone, filled by the upper portion of the tympanic membrane.

Option C: Petro-tympanic fissure

  • It is a fissure in the temporal bone that runs from the temporomandibular joint to the tympanic cavity.

Option D: Foramen of Huschke

  • It represents a developmental defect in the anteroinferior aspect of the bony external auditory meatus.

questions.text: A 62-year-old judge presents to the physician complaining of the subtle weakness of his left lower face that he first noted while shaving. Two months later, he noted that he could no longer close his left eyelid fully and had increasing weakness in the remainder of his left face. Which of the following is the narrowest nerve segment involved in the patient's pathology?
questions.solution:
Option A: Labyrinthine segment

  • It is a case of Bell's palsy caused due to a lesion of the facial nerve.

Labyrinthine segment (3.0 mm):

  • From fundus of meatus to geniculate ganglion where nerve takes a turn posteriorly forming a "genu".
  • The nerve in the labyrinthine segment has the narrowest diameter (0.61–0.68 mm), and the bony canal in this segment is also the narrowest.
  • Thus, edema or inflammation can easily compress the nerve and cause paralysis.
  • This is also the shortest segment of the nerve.
  • Tympanic segment :
    • Tympanic or horizontal segment (11.0 mm). From geniculate ganglion to just above the pyramidal eminence. It lies above the oval window and below the lateral semicircular canal.
  •  Mastoid segment :
    • Mastoid or vertical segment (13.0 mm). From the pyramid to stylomastoid foramen. Between the tympanic and mastoid segments is the second genu of the nerve.
  • Meatal segment :
    • Meatal segment (8–10 mm).
    • It is within internal acoustic meatus.

Option B: Tympanic segment

  • It is a false statement.
  • Tympanic or horizontal segment (11.0 mm). From geniculate ganglion to just above the pyramidal eminence. It lies above the oval window and below the lateral semicircular canal.

Option C: Mastoid segment

  • It is a false statement.
  • Mastoid or vertical segment (13.0 mm). From the pyramid to stylomastoid foramen. Between the tympanic and mastoid segments is the second genu of the nerve.

Option D: Meatal segment

  • It is a false statement.
  • Meatal segment (8–10 mm).
  • It is within internal acoustic meatus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman neuro-fibromatosis II patient comes to the E.N.T. department with a 3-week history of intermittent episodes of dizziness. The episodes last for hours and are characterized by the sensation that the room is spinning. The patient also reports that she has started using her cell phone with her left ear because she hears better on that side. She has experienced intermittent ringing and fullness in her right ear. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 76/min, respiration is 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/76 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is horizontal nystagmus to the right. M.R.I. revealed the below image. Which of the following audio-metric test is a reliable indicator in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: B.E.R.A.

  • The above given is a case of vestibular schwannoma.
  • The best audiometric test for vestibular schwannoma is B.E.R.A.
  • Brainstem-evoked response audiometry (B.E.R.A.) is very useful in the diagnosis of retro-cochlear lesions. In the presence of the VIIIth nerve tumour, a delay of > 0.2 ms in wave V between two ears is significant.
  • Vestibular Schwannoma is a benign tumour of abnormally proliferative Schwann cells, which covers the lateral portion of the vestibular nerve in the internal acoustic meatus.
  • Earlier name - acoustic neuroma (obsolete now).
  • Most common benign tumour of the cerebellopontine angle. (C.P. angle)
  • Usually unilateral but bilateral in neurofibromatosis II.
  • Site of origin:
    • Inf. vestibular nerve in IAC (60-90%) → most common.
    • Sometimes sup vestibular nerve.
    • Rarely from the cochlear nerve.
    • Arises from Schwann cells in the myelin sheath.
  • Clinical features:
    • SNHL - slow & progressive (most common presentation).
    • Tinnitus.
    • Vertigo/dizziness (not prominent).
  • Signs:
    • Earliest: Loss of corneal reflex (due to 5th nerve involvement).
    • Hitzelberger sign: Loss of sensory supply by the facial nerve in the posterosuperior wall of the external auditory canal.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Gadolinium-enhanced MRI→ (initial investigation of choice).
    • The best test for acoustic neuroma is B.E.R.A.
    • The most diagnostic finding suggestive of acoustic neuroma on B.E.R.A. has increased interaural latency of wave V of > 0.2 ms.
  • Treatment:
    • Large tumour– surgical excision.
    • Small tumour
      • Old patient, slow-growing tumour - serial M.R.I. every 6M.
      • A young patient with a fast-growing tumour - gamma knife excision.
      • Approaches for surgical excision.
      • When there is no hearing present: Translabyrinthine approach.
      • If hearing present: Middle cranial fossa approach (limited access).
      • Retro sigmoid /suboccipital approach: The tumour is sent for histopathology after Sx excision.
        • Anatomy A cells: More common
        • Densely packed cells with small spindle-shaped nuclei.
        • Anatomy B cells: Loosely arranged, vacuolated pleomorphic cells.

Option A: Speech Audiometry

  • Speech audiometry shows poor speech discrimination, and this is disproportionate to pure tone hearing loss. Roll-over phenomenon, i.e., reduction of discrimination score when loudness is increased beyond a particular limit, is most commonly observed.

Option B: Age-wise hearing assessment

  • This test is usually done on children.
  • This test is done at the age starting from 6 months to 10 years.
  • Adults get their hearing test every 10 years until the age of 50 and then every 3 years after 50 years of age.

Option D: Pure tone audiometry

  • Pure tone audiometry will show sensorineural hearing loss, more marked in high frequencies.
  • It determines the type, degree, and configuration of hearing loss.

questions.text: A 12-year-old male presents to the ENT department with a complaint of recurrent epistaxis. On extensive examination and workup, he is diagnosed with a case of hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia. Which of the following is the treatment of choice in recurrent epistaxis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Septal Dermoplasty

Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT) or Osler-Weber-Rendu disease:

  • Autosomal dominant.
  • Affects blood vessels in the skin, mucous membranes, and viscera.
  • Chromosome 9q (HHT1) and chromosome 12q (HHT2).

Curacao Criteria:

  • Telangiectasia.
  • A-V malformations and aneurysms.
  • Recurrent epistaxis occurs in 93% of cases.
  • Positive family history in first-degree relatives.

Treatment:

  • Packing.
  • Cautery.
  • Antifibrinolytics.
  • Systemic or topical estrogens.
  • Coagulative lasers.
  • Septal dermoplasty (treatment of choice).
  • Ligation and embolization.
  • The last resort is permanent surgical closure of the nostrils (Young's operation).
  • Laser photocoagulation with NdYAG, Argon, and KTP532 lasers.

Option A: Anterior ethmoidal artery ligation

  • This patient has Osler-weber-Rendu disease.
  • The treatment of choice for this Patient is septal dermoplasty.

Option C: External carotid artery ligation

  • The treatment of choice for the posterior epistaxis is endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation.
  • If bleeding is not controlled, internal maxillary and external carotid artery ligation are done.
  • This patient has osler weber rendu disease which requires an immediate management with the septal dermoplasty.

Option D: Internal carotid artery ligation

  • The internal carotid is never ligated in cases of epistaxis.
  • This can lead to brain ischemia and should be avoided in all the cases of the nasal bleed.
  • Moreover, whenever the nasal bleed is caused by Osler weber rendu disease, septal dermoplasty is the treatment of choice.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy presents to the ENT outpatient department due to bilateral earaches and impaired hearing for 1 week. His mother reports that the child has had recurrent upper respiratory tract infections for a few months. The patient has the following features on physical examination, along with amber-coloured fluid behind the tympanic membranes bilaterally.



Surgical excision is planned for this patient’s disease. Which of the following is not a complication of the surgery performed on this patient?
questions.solution:
The correct option is:

3. Grisel syndrome

Explanation of Options:

  1. Hyponasal speech: Adenoidectomy is the surgical removal of the adenoids, which are lymphoid tissue located in the back of the nasal cavity. Complications of adenoidectomy can include temporary changes in speech, including hyponasal speech. Hyponasal speech occurs when there is inadequate airflow through the nasal passages, leading to a muffled or "nasal" sound in speech.

  2. Injury to Eustachian tube opening: The Eustachian tubes connect the middle ear to the back of the throat and are responsible for equalizing pressure in the middle ear. In some cases, adenoidectomy can lead to transient swelling or inflammation around the Eustachian tube opening, causing a temporary dysfunction in its function. This may result in ear discomfort, fluid accumulation in the middle ear, or transient hearing issues.

  3. Velopharyngeal insufficiency: Velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI) is a condition in which there is improper closure or inadequate movement of the soft palate and the back of the throat during speech. Adenoidectomy can lead to transient changes in the soft palate function, which may cause velopharyngeal insufficiency and affect speech. However, this is usually temporary and improves with time.

  4. Grisel syndrome: Grisel syndrome is a rare complication that involves atlantoaxial subluxation, a condition in which there is abnormal movement between the first and second cervical vertebrae (the atlas and axis). Grisel syndrome is usually associated with infections in the head and neck region, such as pharyngitis or tonsillitis, and not specifically with adenoidectomy.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the ENT clinic by her parents with the complaint of abnormally muffled voice since birth. She was born full term and has normally achieved her developmental milestones. On examination, there is no sign of respiratory distress. Laryngoscopy reveals a thin membrane with a concave posterior border between the vocal cords. Which of the following is the most common site of the above pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: Glottis

  • The above clinical and laryngoscopy findings are typical of the laryngeal web.
  • Laryngeal web occurs due to incomplete canalization of the larynx during can result in a congenital laryngeal web.
  • The combination of a weak cry since birth and recurrent croup in infancy should always raise suspicion of a laryngeal web.
  • Most laryngeal webs involve the anterior glottis, joining the vocal cords along a variable part of their length, producing a varying degree of respiratory obstruction and dysphonia.
  • Below is a laryngoscopy image of the glottis narrowed by a laryngeal web.

Option A: Supraglottis

  • Most laryngeal webs involve the anterior glottis.
  • Supraglottis is not a usual site of the congenital laryngeal webs.

Option C: Subglottis

  • Most laryngeal webs involve the anterior glottis.
  • Subglottis is not a usual site of the congenital laryngeal webs.
  • Subglottis can be affected by congenital subglottic stenosis (without a web).

Option D: Trachea

  • Although the trachea is also involved in many congenital anomalies, congenital webs are usually a part of laryngeal pathologies.
  • The common congenital anomalies of the trachea include tracheomalacia, tracheal rings, and trachea-esophageal fistula.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male presents to the ENT outpatient department with hoarseness of voice for the last two days. Two weeks ago, he was admitted to the intensive care unit due to a COVID-19 infection complicated by respiratory failure. He underwent endotracheal intubation and was kept on mechanical ventilation. On a laryngoscopy, he is found to have the following lesion:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Intubation granuloma

  • The picture shows mass involving the vocal process of arytenoid - typical of Intubation Granuloma.
  • These are formed by the proliferation of granulation tissue with epithelial hyperplasia.
  • They result from injury to the thin mucoperichondrium over the vocal processes from mechanical trauma, either following intubation or from the repeated high-velocity impact of the vocal processes against each other from throat clearing, coughing, or talking in a habitually low-pitched, creaky, hyper-functional manner.
  • They may be unilateral or bilateral and range from a nodular, diffuse thickening over the vocal process to large pedunculated, exophytic masses obscuring the posterior glottis.
  • Patients with a change in voice and vocal fatigue, a constant tickling sensation, discomfort, or pain localized to the posterosuperior aspect of the larynx, worsens phonation, coughing, and throat clearing. Pain can radiate to the ear.
  • The main treatment principles include reducing the effects of laryngeal irritants, i.e., stopping smoking, improving vocal hygiene, treating any respiratory tract infections, allergies, and gastroesophageal reflux.
  • Voice therapy has also shown some benefits.

Option A: Carcinoma of the larynx

This is false because:

  • Carcinoma of the larynx is less likely in this patient with a recent history of intubation.
  • Patients can present with a long history of hoarseness, weight loss, and smoking.
  • Diagnosis can be made by direct visualization using laryngoscopy followed by biopsy and CT scan to check for metastasis.

Option B: Vocal Nodules

This is false because:

  • Vocal nodules are benign growths that form on vocal folds.
  • Over time the vocal nodules become hard and callous.
  • Patients usually have a history of voice overuse.

Option C: Laryngomalacia

This is false because:

  • Laryngomalacia is defined as increased laxity of supraglottic structures.
  • Clinical presentation of laryngomalacia begins during the neonatal period and presents with inspiratory stridor that worsens when supine and improves in the prone position.
  • Laryngoscopy shows the collapse of the supraglottic structure with inspiration and omega-shaped epiglottis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with complaints of recurrent ear discharge from his left ear for the past 6 months. He reports a foul-smelling, yellowish-green discharge with occasional bloodstains. He also complains of mild hearing loss in the affected ear. On examination, the left ear canal shows a central perforation of the tympanic membrane with granulation tissue. There are no signs of active infection or inflammation in the ear. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM)

Explanation of the correct option: The patient's clinical history, recurrent ear discharge, foul-smelling yellowish-green discharge, and the presence of a central perforation with granulation tissue in the ear canal strongly suggest Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM). This diagnosis is further supported by the associated hearing loss, which is commonly seen in CSOM due to middle ear involvement.

It is important to differentiate CSOM from acute otitis media, otitis externa, and serous otitis media as the treatment and management for each condition differ. CSOM typically requires a combination of medical therapy (e.g., antibiotics, ear drops) and may sometimes necessitate surgical intervention.

Explanation:

A) Acute Otitis Media: Acute otitis media is characterized by a rapid onset of middle ear infection, usually with severe ear pain, fever, and systemic symptoms. On examination, the tympanic membrane may be bulging and erythematous, and there may be signs of active inflammation or effusion in the middle ear. The patient in this case has a chronic history of ear discharge, which is not typical of acute otitis media.

B) Otitis Externa: Otitis externa, also known as swimmer's ear, is inflammation of the outer ear canal. It is often associated with ear pain, itching, and redness of the ear canal. The ear canal may be swollen and tender, and there may be a watery or purulent discharge. The patient in this case does not have the typical symptoms of otitis externa, and the presence of a central perforation of the tympanic membrane points to a middle ear issue rather than an outer ear problem.

D) Serous Otitis Media: Serous otitis media, also known as otitis media with effusion, is characterized by fluid accumulation in the middle ear without active infection. It is often associated with a sensation of ear fullness and mild hearing loss. The tympanic membrane may appear normal or retracted, and there is usually no ear discharge. The patient in this case has a chronic history of ear discharge, making serous otitis media less likely.

questions.text: Children in the school-going age (6-14 years) represent over 25 % of the population in developing countries. The proximity between the teacher and the students makes the "school teacher" the most appropriate "primary screener" for the vision screening programme among school children. Which of the following do the primary screeners use as the visual cut-off for referral to the nearest primary health care centre?
questions.solution:
Option A: <6/9 in either eye

  • The visual cut-off for referral to the nearest PHC: is <6/9 in either eye.
  • School teachers do the screening. Female teachers are preferred.
  • Focus on middle school(5-8th) covering 10-14 years of age.
  • 1,50,000 children to be screened per block.
  • One trained teacher to handle 150 students.
  • One-day training for the teacher at the nearest PHC.
  • Teacher Kit: Vision screening cards, referral cards, tape/rope to measure 20 feet.

Option B: <6/12 in either eye

  • The vision should be less than 6/9 in either eye for referral to the nearest primary health care centre.

Option C: <6/9 in both eyes

  • Less than 6/9 vision in either eye is enough for referral to PHC.

Option D: <6/12 in both eyes

  • <6/12 in both eyes is not a criterion for the referral to PHC.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented to the accident and emergency department with a gunshot wound in the right side of his cheek caused by a bullet fired from an air gun half an hour ago. He is vitally stable, oriented to time, place and person, and has minimal blood loss. After initial resuscitation, a CT scan was done, which showed a foreign body located on the right side of the skull. It is determined that the pellet penetrated the anterior and posterior walls of the maxillary sinus without any noticeable injury to the blood vessels or nerve damage. Injury to which of the following structures can cause damage to lacrimal secretion in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pterygopalatine ganglion

  • Damage to the pterygopalatine ganglion can result in defects in lacrimal secretion, as it’s the relay for secretosensory signals from the superior salivatory nucleus.
  • Lacrimal glands:
    • The main lacrimal gland consists of two parts:
      • The orbital part is larger, superior and related to the bony orbit, and
      • The palpebral part, which is smaller, is situated inferior to the orbital part.
    • The orbital part has two surfaces: The superior surface, which is in touch with the bone and the inferior surface lies on the levator muscle.
  • Lacrimal passages: consist of puncta, canaliculi and lacrimal sac.
  • The Nasolacrimal duct allows communication between the lacrimal sac and the inferior meatus of the nose.
  • Blood supply:
    • The main supply is from a lacrimal artery, a branch of the ophthalmic artery.
  • Nerve supply of lacrimal gland:

  • The nerve supply of the lacrimal gland can be divided into the following:
    • Sensory supply
    • Sympathetic nerve supply
    • Secretomotor fibres
  • Sensory fibres:
    • These nerve fibres relay the general sensation from the lacrimal gland to the higher centres.
    • They arise from the trigeminal nerve’s (CN V) ophthalmic division.
    • The ophthalmic division gives rise to the lacrimal nerve, which carries sensory signals.
  • Sympathetic supply:
    • Sympathetic nerve supply is from the carotid plexus of the cervical sympathetic chain.
  • Secretomotor fibres:
    • The secretomotor fibres are responsible for lacrimation.
    • The signals arise in the pons, in the superior salivatory nucleus.
    • These signals are carried by the facial nerve in the facial canal and synapse at the geniculate ganglion.
    • A branch, namely the greater petrosal nerve, deep petrosal nerve and nerve of the pterygoid canal, then forms the pre-ganglionic fibres to the pterygopalatine ganglion.
    • Postganglionic fibres from the sphenopalatine or pterygopalatine ganglion are carried by the zygomatic nerve, which gives off a branch called the lacrimal nerve.
    • Finally, the lacrimal nerve innervates the lacrimal gland directly.

Option A: Ciliary ganglion

  • It is a parasympathetic ganglion.
  • It lies at the apex in orbit, specifically between the optic nerve and lateral rectus muscle.
  • It contains pathways for the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve.

  • It plays a role in controlling ciliary muscles and sphincter pupillae muscles.
  • It is not responsible for lacrimation and doesn't supply the lacrimal gland.

Option C: Optic nerve

  • The optic nerve is the second cranial nerve.
  • It is a purely sensory nerve. 
  • It is responsible for visual acuity, light reflex, accommodation, and the perception of colour and contrast.
  • It extends from the retina, exiting the skull through the optic canal to synapse in the cortex.
  • Damage to the optic nerve results in complete, irreversible blindness.

Option D: Oculomotor nerve

  • It is the 3rd cranial nerve.
  • It is a motor nerve.
  • It innervates the following extraocular muscles: Levator palpebrae superioris, superior, medial and inferior recti.
  • It also provides parasympathetic signals to ciliary and pupillary constrictor muscles.
  • Damage to the oculomotor nerve presents with ptosis, diplopia, and loss of upward and downward gaze and adduction.
  • Light reflexes can also be lost in oculomotor nerve palsy.

questions.text: A forty-six-year-old patient presents to your clinic with the complaint of visual difficulties in his right eye. He was recently diagnosed with a cataract in his right eye and was operated on for it with the placement of an intraocular lens. Eye examinations are performed. When the patient is asked to look from side to side, a pendulum motion resembling the action of a windshield wiper is noted. What is the cause of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Malposition of lens

  • The pendular movement of the eye is characteristic of Windshield wiper syndrome.
  • Windshield wiper syndrome is seen due to the malposition of the lens.
  • This is due to the intraocular lens's to-and-fro movement with the head's movement.
  • Windshield Wiper syndrome mostly occurs after cataract extraction with a posterior chamber intraocular lens when the lens is too short and moves in its position. 

Option A: Dislocation of intraocular lens

  • Dislocation of the intraocular lens (IOL) is a rare but serious complication of cataract surgery.
  • Dislocation because of total zonular or capsular instability.
  • Symptoms include a decrease or change in vision, diplopia and glare, and patients may have ocular pain or headaches from intermittent angle-closure and inflammation. 
  • This is not associated with the windshield wiper sign.

Option B: Posterior capsular opacification

  • Posterior capsular opacification (PCO) is also known as after cataract.
  • The most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery occurs in 20-25% of patients.
  • This occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that remain in the capsular bag following cataract surgery.
  • This is not associated with the windshield wiper sign.

Option C: Reaction to the lens material

  • The reaction to lens material depends on the degree of biocompatibility of the lens.
  • Low biocompatibility can cause a series of inflammatory reactions.
  • This is not associated with the windshield wiper sign.

questions.text: A patient has primary open-angle glaucoma in his right eye. His visual acuity was 10/90; despite being on timolol, pilocarpine, and acetazolamide, the IOP remains 20 to 24mmhg. A subsequent visual field test showed further field loss progression in this eye. Which one of the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Argon laser trabeculoplasty

  • This is a case of medically refractory open-angle glaucoma. In this case, surgery is commonly undertaken to arrest visual field loss.
  • Laser trabeculoplasty, both argon laser trabeculoplasty(ALT) and selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT) types is used to increase aqueous outflow facility through the trabecular meshwork (TM) to lower intraocular pressure (IOP) in cases of ocular hypertension and glaucoma.
  • This is the best treatment choice for this patient.

Option A: Seton Placement

  • It is done in cases of refractory glaucoma where trabeculectomy has failed.

Option B: Trabeculectomy

  • Trabeculectomy is a filtering surgery where an ostium is created into the anterior chamber from underneath a partial thickness scleral flap to allow for aqueous flow out of the eye. The aqueous flows into the subconjunctival space, usually leading to an elevation of the conjunctiva, referred to as a filtering bleb.
  • Trabeculectomy is performed for treatment of glaucoma inadequately controlled by maximally tolerated medical therapy. But, better choices like laser trabeculoplasty are available.

Option D: Addition of apraclonidine

  • This is a medically refractive open-angle glaucoma case. In this case, Surgery is commonly undertaken to arrest visual field loss.
  • So, this is the wrong option.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents in the outpatient department with a complaint of headaches for the last 1 year. On further questioning, he reveals that he suffers headaches only while reading the daily newspaper in the morning. It is associated with eye strain and difficulty focusing on different words in the newspaper; therefore, he used to hold books and newspapers farther away to focus on those. There is no previous history of blurred vision or use of a corrective lens in his life. He is subsequently referred to an optometrist to evaluate his eye symptoms as a direct cause of headaches. He underwent an eye examination, including visual acuity, but it does not confirm the condition now, would be the next step?
questions.solution:
The next step in managing a 50-year-old male with chronic headaches, ocular strain during newspaper reading, and an unremarkable ocular/optometric examination would typically be:

Option A. Refraction with a near addition

Explanation:

Option A: Refraction with a near addition: This step is necessary to assess the patient's refractive error, especially for near vision. Presbyopia, which is the age-related loss of near focusing ability, often becomes noticeable around the age of 40-45. Refraction with a near addition helps determine if the patient needs reading glasses or bifocals to alleviate symptoms like ocular strain during near tasks like reading.

Option B: Refraction under Atropine: Atropine eye drops are not typically used for routine evaluation of presbyopia or ocular strain during near vision. They are more commonly used in certain medical or therapeutic situations, such as cycloplegic refraction, but not as an initial step for presbyopia assessment.

Option C: Radial keratotomy: Radial keratotomy is a surgical procedure that is not typically performed as an initial step for managing presbyopia or ocular strain during near tasks. It is used for a different purpose, such as correcting myopia (nearsightedness).

Option D: Cataract surgery: Cataract surgery is indicated when a patient has significant cataracts causing visual impairment. It is not the first-line approach for presbyopia or ocular strain unless cataracts are present and impacting vision.

In summary, assessing refractive error and the need for near vision correction is the appropriate initial step in managing a patient with these symptoms, especially in a middle-aged individual where presbyopia is a common cause of near vision difficulties.

questions.text: An 11-year-old male patient presents with a gradual diminution of vision in his left eye for the past 6 months. Ocular examination reveals a vision of 6/60 in his left eye with no improvement. The vision in his right eye is normal, i.e, 6/6. On fundoscopy, his right eye is normal & left eye shows retinal detachment and subretinal exudation extending into the fovea and telangiectatic vessels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Coat’s Disease

  • Based on the symptoms of a gradual decrease of vision and the presence of retinal detachment and subretinal exudation on fundoscopy, the patient is most likely suffering from coat's disease.
  • All the conditions mentioned above can cause retinal detachment. However, their clinical features are different.
  • Features of coat’s disease:
    • Cause of Idiopathic retinal telangiectasia.
    • Occurs in 1st decade of life.
    • 75% of males are involved.
    • 95% unilateral disease.
    • Variable prognosis - depends on the severity at presentation.
    • Younger age of onset, more severe presentation.
    • Present with unilateral vision loss, strabismus, and leukocoria.
  • Clinical findings:
    • Classical-retinal telangiectasia and focal fusiform arteriolar aneurysms.
    • Intra- and sub-retinal exudates commonly involve the macula.
