    • Exudative Retinal Detachment.
  • Management:
    • Observation - in mild disease without visual symptoms or in patients without the potential for visual recovery.
    • Laser ablation of leakage points causing exudation.
    • Intravitreal Anti-VEGF therapy.
    • Cryotherapy as an alternative to laser ablation.
    • Vitreoretinal surgery if tractional fibrosis or total retinal detachment.

 

Option B: Familial exudative vitreoretinopathy

  • Slowly progressive failure of vascularization of the temporal retinal periphery similar to ROP.
  • Autosomal Dominant inheritance with high penetrance and variable expressivity.
  • Usually presents in childhood.
  • Poor prognosis due to early aggressive onset.
  • Associated with high myopia.
  • Presents with peripheral avascularity with the abrupt termination of retinal vessels temporally.
  • Peripheral vascular tortuosity and telangiectasia can progress
  • Fibrovascular proliferation with or without subretinal exudation.
  • Tractional and or rhegmatogenous retinal detachment
  • Management:
    • Requires lifelong monitoring.
    • Laser ablation of the avascular retina.
    • Vitreoretinal surgery for Retinal detachment:
    • Relatives need to be screened as well.​​​​​​​

Option C: Retinoblastoma

  • The most common primary intra-ocular malignant retina tumor occurs in children before age five. Hereditary retinoblastoma is due to the Autosomal Dominant inheritance of RB1 gene mutations.
  • It may be unifocal or multifocal. In cases with younger age of presentation, the disease tends to be bilateral, multifocal, and more aggressive. Patients with heritable retinoblastoma are also at increased risk of developing non-ocular tumors.​​​​​​​
  • Growth may be endophytic or exophytic, or diffuse. The Hallmark is intra-ocular calcification. Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes are a hallmark of retinoblastoma on histopathology.
  • Retinal detachment can occur due to exudation near the underlying tumor, neovascularization, and tractional retinal detachment.

Option D: Retinopathy of Prematurity

  • Seen in premature low-birth-weight infants, including additional risk factors such as high ambient oxygen concentrations, prolonged hospitalization, perinatal sepsis, etc.
  • As expected, this would be seen in infancy and not in young children and is identified based on screening.
  • Retinal detachment can occur in patients in due progress of ROP.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to a sudden loss of vision in the right eye. It is associated with pain on eye movement. She had a history of acute disseminated encephalomyelitis 2 months ago, for which she was treated with oral prednisolone. On examination, she can only count fingers when seeing from the right eye (visual acuity). A positive afferent pupillary defect is also present. The ophthalmologist suspects optic neuritis. Which of the following is least likely to diagnose optic neuritis?
questions.solution:
Option C: B-scan ultrasonography (USG)

  • Optic neuritis is a severe, painful visual impairment typically affecting young people.
  • Demyelinating disease, such as multiple sclerosis, is its most frequent cause.
  • Other causes include infections (measles, mumps,  tuberculosis, Lyme disease) and autoimmune disorders (sarcoidosis, systemic lupus erythematosus).
  • Common symptoms include unilateral progressive vision loss, impaired colour vision, pain in eye movement, the presence of relative afferent pupillary deficit (RAPD), and normal-appearing fundus with mild papilledema in ⅓ patients.
  • The investigations used to diagnose optic neuritis involve:
  • MRI
  • Blood tests (ESR, antibodies in neuromyelitis optica)
  • Optical coherence tomography (OCT)
  • Visual field test
  • Visual evoked response.
  • B-scan ultrasonography (USG) is used to diagnose conditions affecting the eyeball's posterior segment.
  • Common diseases in which a USG B scan is used are vitreous degeneration, retinal detachment, trauma, and retinoblastoma.
  • However, it is not useful for diagnosing optic neuritis.

Option A: MRI head and orbit

  • MRI head and orbit is the most important test that detects optic nerve inflammation.
  • It also reveals demyelination foci in the brain, especially in periventricular white matter regions, seen in a patient with multiple sclerosis.

 

Option B:  Erythrocyte sedimentation rate

  • ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation) rate help detect inflammation in the body.
  • It is a nonspecific marker that is increased in infectious causes of optic neuritis.

Option D: Visual field test

  • Checking the visual field is useful for evaluating the progression and extent of the disease and is also important for follow-up.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to his family physician with complaints of vertical diplopia. He further explains that he feels unsure while descending stairs. He can eliminate the double vision by tilting his head toward the opposite side. The patient is otherwise vitally stable and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Which of the following extraocular muscles is responsible for ocular malalignment in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Superior oblique

  • This is a case of superior oblique palsy in which the patient presents with complaints of vertical diplopia.
  • The patient further explains he feels unsure while descending stairs.
  • The superior oblique depresses, abducts, and intorts the eye.
  • Paralysis of this muscle results in extorsion and weakness of downward gaze.
  • Head tilting compensates for extorsion.
  • Chin depression would be seen in superior oblique palsy.

Option A: Inferior rectus

  • One of the seven extraocular muscles, the inferior rectus, is principally in charge of depressing the eye (downgaze).
  • One of the four rectus muscles is the inferior rectus.
  • Other rectus muscles are the superior rectus, medial rectus, and lateral rectus.

Option B: Inferior oblique

  • The inferior oblique causes the movements of extorsion, elevation, and abduction.
  • The only muscles that can lower or raise the eye when the eye moves in adduction are the superior and inferior oblique muscles due to their courses.

Option C: Lateral rectus

  • The flat-shaped anterior portion of the lateral rectus is wider than the rest of the muscle.
  • Along with the medial rectus, an adductor, the lateral rectus muscle moves the eye laterally and side to side.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man visits the clinic with a complaint of multiple, small, pruritic, and discolored skin patches on his upper chest and back for the last three weeks. He has no chronic medical condition and takes no medications. On examination, multiple hypopigmented circular macules are found on his upper chest and back, which are arranged around the hair follicles. Fine scaling is also evident on the surface of these macules. Similar lesions appeared on his neck last summer and resolved with topical treatment. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to obtain at this time?

choices.text: Slit skin smear from discrete macules

questions.solution:
Option A: Potassium hydroxide preparation of scales

This patient with multiple small, pruritic hypopigmented macules on his chest and back along with fine scales and a history of such lesions during the last summer season that resolved with topical treatment suggests the diagnosis of Tinea versicolor.

  • Tinea versicolor is most commonly associated with Malassezia spp.
  • Lesions appear mainly during the summers or after a visit to an area exposing the body to a large amount of sunlight because the lesions typically do not tan in the sunlight.
  • KOH preparations are used on scaling skin lesions for diagnostic purposes as it dissolves keratin and allows easier visualization of fungal elements.
  • Microscopic examination of the KOH mount reveals short hyphae and round spores with a characteristic "Spaghetti and meatballs" appearance.

Option B: Slit skin smear from discrete macules

  • It is helpful in the diagnosis of leprosy to demonstrate acid-fast bacilli.

Option C: Tzanck test

  • It is used to demonstrate multinucleated giant cells in herpes infection.

Option D: Skin biopsy of coalesced macules

  • It is helpful in cases of hypopigmented infiltered plaques to rule out mycosis fungoides.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presented during the summer with a 2-day history of a painful, itchy rash affecting his face and neck. He had been helping to clear his neighbor’s garden for the preceding fortnight. He had recently been found to have mild hypertension, treated with bendroflumethiazide. He was otherwise well. On examination, he had a confluent rash localized to his face and neck (see image) with associated periorbital edema. The remainder of the examination was normal. A presumptive diagnosis of allergic contact dermatitis was made, and patch testing was scheduled after the rash had settled. What is the most likely candidate allergen?
questions.solution:
Option D: Sesquiterpene lactone mix

  • Sesquiterpene lactone mix consists of three allergens (alantolactone, costunolide, and dehydrocostus lactone).
  • Sesquiterpene lactone is a diverse group of chemicals found in several plants which cause contact dermatitis.
  • It may take several days for the symptoms to appear.
  • It causes redness, swelling, itching, and fluid-filled blisters.
  • Sesquiterpene lactone mix containing some vegetables and teas such as lettuce chamomile tea may induce systemic allergic reaction through the cell-mediated mechanism.
  • Image shows lesion over the exposed area of face & neck.

  • Probable cause ABCD (airborne contact dermatitis).
  • Parthenium hysterophorus causes ABCD (airborne contact dermatitis)
  • Allergen present is a sesquiterpene lactone.
  • Positive on patch testing.
  • Treatment – Corticosteroids and azathioprine.

Option A: Solar urticarial

  • Solar urticarial is an allergic reaction to sun exposure.
  • It causes an itchy rash or hives on the skin which has been exposed to the sun. 
  • The rash may look like wheals and will be red and swollen.

Option B: Fragrance

  • Most commonly affects the skin and face causing itchiness, redness, rash, or even blisters formation.
  • Fragrance allergies can also affect the eyes, causing redness, tearing, itching, and burning.

Option C: Parabens

  • Parabens offer good antimicrobial coverage.
  • It causes an immediate onset of pain, redness, itching, and burning.
  • Symptoms resolve within ten minutes if the causative material is removed from the skin.

questions.text: A 49-year-old female visits the clinic with a complaint of recurrent painful blisters over the oral mucosa and genital area for the past many months. She gives a history of a similar lesion in the past. A biopsy from the lesion shows a supra-basal split on histopathology and IgG deposits in immunofluorescence microscopy, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pemphigus vulgaris

  • Pointers in favor of Pemphigus vulgaris
    • Recurrent painful blisters over oral mucosa and genital area
    • Biopsy- Supra-basal split
    • Immunofluorescence microscopy- IgG deposits
    • The Immunofluorescent examination finding in Pemphigus Vulgaris is the deposition of lgG & C3 in intercellular space, giving a fish net pattern.

Option A: Eczema

  • Erythematous papules plaques with oozing eczematous surface.

Option C: Lupus vulgaris

  • It is a painful and nodular tuberculosis skin lesion
  • It is characterized by a granulomatous plaque with an extension on one end, atrophy, and healing on the other.

Option D: Dermatitis herpetiformis

  • Antigen: Transglutaminase 3
  • It presents as itchy papulovesicular lesions of the extremities, knees, elbows, and buttocks.
  • IgA deposition at papillary dermis in a granular pattern known as picket fence appearance.

questions.text: A 40 years old woman presented to the clinic with a history of seizure episodes, spasticity, and lower limb weakness for the last 2 months. She also complains of hearing loss and unsteadiness while standing and walking. She needs to support herself against a wall to avoid falling. She has not had any recent injuries and has no history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an unsteady gait. She sways when asked to stand upright with her feet together. She cannot hear fingers rubbing next to her ears or repeat words whispered in her ears. MRI brain showed a 3-cm tumor in the right cerebellopontine angle and a 4.5-cm tumor in the left cerebellopontine angle. The condition was associated with the gene defect coding for protein merlin. The most typical neurological tumor associated with gene defect is?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acoustic Neuroma

  • Acoustic neuromas (also known as vestibular schwannomas) are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII.
  • The tumor is formed within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle.
  • Most tumors are unilateral. Bilateral acoustic neuromas strongly suggest the genetic condition neurofibromatosis type II.
  • Gene affected: NF2 gene located on chromosome 22.
  • NF-2 gene codes for Merlin protein.
  • Common signs and symptoms of acoustic neuroma include:
    • Hearing loss, usually gradually worsening over months to years — although in rare cases sudden — and occurring on only one side or more severe on one side
    • Ringing (tinnitus) in the affected ear
    • Unsteadiness or loss of balance
    • Dizziness (vertigo)
    • Facial numbness and weakness or loss of muscle movement
  • Pathology- Gross findings: encapsulated firm mass.
  • Microscopic findings- Spindle cells in palisades (Antoni A tissue) alternating with myxoid hypocellular areas (Antoni B tissue), S-100 positive.

  • Diagnosis of acoustic neuroma involves audiometry that demonstrates ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss and MRI with contrast to confirm the tumor.
  • Contrast MRI (imaging modality of choice): Recommended in patients with abnormal audiometric testing or high clinical suspicion of acoustic neuroma (cerebellopontine angle syndrome)
  • CT with and without contrast is an alternative for those who cannot undergo MRI. It shows an enhancing lesion by the internal auditory canal, with possible extension into the cerebellopontine angle.

  • The treatment of choice for patients with large tumors or significant hearing loss is surgical removal or radiation therapy. However, observation with follow-up may be appropriate for patients with smaller tumors and minimal hearing loss.
  • On average, the prognosis is favorable, as acoustic neuromas are usually benign, slow-growing tumors with low recurrence rates.

Option B: Optic Glioma

  • It is a false statement.
  • Optic nerve glioma is a slow-growing tumor that typically affects children.
  • 30% of patients have associated NF1 & those have a better prognosis.
  • Gene affected: NF1 gene located on chromosome 17.
  • NF-1 gene codes for Neurofibromin protein.
  • Malignant gliomas (glioblastoma) are rare & almost always occur in adult males with an inferior prognosis & almost certain death within one year.

Option C: Café-Au-Lait Macules

  • It is a false statement.
  • Well pigmented circumscribed macules.
  • Their size may range from a few millimeters to several centimeters (>20cm) and may appear at birth or in early life.
  • Gene affected: NF1 gene located on chromosome 17.
  • NF-1 gene codes for Neurofibromin protein.

Option D: Brainstem Glioma

  • It is a false statement.
  • Childhood brain stem glioma is a disease in which benign (non-cancer) or malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the brain stem.
  • Gene affected: NF1 gene located on chromosome 17
  • NF 1 gene codes for Neurofibromin protein
